title: FDPFNet: A Frequency-Domain Progressive Fusion Network for Optical-SAR Multi-Label Remote Sensing Scene Classification
authors: Yiming Zhao, Kunlun Qi, Yaxian Qing, Kelong Tu, Jiajun Tao, Hongge Li, Chao Yang, Hongyan Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The fusion of optical and SAR remote sensing imagery has become increasingly crucial for accurate multi-label remote sensing scene classification (MRSSC), which plays an essential role in producing reliable land use and land cover (LULC) products. However, visual heterogeneity between optical and SAR data, together with the speckle noise inherent in SAR imagery, greatly limits the performance of existing multimodal fusion approaches. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes a Frequency-Domain Progressive Fusion Network (FDPFNet) that adopts a hybrid CNN–Transformer architecture to serve as an effective and unified multimodal backbone for MRSSC. First, a Low-Frequency Convolution (LFConv) block is introduced, utilizing wavelet transform to highlight low-frequency components shared across modalities while suppressing high-frequency noise in SAR data. Second, a Two-Frequency Decomposition (TFD) block is designed to decompose features into high- and low-frequency components, allowing comprehensive fusion of modality-shared low-frequency semantics while mitigating the adverse effects of inconsistent high-frequency details. Finally, an Adaptive Feature Fusion (AFF) block is developed to dynamically balance intra-modal feature consistency and inter-modal complementarity across multiple hierarchical levels, thereby achieving more effective optical–SAR fusion. Extensive experiments conducted on the BigEarthNet-MM and SEN12-MLRS datasets demonstrate that FDPFNet consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods, and the ablation studies further verify the effectiveness of each proposed module and the overall architecture.

title: Resilient Consensus of State-Delayed Uncertain Lagrangian Agents Using Sampled and Delayed Neighbor Information
authors: Haris E. Psillakis, Athanasios K. Gkesoulis, Athanasios-Rafail Lagos
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems
abstract: In this paper, we develop a robust methodology for resilient consensus in complex nonlinear multi-agent systems (MASs). While substantial work has been done on resilient consensus using the mean-subsequent reduced (MSR) algorithm, challenges remain, particularly when considering communication time-delays and bounded disturbances in linear and nonlinear systems. To address these issues, we introduce a novel variable transformation that reformulates the resilient output consensus problem with delayed and sampled output data, into a continuous-time regulation problem. This transformation enables the extension of the weighted-MSR (W-MSR) algorithm to settings with bounded disturbances and variable time-delays. A key innovation is the incorporation of a drift term in the W-MSR update ensuring bounded system evolution under persistent disturbances. Using this transformation, a distributed controller is then proposed for agents in Euler-Lagrange form with unknown nonlinearities, disturbances and state delays that achieves consensus under adversarial attacks, utilizing only delayed and sampled measurements of neighbor outputs. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methodology through simulations of a group of underactuated robotic vehicles.

title: Systematic Analysis of Blockchain Based Trust Management Frameworks in Crowdfunding
authors: Saddam Hussain, Shehnila Zardari, Mehar Ullah
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This systematic analysis explores the integration of blockchain-based trust management frameworks within crowdfunding platforms, focusing on their ability to resolve key issues such as fraud, lack of transparency, and limited accountability. Crowdfunding, which relies on trust between funders and project creators, is often undermined by centralized control and information asymmetry. Blockchain technology offers a compelling alternative with its inherent decentralized structure and capacity for automated enforcement. This study critically examines how smart contracts, decentralized identity systems, and trust scoring mechanisms based on blockchain can reinforce trust and enhance security in crowdfunding environments. The findings highlight that blockchain enables more reliable verification processes, tamper-proof transaction records, and automated contract enforcement, all of which contribute to increased stakeholder confidence. Despite these advantages, challenges such as legal uncertainties, technical barriers, scalability issues, and adoption resistance continue to hinder full-scale implementation. The analysis also considers ethical and regulatory implications, emphasizing the need for robust governance and interoperable frameworks to support long-term viability. Ultimately, blockchain has the potential to redefine the trust architecture of crowdfunding platforms by fostering greater transparency, accountability, and inclusivity, offering a foundation for more secure and effective fundraising ecosystems in the digital age.

title: ViT-ResNet Fusion: An Explainable Hybrid Framework for High-Accuracy Multiclass Lung Disease Classification in Chest X-Rays
authors: Rahul Deva, Arvind Dagur
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Chest radiographs are widely used to clinically diagnose thoracic diseases such as lung opacity, pneumonia, and coronavirus disease 2019 due to their cost-effectiveness and easy access. However, accurate interpretation remains challenging because of overlapping anatomical structures, low contrast, and subtle disease manifestations. Classical deep learning models are effective but often exhibit overfitting, and weak interpretability, which restricts their clinical applicability. This paper presents an attention-driven hybrid framework that integrates contrast-limited adaptive histogram equalization-based enhancement with a dual-backbone architecture combining a vision transformer and a residual network. The vision transformer captures global contextual dependencies, while the residual network extracts local discriminative features. The concatenated representations are classified using a multi-layer perceptron and optimized end-to-end with the AdamW optimizer and a step learning rate scheduler. To improve transparency, gradient-weighted class activation mapping is used to highlight disease-relevant regions in chest radiographs. Experimental evaluation highlights that the proposed framework achieves 98.54% classification accuracy, outperforming state-of-the-art models, including EfficientNet 96.20%, DenseNet 97.50%, and a fine-tuned vision transformer 95.79%. To ensure generalizability, cross-dataset validation was conducted and trained on COVID-19 Radiography Dataset. The same model was tested on an independent COVID–Pneumonia–Normal chest X-ray dataset which achieved an accuracy of 94.07% and demonstrated good performance over heterogeneous imaging sources. These findings confirm the proposed framework’s robustness, interpretability, and suitability for real-time clinical decision support in both pandemic and routine diagnostic settings.

title: Data-Efficient Constrained Robot Learning With Probabilistic Lagrangian Control_supp1-3648503.mp4
authors: Shiming He
publish: N/A
abstract: We propose a novel framework for data-efficient black-box robot learning under constraints. Our approach integrates probabilistic inference with Lagrangian optimization. With the guide of a learned Gaussian process model, the Lagrange multiplier is controlled by the probability of whether the constraints would be satisfied. This reduces the typical oscillations seen in primal-dual updates and therefore improves both data efficiency and safety during learning. Both synthetic results and robot experiments demonstrate that our method is a scalable and effective solution for constrained robot learning problems.

title: Eliciting Pleasantness With Haptic Feedback: The Role of Physical and Pseudo-Haptic Resistance in Virtual Archery_supp1-3648732.mp4
authors: Yusuke Ujitoko
publish: N/A
abstract: Although haptic technologies that allow users to touch virtual objects have been actively researched in the academic field of haptics, they are not yet widely adopted in real-world applications. To promote broader adoption, designing haptic stimuli that elicit pleasant sensations is essential since hedonic motivation significantly drives user acceptance. However, how such pleasantness can be effectively induced through haptic stimulation during a user's active exploration remains an open question. Furthermore, it is unclear whether “pseudo-haptics”, a low-cost substitute for physical force feedback, can also serve effectively in this affective context. In this study, we investigated the relationship between the applied force during user actions and the resulting pleasantness, using a bow-dragging and arrow-shooting scenario as a case study. Specifically, we conducted three psychophysical experiments to investigate two types of force feedback. One type was a physical force that stimulated the kinesthetic sense, and the other was a pseudo force induced through visual manipulation. Our results revealed that pleasantness tended to be elicited when physical resistance force was present during bow dragging, whereas this tendency was not observed for pseudo resistance force. While there has been a general assumption that pseudo-haptics can replace physical stimuli to some extent in the rendering of haptic properties, our findings quantitatively show that in our case the two are not interchangeable for eliciting positive affect. We also found that the arrow's flying speed contributed to pleasantness as much as the physical resistance force, suggesting that pleasantness is influenced postdictively. Moreover, across all experiments, perceived pleasantness was strongly correlated with the perceived naturalness of the bow-and-arrow behavior. These findings provide valuable insights for designing pleasant interactions involving continuous force feedback, highlighting the distinct roles of physical and pseudo-haptic cues.

title: Channel Estimation for Movable Antenna Systems: Exploiting Joint Sparse and Low-Rank Structure
authors: Zipeng Lian, Wanyue Zhang, Yunchao Song, Chen Liu
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: This paper investigates the problem of channel estimation in millimeter-wave movable antenna systems. Unlike previous methods solely based on sparsity, we propose a channel estimation method that simultaneously exploits both the sparsity in the angular domain and the low-rank structure of the channel. Specifically, by leveraging these properties, the channel estimation problem is formulated as a matrix completion problem, where sparsity is promoted by incorporating ℓ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sub>-norm term in the objective function and the low-rank structure is enforced via a rank constraint. Simultaneously, we theoretically analyze the minimum number of samples required for channel matrix recovery and propose a two-stage sampling method. To handle the non-smooth ℓ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sub>-norm term, we apply its subgradient method. To address the non-convex low-rank constraint, we adopt a retraction-free descent algorithm with a rank reduction to construct a search direction on the restricted tangent cone and determine the optimal rank. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method for channel estimation with limited samples significantly outperforms existing methods.

title: Low-Complexity SQRD-Based CSI Feedback for Wi-Fi MU-MIMO
authors: Zexiao Lu, Bin Wu, Xiaoxin Liang, Xiaoping Zhou, Guangxi Liu
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: The performance of Wi-Fi multi-user MIMO (MU-MIMO) systems critically depends on timely and accurate channel state information (CSI) feedback, but its practical deployment is fundamentally constrained by the trade-off between performance and complexity. Singular value decomposition (SVD)-based schemes provide near-optimal performance but incur prohibitive computational cost, whereas QR decomposition (QRD)-based schemes offer hardware-friendly but cannot support power allocation. This letter proposes a novel sorted QRD (SQRD)-based scheme, retaining the low complexity of QRD while enabling power allocation. Simulations demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves performance comparable to the SVD benchmark, offering a low-complexity and hardware-friendly solution for next-generation Wi-Fi.

title: Recovery Operation in HfZrO x -Based FeFETs With Interfacial Layer Scavenging
authors: Bong Ho Kim, Seong Kwang Kim, Song-Hyeon Kuk, Jaeyong Jeong, Youngkeun Park, Yoon-Je Suh, Joon Pyo Kim, Chan Jik Lee, Dae-Myeong Geum, Byung Jin Cho, Sang Hyeon Kim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: This work investigates the recovery operation and interfacial layer (IL) scavenging to improve the performance and reliability of HfZrO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</sub>-based ferroelectric field-effect transistors (FeFETs). A systematic electrical characterization demonstrated that IL scavenging reduces the operating voltage and initial interface traps while mitigating interface trap generation and ferroelectric fatigue induced by stress cycling, thereby improving memory window (MW) recovery capability. In addition, by investigating the frequency of recovery pulses under iso-time conditions, we found that lower frequencies are favorable for complete MW recovery. Our findings offer a valuable understanding of the degradation and recovery mechanisms in FeFETs, underscoring the critical role of recovery speed and controlled IL.

title: Research on the Basic Characteristics and Development Paths of Digital Think Tanks: An AI-Driven Transformation Framework
authors: Tao Wang, Kaiyue Yang, Ying Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: The global digital transformation coupled with rapid advancements in Artificial Intelligence (AI) is fundamentally reshaping the knowledge infrastructure and operational paradigms of think tanks. This paper proposes a comprehensive analytical framework to investigate the AI-driven transformation of digital think tanks. We establish a formal system model to characterize the core components and functional capabilities of digital think tanks, incorporating insights from international case studies. The research conducts a qualitative comparative analysis of development patterns across China, the United States, and Europe based on documented evidence and published reports. Furthermore, we propose a strategic development framework for the intelligent upgrading of digital think tanks in China, identifying key technological pathways and institutional mechanisms. Research indicates that AI technologies are transitioning digital think tanks from informatization to a new intelligent phase, reshaping their knowledge production models, decision-support methodologies, and international collaboration patterns

title: A Survey on RIS-Assisted UAV Communication in Edge Computing: Synergistic Mechanisms and Optimization Strategies
authors: Mengxiao Zhang, Xinyu Yu, Wuyungerile Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: Traditional edge computing (EC) systems face critical bottlenecks: limited coverage, signal blockage, and low energy efficiency. To address these, we focus on the synergistic integration of RIS, UAV, and EC technologies. This paper systematically integrates the technical frameworks of RIS, UAV, and EC, with an emphasis on multidimensional collaborative mechanisms. It explores the synergistic benefits in areas such as system energy efficiency optimization, computational task offloading, latency control, and physical layer security. Furthermore, key technologies, optimization algorithms, and recent research progress in RIS-UAV-EC systems are thoroughly analyzed, and future directions are outlined, providing theoretical foundations and design insights for constructing efficient and intelligent low-altitude edge communication networks. Recent research findings<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[1]</sup> demonstrate that in specific deployment scenarios, increasing the number of aerial RIS elements can enhance system energy efficiency by up to 50%. Furthermore, a comprehensive review<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[2]</sup> confirms that compared to traditional UAV-Edge Computing (UAV-EC) systems, the integration of RIS with UAVs significantly reduces latency and extends coverage range. These results underscore the substantial potential of the RIS-UAV-EC collaborative architecture in building sustainable, low-latency, and high-efficiency edge computing networks.

title: Data Spaces Against Hybrid Warfare: A Novel Way to Achieve Resilience
authors: Borislav Bankov
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: Most experts contend that achieving resilience to hybrid warfare (HW), the synergetic blend of conventional and unconventional warfighting, requires sharpening of the West's technological edge. Of all technologies, artificial intelligence (AI) receives the most attention with specialists asserting that AI has strategic-level implications for HW. Meanwhile, one much less-examined factor in the technology discussions on HW is data. The lack of research on data is surprising, given the consensus on the critical role of AI in HW. At a minimum, from a technical perspective, one cannot train AI models without robust datasets. At a maximum, if hybrid actors can abuse siloed data systems to disrupt critical functions, then the West requires robust data governance to counter HW. This article thus asks how the data challenges of achieving resilience to HW could be sustainably resolved. The objective is: (i) to analyze the data challenges of tackling HW; (ii) to offer a working framework to resolve them. The text combines defense studies with latest insights from data science to argue that data spaces (DS), a novel data governance model, are uniquely qualified to resolve the data challenges of resilience. DS are trusted interoperable data sharing ecosystems that can supercharge national and international collaboration. DS can thus lead to enhanced detection and foresight of hybrid operations, more robust legislation and innovation cycles, and an overall paradigm shift toward data-driven resilience to HW.

title: Comparative Analysis of YOLO8 and YOLO11 for Cold Spots Detection on the Lunar Surface
authors: Shachaf Weil Zattelman, Fadi Kizel
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Lunar cold spots are thermal anomalies linked to fresh impact craters. Detecting and understanding them provides insights into the Moon's surface evolution and thermophysical properties. This study evaluates YOLOv8 and YOLOv11 deep learning models for automating cold spot detection using Diviner radiometer data. The training dataset, derived from 128-pixel-per-degree nighttime regolith temperature maps (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 60^{\circ}$</tex> latitude), included 384 images with 652 annotated cold spots. Testing utilized 4,816 overlapping <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 1 2} \times \text{5 1 2}$</tex>-pixel sub-images from the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{2 0 2 3}$</tex> High-Resolution Nighttime Temperature map. In summary, Both models excelled in detecting faint anomalies, while YOLOv11 outperformed YOLOv8, achieving precision (0.85), recall (0.78), and F1 score (0.81) in cross-validation. In addition, both significantly outperformed manual methods, identifying previously undetected cold spots and enhancing our understanding of lunar thermal anomalies. These findings highlight deep learning's transformative role in planetary exploration, combining precision and scalability for efficient data analysis.
