title: Multi-Entropy Feature Extraction with LSTM Networks for Acoustic Emission-Based Railway Crack Localization
authors: Popphon Laon, Supavee Pourbunthidkul, Praphaporn Rattan, Tanawit Sahavisit, Wara Suwansin, Pattharin Wichittrakarn, Pattarapong Phasukkit, Nongluck Houngkamhang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Railway infrastructure security is contingent upon the prompt identification of structural anomalies within steel tracks. This research establishes a framework that merges acoustic emission (AE) sensing with advanced machine learning for prompt fracture identification and location. To improve the quality of Raw AE signals, they are first cleaned using Kalman filtering to tackle environmental disturbances and ambiguous readings. The characteristics that arise from entropy comprising approximate entropy, Shannon entropy, and dimensional entropy are derived to delineate the temporal patterns of fracture-induced emissions. Density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise (DBSCAN) is applied to remove outliers during preprocessing. Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks classify crack locations into three anatomical regions: rail head, web, and foot. Experimental validation with 3,000 labeled AE signals (1,000 per class) under laboratory conditions, the full pipeline that integrates Kalman filtering, entropy features, DBSCAN, and an LSTM classifier attains an accuracy of 98.83%. With an entropy-based variant, the accuracy drops to 96.67%, confirming the incremental value of temporal denoising and outlier rejection. While using mel-frequency cepstral coefficient (MFCC) baseline achieves 97.67% accuracy, a deep neural network (DNN) trained on Kalman-filtered, entropy-based, and DBSCAN-processed inputs reaches 96.33% accuracy, underscoring the advantages of temporal modeling for AE. A GRU using the same Kalman-filtered, entropy-based, and DBSCAN-processed inputs, achieves 97.67% accuracy, but trails the LSTM overall. When deployed on actual railway lines with a mobile inspection platform, the system maintained robust performance, correctly identifying 84.67% of cracks at 3 km/h and 80.67% at 5 km/h. The LSTM configuration consistently outperformed all alternative approaches, including the entropy-only variant, MFCC-based method, DNN classifier, and GRU model. This confirms the LSTM’s enhanced capability to capture the temporal dynamics of AE signals, establishing it as the most effective framework for AE-based crack localization in railway structural health monitoring.

title: Weighted Community Division for Automated Software Architecture Refactoring
authors: Sirong Zhao, Jialing Yang, Jiao Xie, Kaiwei Fan, Jianmei Lei, Guoqi Xie
publish: IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering
abstract:
Adopting Model-Based Development (MBD) in automotive software becomes necessary because it provides a rigorous development process. As the increase in the number of software components (SWCs) and their interactions, modifications to one part of the software might impact other parts due to the high coupling of SWCs. Developing an automated software refactoring technique to implement high cohesion and low coupling of software is necessary. Software refactoring usually contains code refactoring and architecture refactoring. Code refactoring only modifies the code inside the SWCs without changing its original functionality and external behavior, whereas current architecture refactoring does not consider the interaction weight (strength) between SWCs.

In this study, we propose a weighted community division algorithm called Weighted-Girvan-Newman (W-GN) for software architecture refactoring. W-GN algorithm refactors the architecture by dividing SWCs into modules based on the interaction weights of SWCs. We further develop an automated architecture refactoring tool called AutoToolMD. This tool assists engineers in improving development efficiency and ensures the architecture aligns with the requirements of high cohesion and low coupling. Evaluations show that W-GN indicates more suitable modularity values than the traditional Girvan-Newman (GN) algorithm because the former can better reflect the real architecture with interaction weights. We apply AutoToolMD to automatically refactor architecture in automotive industry practice. Case study with the Zone_B PwrSplyMngt and Zone L_Lock modules in the Honda zone control software shows that AutoToolMD effectively refactors architecture with a significant improvement in testing efficiency and readability.

authors: Ashiqur Rahaman Molla, Ram Mohan Chowdary Kota, Jaishree Mayank, Arnab Sarkar, Arijit Mondal, Soumyajit Dey

title: A Novel Rat Robot: Multi Degree of Freedom Motion Control_supp2-3648651.mp4
authors: le zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Objective: The development of brain-computer interface (BCI) technology has enabled animals to execute movements in accordance with human intent. The rat robot represents a novel robotic system based on BCI technology. However, due to limitations in electrode fabrication techniques and the use of simplistic control strategies, current rat robots are restricted to limited movement patterns, which hinder their applicability in real-world scenarios. To address these challenges, we have developed a portable wireless neural stimulator and a novel 3D integrated stimulating electrode. By refining the locomotion control strategy, we aim to achieve complex, high-degree-of-freedom movement in rat robot systems. Methods: 3D integrated electrodes were implanted into the rats' head, with no reward-based training required. By utilizing a wearable wireless stimulation backpack to connect the electrodes and deliver electrical stimulation to multiple brain regions, thereby enabling the rat to perform forward movement, turning, and stopping behaviors. Results: The experimental results demonstrate that under optimized stimulation parameters, the forward speed of the rat robot can be controlled to achieve 31.06 ± 1.21 m/min, the turning angle can reach up to 150 ± 1.22°, and the stopping duration can be flexibly adjusted. Furthermore, we presented a practical scenario in which the rat robot successfully executed a predefined navigation task in a real-world environment, thereby validating its high degree of movement flexibility and control precision. Conclusion: This study achieved high-degree-of-freedom motion control of rat robots without the need for reward-based training, which was previously unattainable. Significance: This research establishes a crucial foundation and provides valuable technical references for the application of animal robots in fields such as information reconnaissance and wreckage search and rescue operations.

title: Protection Method for Continuous Operation of Wind Power Plants in a Mechanical Circuit Breaker Based Multi-Terminal HVDC System
authors: Mitsuyoshi Enomoto, Keima Wakatsuki, Kenichiro Sano
publish: IEEE Open Access Journal of Power and Energy
abstract: Multi-terminal high-voltage dc (HVDC) transmission system is a promising approach to connect offshore wind power plants (WPPs) to onshore ac grids. However, there is no standardized protection method against DC faults. As one of its protection methods, mechanical dc circuit breakers (DCCBs) have the potential to improve supply reliability against dc faults while avoiding a cost increase. Nevertheless, due to their relatively slower operation, the blocking of half-bridge based modular multilevel converter (HBMMC) is often required. In offshore ac collecting system, where the HBMMC maintains the grid voltage, such converter blocking can destabilize the grid voltage and lead to shutdowns of offshore WPPs. Large scale shutdowns of offshore WPPs may have a negative impact on onshore ac grids. Therefore, this article proposes a protection method that enables the continuous operation of offshore WPPs while using mechanical DCCBs. The proposed method focuses on the backbone HVDC configuration connecting multiple onshore and offshore terminals, and applies different fault clearing methods across the terminals. At onshore terminals which form a loop configuration, mechanical DCCBs selectively isolate the faulted section. At offshore terminals which form a radial configuration, reconfiguration is employed to reroute power transmission from the faulted line to the healthy line. These operations are coordinated based on the fault ride-through (FRT) capability of offshore WPPs and realizes their continuous operation. The proposed method is verified by an experiment using the scaled-down three-terminal HVDC system.

title: Semantic Consistency Interaction with Calibration Loss for Remote Sensing Image-Text Retrieval
authors: Jinlong Xu, Yun Ge, Yan Zeng, Huyang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote Sensing Image-Text Retrieval (RSITR) plays a crucial role in the remote sensing community but faces difficulties due to the heterogeneity between the image and text modalities. While existing methods primarily focus on enhancing cross-modal alignment, they suffer from two key issues. One is that fine-grained local alignment approaches extract local features lacking contextual integration, which leads to semantic inconsistency. The other is that conventional losses fail to adapt to the varying model states of different subtasks, which may lead to the model calibration problems. This implies a mismatch between the confidence scores of the network and the true probabilities. To address these challenges, this study proposes two complementary components. One is a Local Semantic Consistency Interaction (LSCI) module, which uses cross-attention and self-attention along with an image-text alignment head to optimize multimodal representations and mitigate context-induced semantic inconsistency. The other is Task-specific Calibration loss (TC), which dynamically adjusts the gamma parameter in Focal or inv-Focal loss, allowing the model to prioritize both hard and easy sample pairs according to the calibration error specific to each subtask. The gamma parameter is adjusted by leveraging the previous states of the model and the knowledge of calibration performance on the validation set. By integrating the LSCI module and TC loss, the semantic inconsistency between image and text can be improved, and model calibration can be enhanced. Comparative assessments conducted on three public datasets show that our methods can achieve competitive performance on the RSITR task compared to many existing methods. The source code is available at https://github.com/StrongerPeople/LSCI-TC.

title: DCT-Based Video Steganography with Error Correction for Secure and Robust Data Hiding
authors: Sriharsha Upadhya P, Guru Prasad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Video steganography provides a method of secret communication by embedding data in the intricate frame structure of the video file, enabling the hidden data to escape hiding. This paper presented a video steganography system based on a discrete cosine transform (DCT) that embeds text messages into the luminance component of the video frames, and ensures that the data is robust against noise and compression by employing a repetition-based error correction coding (ECC) scheme, where the message is embedded by modifying DC coefficients of deterministically chosen 8x8 pixel blocks with fixed-strength (150.0). The steganography system was evaluated using a wide range of metrics including peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), mean squared error (MSE), bit error rate (BER), mean absolute error (MAE), and root mean squared error (RMSE).In addition, the difference between the DC coefficient distributions in the embedding of the original frames and the steganographic one is represented as histograms to help chronicle the way the steganographic process may have impacted the frequency domain. The results of high PSNR and SNR with low levels of MSE, RMSE, MAE, and BER suggest a successful data hiding procedure by examining the visual changes to the steganographic frames. Comprehensive information is provided by the logging and diagnostic outputs the steganographic and video embedding algorithms produced, including saved DC coefficient distributions in the traditional frequency domain. All of these elements helped to show that DCT-based video steganography is a viable way to communicate in a secure manner and that there are possibilites to improve efficiency in hiding data, while minimizing impact to the visual quality of the video frame.

title: Estimation of Forest Stand Height Based on Individual Tree Detection Using UAV Laser Scanning Data
authors: Qingwang Liu, Fengqin Hao, Ying Guo, Liyong Fu, Linglong Zhao
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Forest stand height has been used as a crucial parameter for regional or global biomass or carbon storage inventory. The UAV laser scanning could acquire high density point cloud data to detect individual trees, which were further used for estimation of forest structure parameters. However, it is quite difficulty to accurately segment tree crowns in closed forest canopies. An individual tree detection algorithm based on Gaussian probability distribution was proposed to extract tree heights and crown areas in the temperate forest. The effects of the overlapping point cloud among flight strips and the smoothed CHM were also been analyzed. The Lorey's heights from field measurements of individual trees were modeled using the mean height and mean height weighted by crown area of detected individual trees. The metrics of point cloud were also extracted to model the Lorey's heights. The result indicated that the model of the Lorey's height from the smoothed CHM of all point cloud <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(R^{2}=0.950, R M S E=1.056 ~\mathrm{m}\right)$</tex> was better than that based on the NPC with overlapping point cloud (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{R}^{2}=0.937$</tex>, RMSE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=1.191 ~\mathrm{m}$</tex>). The models from the overlapping point cloud and the smoothed CHM were both better than that from the cut-overlapping point cloud and the unsmoothed CHM. The UAV LiDAR has widely potential application in forest resources survey and monitoring, forest fire risk assessment, and forest ecosystem modelling.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Starlink Broadband Signals for Ocean Remote Sensing Applications
authors: Rozaine Wijekularatne, James Garrison, Andrew Dempster
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The rise of Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite mega constellations, such as Starlink offers a unique opportunity for Signals of Opportunity (SoOp) reflectometry due to their wider coverage and near continuous signal availability. This paper presents details of an experiment carried out using a receiver setup with Low Noise Block Downconverters (LNBs) and a USRP N-310 device to capture direct Ku-band user downlink signals from overhead Starlink satellites in Sydney, Australia. Preliminary results demonstrate the ability to generate waveforms by cross correlating the direct signals with the Starlink Primary Synchronization Sequence (PSS) and Secondary Synchronization Sequence (SSS) code. These results validate the feasibility of leveraging Starlink broadband signals for SoOp reflectometry applications.

title: Model-Based Design of Anti-lock Braking System (ABS) Using SysML
authors: Chakradhar Reddy Goli, Shanmugha Sundaram G A
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: This paper presents a simplified and model-based design of an Anti-lock Braking System (ABS) using the Systems Modeling Language (SysML) in CATIA Magic Draw software. ABS is a vital vehicle safety system that prevents wheel lock during braking by helping maintain traction and avoid skidding. The control of ABS depends on nonlinear vehicle dynamics and the regulation of wheel slip ratio. Using the SysML language, we model both the structure and behavior of ABS with diagrams such as use case, activity, sequence, and state machine diagrams. This approach supports better system understanding, accurate documentation, and improved design updates. Inspired by methods used in aviation system modeling, this study shows how SysML and CATIA Magic Draw can be applied effectively in vehicle safety system development. The work also highlights the benefits of model-based systems engineering (MBSE) in creating reliable and traceable control system designs.

title: Rheology of Multicomponent Colloidal Dispersions: A Tracheobronchial Mucus Mimics Study
authors: Ciprian-Ștefan Mateescu, Doru-Daniel Cristea, Nicoleta-Octavia Tănase, Andreea Trifan, Mihai Dragomir, Eduard Liciu, Corneliu Bălan
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Mucus plays a key role in airway defense by modulating mucociliary clearance and enhancing cough efficiency. This study presents an oscillatory strain-sweep rheological test at an angular frequency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\omega=1 \text{rad} \cdot \mathrm{s}^{-1}$</tex>, conducted on two synthetic mucus samples obtained by dispersing Fresubin in water. One sample relates to healthy mucus (S1: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mathrm{g} / 50 \text{ml}$</tex>) and the other simulates obstructive diseases (S2: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5 \mathrm{g} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{5 0 m l}$</tex>). Storage modulus, loss modulus, linear viscoelastic region (LVR) limits, damping factors, crossover strains, and apparent yield stresses have been observed. This study aims to demonstrate the capability of mucus mimics to reproduce small-strain characteristics, such as those found in healthy mucus and pathological viscoelastic brittleness associated with obstructive diseases. This study also demonstrates the tunability of such dispersions, supporting their use in future experimental setups involving mechanical ventilation in respiratory disease models.

title: Lifetimes of Cable Insulations Subjected to Thermal and Radiation Stresses
authors: Cristina Stancu, Mădalina Maftei, Petru V. Notingher
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This paper presents a method for calculating the estimated, consumed, and remaining lifetimes of power cable insulation subjected to thermal and radiation stresses. New calculation relationships are proposed for lifetimes under both constant and time-varying stresses. The results show that consumed lifetime values increase, while estimated and remaining lifetimes decrease with increasing temperature and dose rate, and that these variations are more pronounced in the case of variable stresses exceeding the nominal operating limits of the insulation. Finally, it is shown that calculating the remaining lifetime values enables more effective monitoring and the implementation of a comprehensive maintenance program for power cables.

title: Sharing Transport Planning Information in Traffic Simulation Software
authors: Elena Chekina, Oleg Golovnin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The paper presents a method for jointly utilizing multi-structured and multimodal transport information within software for traffic simulation and prediction. The method entails executing a series of atomic steps toward robotic process automation. Robots imitate human tasks and interact with transport planning and simulation software through either a graphical user interface or an application programming interface. The method involves sharing information regarding road signs, traffic lights, road markings, and road barriers as part of a set of restrictions imposed on traffic flows in a transport model of traffic simulation software and vice versa. The method facilitates the automation of repetitive procedures involved in sharing information between software for developing transport planning designs and traffic simulation software. We implemented the proposed method in software and conducted experiments on segments of urban road networks in Samara, Russia, using both IndorTrafficPlan and SUMO tools. Our experiments indicate that adopting the method reduces labor costs associated with evaluating the efficacy of planned transport management interventions by approximately 85%.

title: Circuits for Secure Root-of-Trust: TRNG, PUF, Attack-Resistant Cryptographic Accelerators [Feature]
authors: Sanu K. Mathew, Raghavan Kumar, Vivek De
publish: IEEE Circuits and Systems Magazine
abstract: Silicon-embedded root-of-trust circuits such as True Random Number Generators (TRNG) and Physically Unclonable Functions (PUF) are foundational primitives that generate dynamic and static entropy essential for data security and privacy applications. At the same time, secure platforms are vulnerable to physical side-channel and fault-injection attacks that attempt to steal embedded secret keys/IDs. This article describes all-digital area-efficient implementations of TRNGs and PUFs that generate cryptographic quality random bitstreams with tolerance to process/voltage/temperature variations. These include: (a) Ring-oscillator-based TRNG implementations that employ multiple injected-edges and beat frequency detectors to harvest and convert thermal noise-induced jitter into random bitstreams with throughput and energy-efficiency of 23Mbps and 15Mbps/mW respectively; (b) SRAM PUF with data-remanence bit-masking technique to identify 100% stable bitcells; (c) Unified PUF-TRNG with a common-entropy source and self-calibrating Von Neumann extractor circuits generating PUF/TRNG random bit throughput of 0.56/1.48Gbps with 0.9996/0.99997 static/dynamic entropy respectively. A reconfigurable AES accelerator with minimum-traces-to-disclosure (MTD)<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$>1\text{B}$ </tex-math></inline-formula> traces in on-demand SCA-resistant mode, while also providing a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.2\times $ </tex-math></inline-formula> boost in encryption performance during a dual-core mode of operation is also described. Finally, a self-checking AES engine that uses arithmetic and parity checkers for real-time detection of laser and voltage-based attacks with up to 99.99% fault coverage is described.

title: Photovoltaic Solar Radiation Prediction Using Advanced Machine and Deep Learning Models
authors: Mohanad Abd Shehab
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: The increasing demand for energy has led to the worldwide adoption of solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. Accurate predictions of solar irradiance are necessary for the integration of PV systems into the electrical grid. Through utilizing of advanced machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) techniques, this study aims to improve solar irradiance prediction. XGBoost, Multilayer Perceptron (MLP), Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Regression (SVR), Gradient Boosting, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), LightGBM, CatBoost, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM) are among the state-of-the-art models whose performance is assessed by a thorough framework. The HI-SEAS weather station provides a strong dataset of 32,686 entries with 11 meteorological parameters, including temperature, pressure, humidity, wind direction, and wind speed, which is used to train and test these models. The dataset is preprocessed to ensure highquality input for the models, and feature engineering techniques are applied to enhance predictive accuracy. Standard metrics, such as Mean Squared Error (MSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and statistical <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex>, are used to thoroughly assess each model's performance. Our results show that Gradient Boosting and LightGBM are two of the ML models that perform well, demonstrating their capacity to process high-dimensional data and produce precise predictions. LSTM, and BiLSTM models perform better than conventional ML techniques when it comes to identifying the intricate, non-linear correlations present in solar irradiance data. By identifying the most effective models, this research advances reliable solar forecasting tools for enabling continuous grid integration and supporting the global transition to sustainable energy.

title: IoT labels’ impact on security and privacy concerns
authors: Yi-Shyuan Chiang, Pardis Emami-Naeini, Camille Cobb
publish: 2025 European Symposium on Usable Security (EuroUSEC)
abstract: Countries are launching Internet of Things (IoT) cybersecurity label programs to help consumers make more informed purchasing decisions and motivate manufacturers to create more secure IoT products. In such programs, products that meet program requirements can be sold with a special label to signal cybersecurity compliance. Currently, there is no evidence-based guidance or standardized implementation of labels or label-awarding program policies. We conducted an online survey to understand the impact of IoT labels and choices such as validation requirements (i.e., whether manufacturers need to self attest or seek third-party audits to validate their products’ compliance) regarding participants’ security and privacy concerns. Our research provides empirical evidence to guide policy choices by effective label-awarding programs. We find that the presence of IoT labels alleviated both security and privacy concerns; however, we did not find differences between other program implementation choices. We provide recommendations for IoT cybersecurity label programs and discuss the potential societal impacts of label programs.

title: Development of an LED Lighting Load Model for Assessing Current Harmonic Emission Levels in Power Networks
authors: Pavel Bordadyn, Tatyana Krivorotko, Maksim Silaev, Vladimir Tulsky, Konstantin Shish, Vladimir Korolev
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper presents the development of an LED lighting load model to assess the level of current harmonic emission in the electrical grid. The current waveforms of single LED lamps and their combinations were measured and processed over an active power range of 13 W to 143 W. The dependencies of the individual harmonic distortion coefficients up to the 40th order and the initial phases of current harmonics on the active power consumed by the LED lamps were obtained. Based on the results, an averaged model was developed that predicts the current waveform of the LED lighting load for a given active power. This model can be used for accurate modeling of distorting loads to assess the level of voltage non-sinusoidality at network nodes.

title: Dual-Port Wideband MIMO Antenna with Pattern Diversity and High Isolation for mm-Wave 5G
authors: K. Vijayakumar, Brijesh Mishra
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and analysis of a dualport wideband multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) antenna featuring pattern diversity and high isolation for millimeter-wave (mm-wave) 5G applications. The single antenna element of the proposed MIMO antenna module consists of a T-shape feed printed on one side of the RT duroid low-loss substrate and two rectangular slots loaded ground plane on the other side. The MIMO antenna designs have been realized using the anti-parallel arrangement of two antenna units relative to one another. The proposed MIMO has a small design of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12.5 \times 6.25 \times 0.8 \text{mm}^{3}$</tex>. The antiparallel arrangement is generating pattern diversity. The achieved impedance bandwidth ranges from 25.8 GHz to 32.8 GHz, including a total span of 7 GHz, which includes the critical band N257 (26.5-29.5 GHz) for 5G millimeter-wave communications. Wideband impedance matching is achieved by optimized feed geometry, guaranteeing steady performance over the designated mm-wave frequency range. High port isolation is achieved without intricate decoupling mechanisms, hence minimizing design complexity and preserving a small footprint. The simulation was conducted using the Ansys HFSS electromagnetic solver. The suggested MIMO antenna demonstrates a minimal envelope correlation coefficient (ECC) and substantial diversity gain (DG), and consistent gain patterns, making it an appropriate choice for next-generation high-speed wireless communication systems.

title: Optimizing Marketing Strategies Through Data-Driven Segment Analysis: A Data Science Approach
authors: Vahini Siruvoru, Kona Veda Varshini, S K Grishika, Guttala Mohan Chandra, Jadavath Kowshik
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This paper presents a data-driven approach to optimize marketing strategies using advanced data science techniques. By employing clustering algorithms, regression models, and machine learning, this study effectively segments customers, predicts customer revenue, and assesses the likelihood of customer churn. The findings offer actionable insights for businesses to create personalized marketing campaigns, improve customer engagement, and maximize their return on investment (ROI)..

title: Distinguishability of EC Point Doublings and Additions in Binary kP Implementations using Chevallier-Mames Atomic Blocks
authors: Gerrit Schrock, Gerald Isheanesu Matungamire, Alkistis Aikaterini Sigourou, Zoya Dyka, Peter Langendoerfer, Ievgen Kabin
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: Scalar multiplication kP is the most frequently attacked operation in Elliptic Curve Cryptosystems (ECC). The atomicity principle and different atomic block patterns have been proposed in the past as effective means to counter simple SideChannel Analysis (SCA) attacks. In this work, using our software and hardware implementations as an example, we show that the binary left-to-right kP algorithm with Chevallier-Mames atomic block patterns for point doubling and point addition is vulnerable to simple data-bit SCA attacks. Atomic blocks involving multiplications with special values like 1 are visibly distinguishable. For the right-to-left kP algorithm, this distinguishability is observable only in atomic patterns executed immediately after initialisation. We also show that the well-known randomisation of EC point coordinates, originally designed as a countermeasure against vertical attacks, is also effective against such horizontal data-bit SCA attacks.

title: ICE Penetrating Radar and Thermal Profiler: Campaign Results and Initial Analysis
authors: Dongjin Bai, Xiaolong Dong, Saibun Tjuatja, Di Zhu, Zijin Zhang, Jianying Ma
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: ICE Penetrating Radar and Thermal Profiler (ICEPATH) is an active and passive microwave suite including ice penetrating radar and ultrawideband radiometer system developed to detect the internal structure and physical properties of ice sheets and glaciers. The active instrument is an ice penetrating radar that can operated on P-band over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{4 0 0 - 7 0 0 ~ M H z}$</tex> and on L-band over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 7 0 0 - 2 0 0 0} \text{~ M H z}$</tex>, whereas the passive instrument is a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{P}$</tex>-to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{L}$</tex>-band ultrawideband microwave radiometer covering <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$300-2000 \text{MHz}$</tex>. This active and passive microwave suite is mounted on helicopter and accomplishes its first flight experiment to make combined active and passive microwave detection of Laohugou No. 12 glacier in Qilian Mountain, Gansu, China in October 2024. This paper makes initial analysis of the radar and radiometer results obtained during the campaign, try to give some explanation of the data features, providing the basis for future analysis of the glacier properties.

title: Testability-based Hardware Trojan Design
authors: Shreoshi Chattopadhyay, Smruthi Sajan Varier, M Nirmala Devi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Hardware Trojans (HTs) are modifications of an original circuit during design and manufacturing of integrated circuits (ICs). These modifications have various effects on the circuit, such as leakage of information, reduced reliability etc. which are malicious in nature. The stealthiness of an HT can be determined by its ability to be not detected during testing. Design and insertion of Hardware Trojans provides insight into an attackers’ perspective, enabling us to identify nodes vulnerable to HT insertion in various circuits, and selection of logic elements for designing HTs. This approach can help us in designing robust circuits that are resilient to Hardware Trojans.

title: IoT for Monitoring Ground Movement Integrated with Data Logger
authors: Intan Komalasari, Ivany Sarief
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Geothermal fields in Indonesia are generally located in areas of volcanic deposits characterized by mountainous to hilly areas dominated by steep slopes, which can trigger natural ground movements or landslides. Therefore, landslides are one of the geological hazards (Geohazard) in geothermal areas that can impact facilities and local communities. When ground cracks begin to appear, monitoring of ground movement must be carried out immediately to determine the next hazard mitigation steps that need to be taken. Manual measurements carried out directly will pose a danger to workers. With Internet of Things technology, measurements can be done online without the need to come directly to the location where the ground crack occurred. The method and implementation involve using a distance sensor connected to a controller. Data is transmitted via a long-range Wi-Fi network. The received data is integrated with a data logger in real time. In addition to ground movement data, rainfall is also measured as supporting data that may influence ground conditions. Online monitoring is expected to provide real-time data for further analysis and to serve as an early warning system in the event of significant ground movement. Another key objective is to reduce the risk to workers due to the potential danger of landslides when conducting manual measurements.

title: Real-time Gaze Estimation via Face Mesh and Machine Learning: A Case Study
authors: Erick Noboa, György Eigner, Vivien Roxána Patakvölgyi, Lourdes Ruiz
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: The quest for more intuitive human-computer interaction continuously seeks pathways to bridge the cognitive gap between human intentions and digital execution. Among these, gaze tracking stands as a beacon, promising to unlock hands-free control and enhanced user experiences. However, hardware-based eye trackers often compete with the inflated cost and impractical setups of standard hardware-based eye trackers. The present work focuses on the development of an open source gaze estimation system, creating a user-calibrated, real-time focus prediction system based on a commonly available web camera and the robust technology of Google’s MediaPipe Face Mesh pipeline. The proposed solution is based on Support Vector Regression (SVR) models with custom feature engineering that incorporates both facial landmarks and head pose dynamics. The paper details a calibration methodology designed to forge a bespoke mapping for each user, adapting to individual biometric and environmental variations. Furthermore, this work addresses practical implementation considerations, including the crucial step of feature scaling and the process of hyperparameter optimization via exhaustive grid search. The presented results, as illustrated in the accompanying scatter plots, demonstrate the SVR models’ ability to capture complex nonlinear relationships, marking a promising step towards robust and accessible gaze tracking in diverse interactive paradigms.

title: Case Study on Power Quality Improvement in Industrial Networks Using Capacitor Banks
authors: Galati Romania Marin, Marian Gaiceanu, Silviu Epure, George Petrea, Adriana Burlibasa
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: This paper presents a detailed case study on the improvement of power quality in a 6 kV industrial electrical network through the application of capacitor banks. Industrial facilities operating at medium voltage are often affected by power quality issues such as low power factor, excessive reactive power demand, voltage drops, and high distribution losses. These factors not only reduce the operational efficiency of the electrical network but also increase energy costs and the risk of equipment malfunction. Capacitor banks represent a well-established and cost-effective solution to address such problems by compensating reactive power, stabilizing voltage profiles, and improving the overall energy efficiency of the system.In this study, a 6 kV distribution network supplying an industrial process was analyzed under two conditions: before and after the implementation of capacitor banks. Key performance indicators such as active and reactive power flow, power factor, system losses, and voltage stability were carefully monitored. The analysis revealed that the integration of properly sized capacitor banks significantly improved the power factor, reduced energy losses, and maintained voltage within the recommended limits. These improvements not only enhance the reliability and efficiency of the industrial process but also contribute to lowering operational costs and ensuring compliance with power quality standards. The findings confirm that capacitor banks are an effective and sustainable approach for improving power quality in medium-voltage industrial networks.

title: Modeling the Interplay of Ghrelin, Leptin, and Exercise on Energy Balance: A Systems Dynamics Approach
authors: Mantana Chudtong, Ilona Nagy, Andrea De Gaetano
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: We detail a possible mathematical model describing the dynamics of key energy substrates, regulatory hormones, appetite, and fat mass incorporating the effect of exercise. The model describes physiological responses to three mixed meals (breakfast, lunch, dinner), represented by difference-ofexponential influx functions. The size of these meal pulses is modulated by appetite, which is dynamically regulated by ghrelin and leptin concentrations. The system is formulated as set of coupled nonlinear algebraic and ordinary differential equations (ODEs), including state variables for appetite, gut glucose and lipid contents, glycemia, lipidemia, insulinemia, plasma ghrelin and leptin concentrations, weight and fat mass, as well as the effect of exercise.

title: Research Hotspots in Educational Data Mining Studies: Knowledge Graph Analysis Based on CiteSpace
authors: Fahua Zeng, Xinrui Dai
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: The rapid growth of educational data, its increasing diversity, enhanced accessibility, and the rise of educational computing have collectively propelled the swift advancement of educational data mining research, attracting widespread scholarly attention and in-depth exploration. This paper employs visual analysis of international educational data mining literature from 2020 to 2025 to identify key research hotspots over the past five years, thereby furthering the development of educational data mining. This study utilised core journals indexed in the Web of Science database, employing the search term “Educational data mining”. Leveraging the CiteSpace literature visualisation tool, a knowledge graph analysis was conducted on research hotspots within educational data mining. Findings indicate that key research areas include: precise prediction and intervention of student academic performance; intelligent support systems for higher education; optimisation of educational data mining methodologies; and the exploration of learning behaviour patterns within online educational environments.

title: Modeling of Intra-Company Planning Based on the Environment
authors: Oleg I. Dranko, Evgeny Stepanov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: We examine a mechanism for internal corporate planning that accounts for changes in the external environment. Factors influencing the external environment are described in terms of capital, labor, and materials. The relationship between external factors and indicators and their impact on the company's internal environment is examined. Based on these relationships, an optimal operating strategy is developed. The model is illustrated using the example of a manufacturing company. To obtain initial industry data, financial statements from approximately 2 million Russian organizations were processed. From this dataset, information on industry development was extracted using big data processing.

title: Diffusion-Based Synthetic Brightfield Microscopy Images for Enhanced Single Cell Detection
authors: Mario de Jesus da Graca, Jörg Dahlkemper, Peer Stelldinger
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Accurate single cell detection in brightfield microscopy is crucial for biological research, yet data scarcity and annotation bottlenecks limit the progress of deep learning methods. We investigate the use of unconditional models to generate synthetic brightfield microscopy images and evaluate their impact on object detection performance. A U-Net based diffusion model was trained and used to create datasets with varying ratios of synthetic and real images. Experiments with YOLOv8, YOLOv9 and RT-DETR reveal that training with synthetic data can achieve improved detection accuracies (at minimal costs). A human expert survey demonstrates the high realism of generated images, with experts not capable to distinguish them from real microscopy images (accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 {\%}$</tex>). Our findings suggest that diffusion-based synthetic data generation is a promising avenue for augmenting real datasets in microscopy image analysis, reducing the reliance on extensive manual annotation and potentially improving the robustness of cell detection models.

title: Real-Time Vehicle Detection Using Deep Learning for High-Speed Traffic Surveillance
authors: Ramakalyani Karnati, Umamaheswaran S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: The ability to detect vehicles accurately and swiftly is fundamental to the success of modern intelligent traffic systems, impacting areas such as traffic regulation, public safety, and autonomous transport. Traditional object detection approaches, especially those based on conventional convolutional neural networks (CNNs), often encounter challenges in processing real-time video streams under varying environmental conditions. This research presents an enhanced multi-class vehicle detection framework utilizing Swin Transformers, known for their hierarchical attention mechanisms and robust feature extraction. The proposed system achieves low-latency processing comparable to established models such as YOLOv3, YOLOv4, and Faster R-CNN. Specifically, YOLOv3 and YOLOv4 typically yield 55–60% mean average precision (mAP) on custom datasets, while Faster R-CNN achieves 60–65% mAP. The integration of Swin Transformer with YOLOv5 (custom head) attains 75% mAP, and Swin Transformer combined with Mask R-CNN achieves 70–80% mAP. The standalone Swin Transformer also maintains high detection accuracy. These results indicate the system’s suitability for deployment in smart city infrastructures.

title: Blockchain Integration for Decentralized and Secure Policy Management in Software-Defined Networking Architectures
authors: Freddy Oscar Songo-Kette Mogambo, Serge Etiennovitch Boda, Edgard Ndassimba, Samuel Ouya
publish: 2025 8th World Symposium on Communication Engineering (WSCE)
abstract: Software-Defined Networking (SDN) relies on a logically centralized control plane that simplifies automation but also introduces vulnerabilities such as single points of failure and exposure to malicious modifications. To overcome these limitations, this work proposes the integration of blockchain technology for decentralized and tamper-resistant policy management. A functional prototype combining OpenDaylight, Ethereum smart contracts, and a Node.js middleware was implemented and tested in a Mininet environment. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that, compared with a traditional centralized SDN controller, the proposed system increases policy registration latency from 45 ms to 210 ms on average and CPU load from 18% to 27%. However, it ensures full traceability, immutability, and resilience of network policies. Moreover, in failure scenarios, policies remain verifiable and enforceable, whereas centralized solutions lose control. These findings confirm that the blockchain-based approach provides improved security and governance at the cost of moderate overhead, making it suitable for critical infrastructures such as 5G and multi-domain networks.

title: Gumbel-Based Active Sparse Mobile Crowd Sensing with Time Series Transformer
authors: Victor Li, Carson Lam, Ting Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Mobile Crowd Sensing (MCS) has revolutionized the way we collect environmental and urban data by leveraging a tremendous number of distributed sensors equipped on wearable devices like smartphones, smart watches, and so on. Gathering continuous data from these sensors allows us to generate a complete spatiotemporal field for the desired measurements. However, obtaining continuous sensing data at all locations and times is often infeasible due to resource limits, cost constraints, and practicality. To address this problem, we proposed a Learned Gumbel-Based Active Sparse MCS framework utilizing an Encoder-Decoder Time Series Transformer that reconstructs the full spatiotemporal field for a given time cycle and a small subset of available sensors. Notably, an active sensor selection layer is included, which leverages the Gumbel distribution to create noise from learned weights, helping to dynamically select the most effective sensors for the next sensing cycle. We verified the effectiveness of our proposed model by comparing it to random selection, attention-scoring, and statistical methods. Our Gumbel-Based selector achieves higher performance in both firstand second-order norm metrics.

title: Automated Control of the Electrical Ventilation System of the Pool
authors: Grigory Semin, Valeria Semina, Stanimir Valtchev, Victor Meshcheryakov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The article presents the application of the neighborhood modeling method to optimize the energy consumption of a swimming pool ventilation system. A neighborhood structure consisting of two weakly connected subsystems has been developed, and a decomposition algorithm has been proposed to reduce the number of identifiable model parameters. Using the example of a real ventilation system in a university sports complex, it has been demonstrated that modernization with the installation of frequency converters and automation systems ensures energy savings.

title: A Machine Learning Method to Determine the Optimal Number of Stages for a Ring Oscillator
authors: Vazgen Melikyan, Tatevik Chilingaryan, Gevorg Harutyunyan, Davit Marukhyan, Arthur Sahakyan, Manvel Grigoryan
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: An effective method of automated selection of the number of stages of one of the most important and widespread blocks used in digital integrated circuits, the ring oscillator, based on machine learning (ML), is presented. In addition to the ability to automatically determine the number of stages, it also provides the best tradeoff between the main parameters: power, area and performance due to the ability to take the peculiarities caused by the technological process into account. The use of the ML method made it possible to reduce the duration of the RO stage calculation by approximately 4-5 times, at the expense of a 3,57% loss of accuracy.

title: Improving the Range and Quality of Underwater Voice Communications Using the Modified Khurgin-Yakovlev Algorithm
authors: Vladimir Timurovich Dmitriev, Leonid Vyacheslavovich Aronov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The parameters of the hydroacoustic data transmission channel were calculated by mathematical model, and the dependencies of the maximum length of the route on the data transmission rate were obtained. The paper shows that the application of a modification of the Khurgin-Yakovlev algorithm in adaptive noise-resistant underwater communication systems makes it possible to improve the quality of reconstructed speech at the output of the transmission system under the influence of interference in the communication channel. The use of systems based on the modification of the Khurgin-Yakovlev algorithm makes it possible to increase the transmission range of information under the influence of interference in the underwater communication channel. Computer modeling has shown that the distance gain when using a modification of this algorithm is from 75 km, with a frequency band from 1 to 6.3 kHz and an acoustic carrier from 3.3 to 21 kHz with the given initial data.

title: Mitigating Syntax and Logic Errors in LLM Based Code Generation via XML-Structured Prompts
authors: Saket Sambaraju, Jeffrey Boman, Howell Wu, Ziliang Zong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have become powerful tools for automated code generation. Yet, they remain prone to both syntax and logic errors that limit their effectiveness in real-world software development. This paper comprehensively evaluates LLM-generated code utilizing the Codeforces Benchmark, and proposes XML-Structured Prompts (XSP) to improve code quality. Specifically, we present three creative strategies: XSP for improving problem comprehension, Syntax-Aware XSP (SA-XSP) for mitigating syntax errors, and Testcase-Driven Logic Error Debugging (TDLED) for resolving logic errors through test case feedback. Our experiments on 30 LLMs, ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.5 ~\mathrm{B}, 70 ~\mathrm{B}$</tex>, to 671 B parameters and including 5 reasoning models, demonstrate that the proposed methods improve accuracy by up to 27.5 %, especially in smaller models, with syntax error reductions of up to 60 % and logic error corrections by up to 30%.

title: Exploration of Machine Learning Prediction Models for VM Performance Monitoring in Cloud Infrastructure
authors: Rahadian Adiguna Wicaksono, Aditya Arya Putranda, Hamonangan Situmorang, Galih Nugraha Nurkahfi
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: The increasing complexity of cloud services highlights the need for intelligent and adaptive systems to monitor virtual machine (VM) performance. While most studies focus on public cloud deployments, this work investigates machine learningbased performance prediction in resource-constrained cloud environments. A three-layer monitoring pipeline is proposed: (1) time-series prediction using GRU, TCN, and XGBoost models; (2) anomaly detection through residuals, z-scores, and health scores; and (3) performance classification using Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM). Preprocessing includes RAM-to-percentage conversion, MinMaxScaler normalization for CPU, sliding window creation, and data partitioning. Model performance is evaluated using Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and residual analysis. A confidence index is introduced to combine prediction accuracy and decision stability over time. Experimental results show that the TCN model achieves the highest confidence index, indicating a strong balance between sensitivity and consistency. GRU and XGBoost are more stable but slower in reacting to anomalies, while the LSTM baseline tends to classify many conditions as uncertain. The entire pipeline is deployed through a Streamlit-based dashboard that visualizes inference results and VM classifications in real time. System usability is tested using the System Usability Scale (SUS) and yields a score of 85, placing the system in the “Excellent” category and indicating high user satisfaction. This study presents a modular and lightweight monitoring framework suitable for adaptive performance management in clouds.

title: Digital Business Value in Disaster Resilience: Case Study of ASEAN's Integrated Early Warning System for Earthquake-Prone Regions
authors: Yudi Limbar Yasik, Jack Febrian Rusdi, Marsudi Wahyu Kisworo, Teguh Aprianto, Iwan Abadi, Renny Sunarny
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Southeast Asia, situated in the seismically active Pacific Ring of Fire, suffers substantial socio-economic and humanitarian losses due to frequent earthquakes. Existing disaster management strategies often lack regional interoperability, standardized data protocols, and sustainable financial models for advanced Early Warning Systems (EWS). This paper proposes the ASEAN Integrated Network for Early Warning and Tracking (AINET)—an innovative framework combining Internet of Things (IoT) for real-time seismic data collection, Artificial Intelligence (AI) for rapid event analysis, and Geographic Information Systems (GIS) for dynamic impact visualization and information dissemination. The system is designed with aggressive performance targets, specifically aiming for sub-second data acquisition and processing, enabling multi-second alert delivery to minimize the critical time gap before destructive S-waves arrive. Critically, the study introduces a Digital Business Value Framework that outlines how the technical design generates measurable socio-economic value and financial sustainability, distinguishing it from conventional, purely government-funded EEWS models. This framework leverages principles of Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA) and Return on Investment (ROI) by quantifying the value generated from averted losses in infrastructure and human capital across the disaster management cycle. AINET presents a crucial strategic roadmap toward a more resilient, technologically advanced, and economically self-sustaining disaster management ecosystem for the ASEAN region.

title: Data Driven Crop Yield Forecasting
authors: Sumangala N, K J Dhrithi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Accurate prediction of crop yield plays an important role in agricultural sustainability by enabling efficient resource use and thereby improving productivity. In this paper, a machine learning-based model for Maize yield prediction based on past and present climate data is proposed. In contrast to recent work on hybrid models with low interpretability and high mean absolute error, our model employs interpretable models—Random Forest(RF) and XGBoost that yield much improved performance. Past climate data from Kaggle were preprocessed, normalized, and outlier values were removed. A location-aware API-based Flask web application employs present climate data. RF provided the best performance among all the models tried with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.9322. These results prove that application of interpretable models with real-time data is highly effective for smart agriculture purposes.

title: Typology of Educational Pathways in AI by Disciplinary Profiles of Russian Universities
authors: Ekaterina Kasatkina, Daiana Vavilova, Rinat Faizullin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The study presents a comprehensive analysis of educational programs of Russian universities in the field of artificial intelligence (AI). Based on the study of 100 undergraduate curricula from 38 universities selected taking into account the rating of the association "Alliance in the Field of Artificial Intelligence" for 2025 and the geographical representation of the Russian Federation’s regions, the authors developed an original methodology for the typology of educational trajectories using cluster analysis of the structure of curricula. The sample of universities that implement training in the field of AI covers all federal districts of the Russian Federation, demonstrating a balanced representation - from the Central (11 universities) to the Far Eastern (4 universities) districts, which ensures the representativeness of the results for the entire system of Russian higher education. The methodology includes systematization and classification of more than 3 thousand disciplines in five key modules: "Computer Science", "Mathematics", "Software Engineering", "Practices and Certification" and "Other Disciplines". To identify structural patterns, the hierarchical clustering method (Ward’s method) is used, where the input data is the percentage distribution of the academic load between the selected modules. Tile maps, dendrograms and radar diagrams are used to visualize the results of the analysis. Cluster analysis made it possible to identify four stable types of educational programs. The first cluster – theoretical and mathematical – is characterized by a high share of mathematical disciplines (47.6%) and is presented in classical universities. The second cluster – engineering and analytical – demonstrates a balanced combination of mathematics (26.6%) and applied aspects of data analysis (20.9% "Software Engineering"). The programs of the third cluster – applied development – are focused on practical skills (36.2% "Software Engineering"). The fourth cluster – innovative and technological – integrates advanced AI technologies (25.2% "Computer Science") with an interdisciplinary approach. The obtained results are of great practical importance for various stakeholders (applicants, higher education institutions, education regulators and business).

title: Development of a System for Measuring the Dielectric Permeability of the Air Environment to Improve the Storage of Poume Fruits
authors: Mykola Kundenko, Antonina Rybalka, Ivaylo Blagov, Larisa Vakhonina, Vitalii Mardziavko, Andrii Rudenko
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: The article considers the problem of controlling the concentration of ethylene during fruit storage, which critically affects their ripening and quality preservation. The authors propose a new high-precision system for indirect determination of ethylene content based on changes in the dielectric permittivity of the air medium. The methodology is based on a resonant method with a frequency discriminator operating on an open resonator with a frequency autotuning system. Transient processes are simulated and system parameters are optimized. The results demonstrate extremely high accuracy (up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10^{-3} \%$</tex>), sensitivity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(10^{-5}\right)$</tex> and stability of operation (up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1\times10^{-7}$</tex>), which allows for effective detection of even low concentrations of ethylene. The originality of the development lies in the integration of modern technologies of high-frequency electronics, metrology and automatic control for agricultural applications. The system has significant practical value, in particular for automated monitoring of fruit storage conditions and can be adapted to other areas of gas analysis.

title: Proposed ICT-Enabled Multidimensional Framework for Floating Solar PV: A Case Study in Cirata, Indonesia
authors: Jack Febrian Rusdi, Marsudi Wahyu Kisworo, Sazilah Salam, Suharjanta Wisnu Pitara, Dea Yunita Sari, Jejen Jaelani Frihatna
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: The development of a floating Solar Power Plant (PLTS) system in the Cirata Reservoir demands a holistic approach that combines technical, environmental, institutional, and socio-economic aspects. This article presents a multidimensional framework based on five key pillars—Design & Mooring, Environment, Energy Production, Regulation & Governance, and Replication & Scalability—designed to support informed decision-making, data validation, and national expansion strategies. The framework is conceptual, informed by literature studies, general data on existing Cirata solar power plants, and preliminary data from field surveys. This study's primary novelty lies in its holistic integration of five distinct pillars—from technical design to regulatory governance and national scalability—into a single, interoperable ICT architecture, a comprehensive approach not yet present in existing models. Modular system visualization and conceptual analysis are used to facilitates cross-disciplinary understanding and evidence-based policy advocacy. The research methodology includes conceptual integration of GIS and sensor data, ecological impact analysis, energy optimization models, and institutional and socio-economic mapping. The framework offers a strategic replication model for the development of floating solar power plants in Indonesia and other tropical countries, with potential adoption as a reference for data-driven energy design, regulation, and planning.

title: Secure and Efficient Vehicle-to-Vehicle Task Offloading via Trust-Aware Collaboration
authors: Xiaomei Zhang, Flowrence Dirisipamu, Khushi Jadhav
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: The proliferation of smart vehicles equipped with advanced computing capabilities has enabled collaborative computing among vehicles, particularly through vehicle-to-vehicle task offloading, also known as peercloud-vehicle. However, the dynamic and heterogeneous nature of vehicular environments presents significant security challenges, especially in trust management. Untrustworthy vehicles can cause unreliable task execution and introduce security vulnerabilities, ultimately compromising the efficiency and security of vehicle-to-vehicle offloading. To address these issues, this paper proposes a comprehensive trust management framework for vehicle-to-vehicle task offloading scenarios. The framework is designed to assess the trustworthiness of vehicles in order to enhance task offloading success rates by avoiding interactions with low-trust vehicles. Specifically, the framework includes two key components. First, we propose a decentralized trust propagation and aggregation mechanism that can adapt to the dynamic nature of vehicular environments. Second, we propose a trust-aware task allocation approach that integrates trust estimation with resource management to optimize task execution. Experimental results on both realworld and synthetic vehicular network datasets demonstrate that the proposed framework enables secure and efficient vehicle-to-vehicle task offloading by accurately estimating trust and significantly improving workload completion performance.

title: Determination of Vertical Gradient of Carbon Dioxide in Near Surface Air with A Sensor Flying on A Drone
authors: Jinchun Yuan
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Although it is very important for estimating air-sea and air-land carbon fluxes, vertical gradient of carbon dioxide in the near surface air were very hard to determine due to logistical difficulties. A few studies of the vertical gradient of cardon dioxide were conducted from airplane that offer poor vertical resolution and from towers that are available at limited locations. Recent developments in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV, i.e. drone) made it possible to carry physical and chemical sensors on a UAV to different altitudes for determining gradient of physical and chemical parameters. Here, we present some vertical profiles of carbon dioxide, water vapor, temperature, and relative humidity determined at: the Moana Loa Observatory, Hawaii; aboard R/V Kilo Moana at ALOHA Station in the North Pacific Ocean; Cape Hatteras, North Carolina; and Spruill Farm Conservation Project, North Carolina. Vertical profiles were observed at each site, and these vertical profiles of carbon dioxide were used to estimate near surface gradients of carbon dioxide. The gradient measured indicates that Mauna Loa is a source of carbon, the Spruill Farm and ALOHA Station is a sink of carbon, while Cape Hatteras is a source of carbon a few observation days and a sink of carbon most the other days during the study period.

title: A Fully Convolutional Network based DoA Estimator with Low RMSE at Low SNRs and Wide Range of Angles of Separation
authors: Jishnu Mohan, T. S. Bindiya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This work proposes a high-performance multisource direction of arrival (DoA) estimator based on fully convolutional network. The proposed network comprises of a feature extractor, parallel classifiers, and an angle estimator. The covariance matrix obtained by preprocessing the received signals serves as the input to the network. A detailed simulation study is performed to asses the DoA estimation accuracy of the proposed network under different conditions, such as wide range of angles of separation and varying signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for single source as well as multi-source scenarios. The results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms the existing deep learning based DoA estimation techniques with lesser number of network parameters and floating point operations.

title: IntentFuse: Language-Guided 3D Scene Understanding via Prompt Filtering and Fusion
authors: Ahalya Ravendran, Madhawa Perera, Feng Xu, Lars Petersson, Dadong Wang, Xun Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Affordances-the actions enabled by objects-are fundamental for meaningful interaction in 3D environments. While language models can infer affordances from abstract prompts, grounding them in visual scenes typically requires extensive supervision. We propose IntentFuse, a lightweight middleware that integrates a compact language model with a pretrained Language Embedded Radiance Field (LERF) to ground affordance reasoning directly in 3D scenes. Our method reformulates free-form queries into structured CLIP-aligned prompts, extracting key roles and filtering negations before injecting them into LERF. Experiments on descriptive, affordance, and negation benchmarks show clear improvements, achieving 95% accuracy on affordance queries and 88 % on negation handling over baseline LERF. IntentFuse enables intuitive, training-free, plug-andplay affordance grounding with applications in real-time robotic instruction following and AR/VR scene exploration, paving the way for more natural and interpretable human-environment interaction.

title: Bifurcation Analysis of an Improved Discrete-Time Tabu Learning Neuron Model
authors: Ting Zhang, Fang Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: To gain a deeper understanding of the discrete tabu learning neuron model’s dynamical behaviors, we analyze its improved version, denoted as the IDTLN model. For its activation function, this model uses a sinusoidal nonlinearity. To demonstrate that the proposed model exhibits Neimark-Sacker bifurcation at its fixed point, we employ the normal form method for discrete-time models along with bifurcation theory. We also derive a formula to determine both the direction and stability of this bifurcation. In addition, we plot the bifurcation curves based on the original parameter settings of the IDTLN model, and these curves are visually presented in the corresponding bifurcation diagrams. Using numerical simulation examples, we not only verify our theoretical findings but also show the IDTLN model’s abundant, complex dynamical behaviors.

title:
M
                    <sup>3</sup>
                    X-AAL: A Multi-Modal, Multi-Tier, MetaExplainability Framework for Trustworthy AI in Ambient Assisted Living Systems
authors: Merlin Kasirajan, M A Hannan Bin Azhar, Scott Turner
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming Ambient Assisted Living (AAL) by enabling real-time monitoring, predictive health assessment, and personalised support. However, the adoption of AI in AAL is hindered by lack of transparency, potential biases, and limited interpretability. This paper introduces $\mathbf{M}^{\mathbf{3}} \mathbf{X}$-AAL-a Multimodal, Multi-tier, Meta-explainability framework designed to enhance trust and understanding in AI-powered AAL systems. The framework integrates diverse data modalities (numerical, textual, and visual) and provides explanations at three hierarchical levels: Tier 1 delivers local and global insights specific to each modality; Tier 2 contextualises these explanations with metadata to identify biases and subgroupspecific patterns; and Tier 3 monitors temporal evolution to detect concept drift and maintain fairness over time. By combining SHAP, word cloud analysis, and Grad-CAM visualisations, $\mathrm{M}^{3} \mathrm{X}$-AAL offers comprehensive interpretability for technical experts, domain specialists, and end-users alike. Experimental results demonstrate the framework’s ability to improve transparency, fairness, and trustworthiness in safety-critical AAL environments.

title: Rateless Transmission Based on Short Polar Codes for Free Space Optical Links
authors: Yuyun Siti Rohmah, Iskandar, Khoirul Anwar, Mohammad Sigit Arifianto
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: This paper studies short polar codes as elements to design rateless polar codes based on extended parity (EP). We propose a new rateless polar codes structure, termed as Ladder model with a short block-length N = 4. We perform a series of computer simulations to evaluate bit-error-rate (BER) performance for several coding rates R over additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN), Rayleigh fading, and free space optical (FSO) channels. The simulation results are then analyzed using the extrinsic information transfer (EXIT) chart over an equivalent binary erasure channel (BEC). The results are expected to stimulate further study on the design of rateless capabilities in polar coding schemes.

title: AKG-Gen: Generating Knowledge Graphs from Air Accident Reports with LLM-Powered Prompting
authors: Jiaqi Li, Jian Zhang, Xin Yao, Danhuai Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Air accident investigation reports are critical resources for aviation safety, as they contain detailed information on accident causes, flight phases, system failures, weather conditions, and pilot operations. However, their unstructured narratives hinder systematic analysis and reuse. To address this challenge, we introduce AKG-Gen, a framework for generating knowledge graphs from air accident reports with LLM-powered prompting. AKG-Gen adopts a hierarchical extraction strategy that leverages large language models to construct an extended quintuple representation incorporating both event and time. It further applies sectionlevel and integration-level prompts for layered knowledge extraction and employs a fusion mechanism to mitigate entity fragmentation and relation redundancy. Experiments on realworld reports demonstrate that AKG-Gen achieves substantial improvements in efficiency, fusion quality, and knowledge coverage compared with manual extraction, thereby enabling systematic accident cause analysis and supporting datadriven decision-making in aviation safety.

title: A comparative study of trigate FinFET 14 nm with different Fin materials for CMOS circuits
authors: Lazzaz Abdelaziz, Bousbahi Khaled, Beladam Fatiha
publish: 2025 33rd National Conference with International Participation (TELECOM)
abstract: This paper studies the impact of fin material Silicon and GaN on the performance of tri-gate (TG) FinFET transistors with 14 nm channel length. A comparative study of the electrical characteristics of silicon and gallium nitride (GaN) FinFETs are investigated using Bohm quantum potential (BQP) approach. TCAD ATLAS tools are used in this simulation to plot the electrical characteristics and the structure of the transistor. The novelty of this paper is to adjust the fitting parameter presented in the BQP formula to have a better performance ratio. The results demonstrate that the proposed device with gallium nitride (GaN) fin material is better because it has a better performance ratio.

title: Enhancing data association in Multi-Object Tracking via learning-based Human Trajectory Prediction
authors: Alfredo Carreras, Josué Manuel Rivera Velázquez, Jean-Bernard Hayet
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: This paper explores how modern, machine learning-driven Human Trajectory Prediction models can be effectively leveraged in the old computer vision problem of multi-object tracking, by substituting the predictors such as Kalman filters in the trajectory prediction stage. Using a data-driven, multi-hypothesis, state-of-the-art predictor, we formulate and evaluate a couple of algorithmic strategies, coined as Data-Driven Prediction based Association (DDPA) for constructing the cost matrix between predictions and detections, with the aim of effectively solve the data association problem under the Hungarian algorithm [1]. The evaluation, conducted on the PETS2009 and Oxford-Town-Centre datasets, show promising results on the capability of these models to enhance the data association phase.

title: Impact of Substrate Bias on the Switching Behavior of GaN Bidirectional Switches
authors: Andrea Minetto, Jingcun Liu, Christian Xiao, Xi Ding, Alexander Young, Hyeongnam Kim, Mohamed Imam
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: The gallium nitride (GaN) bidirectional switch (BDS) enables true four-quadrant operation and offers significant benefits in reducing component count and switching losses. However, its unique device structure introduces new reliability challenges. This work investigates the role of substrate biasing on BDS lifetime. Experimental results show that devices with a floating substrate exhibit catastrophic failure within ~30 minutes of operation, while those with the substrate tied to the low-side source remain stable for more than 1000 hours. TCAD simulations reveal that under floating conditions the substrate self-biases to a positive potential, leading to intensified electric fields at the gate side of the device. This localized field intensification provides a direct explanation for the reported lifetime reduction. These results demonstrate that proper substrate biasing is essential for reliable operation of optimized BDS and point to dynamic clamping to the lowest source potential as the preferred solution for the studied device architecture.

title: Reducing Permanent Magnet Volume in a PMSM Using Optimization Algorithms
authors: Ovidiu Craiu, Tiberiu Tudorache
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: The paper presents a two-step approach to reduce the volume of the rare-earth permanent magnets (PMs) used in a small power permanent magnet synchronous machine (PMSM) with 36 stator slots and 12 rotor surface-mounted PMs. In the first step, half of the PMs with the same polarity were replaced with steel, resulting in a machine with half the number of PMs but the same number of magnetic poles. In the second step, the shape of the PMs was optimized to ensure that the new motor produces the same torque as the initial PMSM. Finally, other optimization criteria were used to enhance the torque-magnet volume ratio of the newly designed PMSM. The study was conducted using Finite Element Method (FEM) models and specific optimization algorithms. To validate the models, both COMSOL Multiphysics and Altair Flux software were used, and the results were compared.

title: IEEE CASS Malaysia Chapter: A Remarkable Year of Growth and Achievement in 2024 [CASS Chapter Highlights]
authors: Asral Bahari Jambek, Haslina Jaafar, Julie Roslita Rusli, Luthffi Idzhar Ismail, Mohd Amrallah Mustafa
publish: IEEE Circuits and Systems Magazine
