abstract: The IEEE Circuits and Systems Society (CASS) Malaysia Chapter had a highly successful 2024 where it earns the prestigious IEEE CASS Global Chapter of the Year Award 2025. Throughout the year, the chapter organized 31 diverse programs including professional talks, workshops, educational initiatives, and networking events. These events serve wide range of members from students to industry professionals. Key highlights included the 75th IEEE CASS Day Celebration featuring distinguished global speakers, the IEEE CASS Industry Forum focused on 5G technologies, and international collaboration through the SINO-Malaysia IEEE CASS Outreach Workshop. The chapter emphasized bridging academia and industry, talent development, and STEM education, particularly encouraging young girls through the Girl’s Tech Connect program. Educational workshops covered MEMS, AI-integrated circuits, and CMOS IC design, while the Integrated Design Project Exhibition showcased innovative student projects. Supported by five IEEE CASS HQ grants, the chapter significantly enhanced its presence and impact across Malaysia. Looking ahead, the IEEE CASS Malaysia Chapter remains committed to advancing technology, fostering collaboration, and nurturing the circuits and systems community locally and globally.

title: High-Performance 2D Photonic Crystal Nanocavity Ring Resonator-Based Biosensor for Biomedical Applications
authors: Shivesh Kumar, Mrinal Sen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This article presents a biosensor based on a twodimensional photonic crystal nanocavity ring resonator designed to detect glucose concentration in urine, ranging from $0 \sim 15 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{dl}$ to $\mathbf{1 0 ~ g m} / \mathrm{dl}$. The sensor comprises two waveguides and a nanocavity ring resonator, with optimized hole radii to enhance key performance metrics. The refractive index of bio-samples at different concentrations is used to analyze the interaction between light and the analyte, leading to significant wavelength shifts and effective optical confinement. The band structure is analyzed using the plane-wave expansion method, while sensing parameters are evaluated using the finite-difference time-domain method. The sensor exhibits a frequency shift and transmitted power variations in response to small refractive index variation. Numerical simulations validate a high performance of the sensor with a sensitivity of $1000 \mathrm{~nm} /$ RIU, a quality factor of $6.1283 \times 10^{4}$, a detection limit of $7.285 \times 10^{-6}$ RIU and a figure of merit of 13725.8 RIU ${ }^{-1}$. Its compact footprint of $97.144 \mu \mathrm{~m}^{2}$ makes it ideal for photonic integrated circuits and advanced sensing applications.

title: Implementation And Tuning a Model Predictive Control Scheme for a Single Ended Primary Inductor Converter
authors: Andronic Michel Rajaona, Ömür Akyazi, Yahya Danayiyen
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: In this paper, an optimized Model Predictive Control (MPC) strategy is proposed for the Single-Ended Primary-Inductor Converter (SEPIC) operating under parameter and load variations. The controller is designed using a discrete-time state-space model to regulate the output voltage V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">o</inf>, input voltage V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">in</inf>, and load resistance R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">load</inf> while satisfying duty-cycle constraints. Initially, random values of the control horizon N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</inf>, prediction horizon N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>, output error weight Q, and control effort weight R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">mpc</inf> were applied. The system performance was then analyzed using the Integral of Time-weighted Absolute Error (ITAE) criterion, represented through a 3D surface plot of ITAE versus Q and R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">mpc</inf>. This analysis enabled the identification of optimal parameters that improved system stability and dynamic performance. The optimized MPC was subsequently tested under variations in input voltage, output reference, and load resistance, maintaining accurate tracking, fast settling, and minimal overshoot. The results confirm that the proposed ITAE-driven MPC effectively enhances SEPIC converter performance under dynamically changing conditions.

title: Real-Time and High-Fidelity Text-to-Speech Synthesis using Tacotron 2 and HiFi-GAN
authors: Abdulgaffur Shaikh, Gauri Malpani, Saniya Kerwadkar, Satish Chikkamath, Amith T
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Recent years have seen tremendous progress in text-to-speech (TTS) systems, with models like Tacotron2 and HiFi-GAN allowing for natural and high-quality speech synthesis. In this paper, we investigate speech synthesis using the HiFi-GAN vocoder in conjunction with the Tacotron2 model. HiFi-GAN converts the mel-spectrograms produced by the sequence-to-sequence model Tacotron2 into high-fidelity audio waveforms. Using the LJSpeech dataset for training, we show how to apply these models. With an emphasis on the generated speech’s temporal coherence and perceptual quality, the synthesized audio is assessed both subjectively and objectively. The study also examines how generative adversarial networks (GANs) can improve the synthesis process in TTS systems, resulting in high-quality, real-time performance. Comparing the combined Tacotron2 and HiFi-GAN approach to earlier techniques, experimental results demonstrate a significant improvement in speech synthesis naturalness. Future developments in TTS systems, such as possible additions to multilingual synthesis and voice style transfer, are covered in the paper’s conclusion. Our system achieved a Mean Opinion Score (MOS) of 4.2/5 across 10 listeners (aged 18–25), with synthesis time averaging less than 2 seconds per sentence. Objective metrics such as Mel Cepstral Distortion (MCD) and Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) further confirm improvements over baseline model

title: Algorithms of Group Autonomous Control of Ground Robotic Systems
authors: Dmitry Bagayev, Sergey Solokhin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The article provides a comparative analysis of various algorithms used for group autonomous control of ground-based robotic complexes. The main factors that necessitated the solution of new extraordinary tasks and examples of practical implementation are presented.

title: An Efficient Variational Wind Field Retrieval Method Based on Multi-parameter Regularization
authors: Lang Huang, Hang Gao, Pak-Wai Chan, Yunli Peng, Youcao Wu, Yifu Zhang, Jinzhu Hu, Chun Shen, Zhen Dong, Jianbing Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Variational methods are widely used in the meteorological community to retrieve 3D-wind from single LiDAR observations, but the weights for loss function components are static and determined empirically, and iteratively minimizing the loss function is computationally expensive. In this paper, we propose a hybrid method, the Model Function-based Multi-Regularization parameter selection with Adaptive Weights (MFMR-AW) for the background field components to overcome these challenges. MFMR-AW employs the multi-parameter regularization method to combine the Lidar observations with the background field. The combined effect of MFMR and AW determines the weights of background field components. Then the variational principle is used to transform the function minimization process into a system of linear equations, which can be well handled with the truncated singular value decomposition method. Simulations and field observations are employed to validate the proposed method. Results show that the mean RMSEs of MFMR-AW can be reduced by up to 66.9% compared to traditional assumption-based background fields, and the proposed method can get comparable or even superior accuracy with only about 1% of the computation cost of the traditional variational method.

title: Task-Guided Prompting for Unified Remote Sensing Image Restoration
authors: Wenli Huang, Yang Wu, Xiaomeng Xin, Zhihong Liu, Jinjun Wang, Ye Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing image restoration (RSIR) is essential for recovering high-fidelity imagery from degraded observations, enabling accurate downstream analysis. However, most existing methods focus on single degradation types within homogeneous data, restricting their practicality in real-world scenarios where multiple degradations often across diverse spectral bands or sensor modalities, creating a significant operational bottleneck. To address this fundamental gap, we propose TGPNet, a unified framework capable of handling denoising, cloud removal, shadow removal, deblurring, and SAR despeckling within a single, unified architecture. The core of our framework is a novel Task-Guided Prompting (TGP) strategy. TGP leverages learnable, task-specific embeddings to generate degradation-aware cues, which then hierarchically modulate features throughout the decoder. This task-adaptive mechanism allows the network to precisely tailor its restoration process for distinct degradation patterns while maintaining a single set of shared weights. To validate our framework, we construct a unified RSIR benchmark covering RGB, multispectral, SAR, and thermal infrared modalities for five aforementioned restoration tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that TGPNet achieves state-of-the-art performance on both unified multi-task scenarios and unseen composite degradations, surpassing even specialized models in individual domains such as cloud removal. By successfully unifying heterogeneous degradation removal within a single adaptive framework, this work presents a significant advancement for multi-task RSIR, offering a practical and scalable solution for operational pipelines. The code and benchmark will be released at https://github.com/huangwenwenlili/TGPNet.

title: The Developments and Challenges Toward Dexterous and Embodied Robotic Manipulation: A Survey
authors: Gaofeng Li, Ruize Wang, Peisen Xu, Qi Ye, Jiming Chen
publish: IEEE Robotics & Automation Magazine
abstract: Achieving humanlike dexterous robotic manipulation remains a central goal and a pivotal challenge in robotics. The development of artificial intelligence (AI) has allowed rapid progress in robotic manipulation. This article summarizes the evolution of robotic manipulation from mechanical programming to embodied intelligence, alongside the transition from simple grippers to multifingered dexterous hands, outlining key characteristics and main challenges. Focusing on the current stage of embodied dexterous manipulation, we highlight recent advances in two critical areas: dexterous manipulation data collection (via simulation, human demonstrations, and teleoperation) and skill learning frameworks [imitation learning (IL) and reinforcement learning (RL)]. Then, based on the overview of the existing data collection paradigm and learning framework, three key challenges restricting the development of dexterous robotic manipulation are summarized and discussed.

title: Forward Distortion Compensation Based on Amplitude-Phase-Frequency Block Modulation for Nonlinear OFDM Wireless Communications
authors: Min Fan, Cheng Yi, Bensheng Yang, Wei Xu, Haiming Wang, Xiaohu You
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: In OFDM wireless communications, power amplifier nonlinearity generates significant out-of-band (OOB) emissions and in-band distortion, conventionally requiring large power back-offs to address both issues simultaneously. We propose a forward distortion compensation (FDC) scheme using amplitude-phase-frequency block modulation (APFBM) that decouples OOB emission suppression from in-band distortion management, enabling reliable transmission even under severe power amplifier nonlinearity. At the transmitter, in-band distortion is intentionally introduced to facilitate aggressive OOB emission suppression, while APFBM manages bit mapping and imposes a power-sum constraint on information-carrying subcarriers. At the receiver, this power-sum constraint guides the compensation for in-band distortion, ensuring reliable information recovery. This compensation strategy also relaxes digital pre-distortion (DPD) accuracy requirements, permitting a simpler Sigmoid-based static DPD focused solely on OOB suppression and eliminating feedback circuits. The experimental results show a relative gain of 4.4 dB with a power back-off of 5.2 dB compared to nonlinear transmission based on quadrature amplitude modulation with equivalent processing at 4.9 GHz, while a relative gain of 2.6 dB is achieved at 26.5 GHz. This approach achieves superior energy efficiency and spectral efficiency trade-offs, enhancing coverage and performance in wireless communications.

title: Bionic AR: Standalone Augmented Reality System Controlled by Multimodal Biosignals
authors: HyunSub Kim, Hyeseong Jeon, Chaeyoon Kim, Chunghwan Kim, HwyKuen Kwak, Tae-Nam Kim, Chang-Hwan Im
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technology can elevate user experiences by facilitating intuitive and immersive communication. Commercial AR devices typically rely on hand-held controllers or cameras to generate control commands; however, neither of these approaches is feasible when hand usage is limited. To address this limitation, we introduce a novel stand-alone AR system“, Bionic AR.” This system integrates a head-mounted display (HMD) with biosignal-based human–computer interface (HCI) technology. By embedding passive dry electrodes into the proposed AR headset in contact areas such as the occipital area, brow ridge, and cheeks, the system can simultaneously record electroencephalography (EEG), electrooculography (EOG), and facial electromyography (fEMG) data. The acquired multimodal biosignals were utilized to implement a steady-state visual evoked potential-based brain–computer interface (BCI), an eye-writing pattern recognition system, a facial expression recognition system, and a silent speech recognition system. In real-time experiments, each HCI module achieved accuracies exceeding 98%, underscoring the feasibility and practical potential of the proposed Bionic AR system.

title: Enhancement Mode GaN Tri-Gate MISHEMT With Fluorinated HfO2 as Charge Trapping Layer in Hybrid Ferroelectric Gate Stack
authors: Rahul Rai, Khanh Quoc Nguyen, Hung Duy Tran, Viet Quoc Ho, You Chen Weng, Baquer Mazhari, Hao Chung Kuo, Edward Yi Chang
publish: IEEE Journal of the Electron Devices Society
abstract: In this study, we demonstrate a hybrid ferroelectric charge-trapping gate-stack enhancement-mode GaN tri-gate high electron mobility transistor (FEG-HEMT) featuring a fluorinated HfO2 (F-HfO2) charge trapping layer (CTL), combined with a tri-gate architecture for power device applications. This architecture integrates ferroelectric polarization and charge-trapping mechanisms within a tri-gate nanowire (fin) structure to achieve normally-off operation. Unlike conventional planar HEMTs, the tri-gate configuration exposes the 2-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) channel along the fin sidewalls, enabling effective depletion through trapped charges in the CTL, thereby achieving a high and stable threshold voltage (VTH). There is a possibility that incorporating fluorine into the HfO2 layer reduces oxygen vacancies and dangling bonds, significantly improving the dielectric interface and device reliability. At the dielectric/semiconductor interface, the interface trap density (Dit) was estimated to be 1×1011 to 1.2×1013 cm-2∙eV-1, as extracted using the frequency-dependent conductance method. The tri-gate device demonstrates an impressive VTH of 4.4 ± 0.2 V, IDS-MAX of 946 ± 10 mA/mm, breakdown voltage (BV) of 768 V, and a high-power figure-of-merit (PFOM) of 973 MW/cm2. Additionally, the device exhibits enhanced time-dependent dielectric breakdown (TDDB) lifetime and gate stress resilience, confirming its superior performance and robustness for high-power applications.

title: UAV Detection and Localization: A RF-Based Framework Via Multiple Stations Collaboration
authors: Tianhao Liang, Mu Jia, Tingting Zhang, Junting Chen, Longyu Zhou, Tony Q. S. Quek, Pooi-Yuen Kam
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: The rapid growth of the low-altitude economy has resulted in a significant increase in the number of low, slow, and small (LSS) unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), raising critical challenges for secure airspace management and reliable trajectory planning. To address this, this paper proposes a cooperative radio-frequency (RF) detection and localization framework that leverages existing cellular base stations (BSs). The proposed approach features a robust scheme for LSS target identification, integrating a cell averaging-constant false alarm rate (CA-CFAR) detector with a micro- Doppler signature (MDS) based recognition method. Multi-station measurements are fused through a grid-based probabilistic algorithm combined with clustering techniques, effectively mitigating ghost targets and improving localization accuracy in multi-UAV scenarios. Furthermore, the Cramer-Rao lower bound (CRLB) is derived as a performance benchmark and reinforcement learning (RL)-based optimization is employed to balance localization accuracy against involved BS number. Simulation results demonstrate that increasing from one to multiple BSs can reduce the positioning error to near the CRLB, while practical experiments further verify the effectiveness of our framework. Furthermore, the proposed RL-based optimization can maintain high accuracy while minimizing resource usage, highlighting its potential as a scalable solution for ensuring airspace safety in the emerging low-altitude economy.

title: Robust Sparse Recovery-Based STAP for Clutter Suppression Under Multipath Effect in Low-Altitude Environments
authors: Sijia Li, Huake Wang, Guisheng Liao, Yinghui Quan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: In low-altitude environment, the clutter heterogeneity caused by multipath seriously affects the clutter suppression performance of Space-time adaptive processing (STAP). A robust Direct Data Domain approach, using sparse recovery (D3-SR) STAP is proposed to realize robust clutter suppression under the multipath effect. Firstly, the D3-SR method is proposed to get a high-resolution clutter power spectrum, which effectively obtains spectrum estimation under the condition of minimal training samples. By setting a smoothing adaptive subspace, the Focal Underdetermined System Solver (FUSS) algorithm, which is used as the iterative algorithm in the D3-SR method, is improved to reduce the computational error and computational complexity. Then, the clutter covariance matrix (CCM) is obtained by the high-resolution clutter power spectrum of the improved D3-SR method, which solves the training sample shortage under the multipath effect. Based on the improved D3-SR method, the robust D3-SR-STAP is proposed to solve the target steering vector mismatch in STAP caused by the reflected signal of the multipath. By setting two-dimensional magnitude-phase constraints around the target angle-Doppler two-dimensional plain, the mainlobe of the STAP adaptive beamformer is maintained. This can effectively improve the STAP performance under the multipath effect in low-altitude environment. Simulation results validate the effectiveness that the robust STAP can achieve great performance of clutter suppression under the multipath effect.

title: Uncrewed Aerial Vehicle Communications for Low-Altitude Economy: Leveraging Integrated Satellite-Terrestrial Networks
authors: Yue Zhang, Hangguan Shan, Fen Hou, Zhiguo Shi, Tony Q. S. Quek, Jiming Chen
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications
abstract: With the rapid proliferation of low-altitude economy, the demand for highly reliable uncrewed aerial vehicle (UAV) communications has become increasingly urgent. Traditional terrestrial communication technologies face significant deficiency in addressing the aerial and moving features of UAVs, while the integrated satellite-terrestrial networks (ISTNs) have emerged as a promising solution for low-altitude communications by combining the pros of satellite and terrestrial systems. This article first presents the limitations of terrestrial networks in meeting UAV traffic demands and coverage requirements. Then, critical design issues confronted by ISTNs are covered, including multi-dimensional resource management, multi-layer cooperative beamforming, handover, and sensing-assisted communications, aiming to ensure seamless wide-area coverage and improve communication reliability for UAVs. Finally, we discuss the remaining open problems in ISTN-based UAV communications.

title: A Review on Bangla Text-to-Speech with Human-Like Expressions
authors: Robiul Islam, MD Rakibul Islam, Rahadul Islam Jishan, Jannatun Noor Mukta, A.K.M. Muzahidul Islam
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Text-to-Speech (TTS) synthesis for Bangla has encountered steady improvement over the last decade made possible because of rapid improvements in deep learning, and ever-increasing amount of speech resources. However, it still remains a challenge to achieve natural and expressive synthesis for the Bangla language due to its complex phonetic structure, variable dialects, and lack of high-quality datasets. In this paper, we present a comprehensive review of Bangla TTS research to date, tracing the progression from traditional concatenative and parametric methods to most modern end-to-end neural frameworks, including autoregressive models (e.g., Tacotron), non-autoregressive models (e.g., FastSpeech 2), flow- and GAN-based architectures (e.g., VITS - Variational Inference TTS), diffusion-based approaches, and conversational systems such as ChatTTS.We synthesize insights from 13 state-of-the-art models to compare their architectural designs, prosody and speaker-control mechanisms, multilingual capabilities, and practical strengths and limitations. Finally, we provide a detailed overview of publicly available Bangla speech datasets, including the Bangla Speech Corpus, SUBESCO, Common Voice (Bangla), and SHRUTI Bengali, evaluating their suitability for expressive and high-quality speech synthesis. Open issues discussed include emotion modeling, addressing code-mixing, resource constraints, and issues of a lack of linguistic resources. This survey is not only a hefty review of the current pace/state of research, but it also identifies high-priority challenges, and valuable opportunities in the future, putting us on the pathway toward a more natural, expressive, and accessible Bangla Text-to-Speech system.

title: Inter-trial consistency in sensorimotor cortex during finger-tapping movements
authors: Hao Lu, Yong Li, Min Xiang, Yuyu Ma, Yang Gao, Xiaolin Ning
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Optically-pumped magnetometer magnetoencephalography (OPM-MEG) is a new technology to detect neural electrophysiological signals. Inter-trial consistency (ITC) is an important indicator to characterize functional connectivity. It also provides a reliable indicator for verifying the accuracy of OPM-MEG measurements.This paper adopts a finger tapping movement paradigm based on auditory cues, uses OPM-MEG and Electroencephalography (EEG) to measure the functional signals of the brain, and calculates and compares their ITC. The results show that the similarity ratio of ITC between OPM-MEG and EEG is greater than 0.92, which proves OPM-MEG can measure the ITC of the brain and characterize the functional connectivity of the brain.This study verifies the potential of OPM-MEG in motor-related paradigm research.

title: Adaptive Prescribed-Time Stabilization of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems: A Time-Transformation Method
authors: Cui-Hua Zhang, Yu-Jia Li, Ze-Yun Hu, Chang-Chun Hua, Kai Ma, Ying Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article addresses the problem of prescribed-time stabilization of nonlinear systems with the features of unknown control directions and time-varying uncertain parameters based on a time-transformation method. The basic ideology relies on a newly established time-transformation method that incorporates the classical adaptive technique, converting the prescribed-time stable control problem of the original system into an asymptotically stable problem of its time-transformed stretched form. Unlike the existing literature, the time transformation method in this article directly gives the adaptive laws before and after the time transformation, which greatly reduces the complexity of designing the adaptive prescribed-time controller due to the fact that the design of the adaptive law in the stretched time domain only needs to satisfy the asymptotic stability criterion. Finally, the proposed methodology is validated by a simulation example.

title: Emotion Recognition in Human–Computer Interaction Using Multimodal Adaptive Reweighting Strategy
authors: Yunkai Li, Yuxin Ding, Xuhui Yan, Lei Yang, Yanhong Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition (MER) plays a vital role in human-computer interaction for consumer electronics. However, a key challenge to the practical deployment of current MER methods is the presence of varying noise levels and potential conflicts among modalities. Moreover, existing multimodal learning approaches usually evaluate modality quality from a global perspective, overlooking the inherent data quality biases present across different modalities. To this end, a multimodal adaptive reweighting strategy (Mars) is proposed, which combines an uncertainty weighting mechanism with a staged training framework for reliable multimodal fusion. Specifically, the proposed uncertainty weighting mechanism computes a dynamically scaled loss for each sample pair, enabling the model to automatically prioritize information from more reliable modalities while de-emphasizing less reliable ones from a sample perspective. The staged training framework initially emphasizes learning from the global sample distribution and gradually shifts focus to high-quality samples in later stages, thereby mitigating overfitting. This approach enhances the robustness of each modality and improves overall MER performance. Experimental results show that Mars outperforms baseline methods by 4.6% and 6.07% on the RAVDESS and FETE datasets, respectively, without introducing additional model parameters. The code of Mars is available at: https://github.com/AI-touch/Mars.

title: Physical Layer Aspects of Quantum Communications: A Survey
authors: Seid Koudia, Leonardo Oleynik, Mert Bayraktar, Junaid Ur Rehman, Symeon Chatzinotas
publish: IEEE Communications Surveys & Tutorials
abstract: Quantum communication systems support unique applications in the form of distributed quantum computing, distributed quantum sensing, and several cryptographic protocols. The main enabler in these communication systems is an efficient infrastructure that is capable to transport unknown quantum states with high rate and fidelity. This feat requires a new approach to communication system design which efficiently exploits the available physical layer resources, while respecting the limitations and principles of quantum information. Despite the fundamental differences between the classic and quantum worlds, there exist universal communication concepts that may proven beneficial in quantum communication systems as well. In this survey, the distinctive aspects of physical layer quantum communications are highlighted in a attempt to draw commonalities and divergences between classic and quantum communications. More specifically, we begin by overviewing the quantum channels and use cases over diverse optical propagation media, shedding light on the concepts of crosstalk and interference. Subsequently, we survey quantum sources, detectors, channels and modulation techniques. More importantly, we discuss and analyze spatial multiplexing techniques, such as coherent control, multiplexing, diversity and MIMO. Finally, we identify synergies between the two communication technologies and grand open challenges that can be pivotal in the development of next-generation quantum communication systems.

title: Cross-Coupled Substrate Integrated Waveguide Filter Using Orthogonality to Improve Selectivity
authors: Peng Chu, Jialong Zhou, Wenyu Zhang, Fang Zhu, Leilei Liu, Ke Wu
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: The substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) filters usually employ cross coupling to achieve quasi-elliptic responses, getting steep selectivity near the passband. However, the added cross coupling also facilitates the transmission of spurious modes, leading to significant spurious passbands and insufficient selectivity in the stopband. It has been challenging to address this problem effectively. In this letter, we propose a solution. By using the orthogonality of spurious modes and coupling paths, spurious modes can be naturally suppressed in both the main and cross-coupling paths, thereby suppressing spurious passbands and improving selectivity in the stopband. At the same time, the quasi-elliptic response remains unaffected, which can be designed as usual, and the structure change is very small without increasing the complexity compared with the conventional design. It should be effective for developing SIW filters in microwave and wireless circuits and systems.

title: An Approach to Breast Thermogram Classification Using Integral Processing for Breast Cancer Screening
authors: Amdy Moustapha Drame
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This study proposes a classification method for breast cancer diagnosis based on thermograms, leveraging thermal asymmetries through infrared thermography and microwave radiothermometry. The developed algorithm relies on an image processing pipeline coupled with a decision tree-based classifier. The stages include thermogram preprocessing with a circular mask, integral image construction, regional feature extraction, and binary classification with regularization via Laplacian smoothing. The dataset, comprising 9,786 thermograms (8,192 healthy, 1,594 at-risk), is balanced using the SMOTE technique and validated through 5-fold stratified cross-validation. Results indicate an accuracy of 0.68, sensitivity of 0.81, and AUC ROC of 0.73, suggesting effective detection of positive cases but moderate specificity (0.54). These promising results open prospects for analyzing thermal variations in breast thermograms, though improvements are needed to optimize specificity.

title: Calculation of the Coefficients of the CVC Working Roll Profiling Equation
authors: Sergey Belskiy, Ivan Shopin, Vasiliy Cherkashin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The uneven distribution of elongations across the width of the rolled strip causes an uneven distribution of residual longitudinal stresses, which disrupt the flat shape of the strip. The non-flatness of the rolled strip is caused by irregularities in the profile of its cross-section during rolling. To regulate the profile of the strip's cross-section, the technology of wide-strip rolling in stands equipped with axial shift devices for the working rolls with CVC profiling is widely used. The article describes a method for determining the coefficients of a cubic parabola for CVC profiling

title: Short-Circuit Characterization of a Planar 1200 V SiC MOSFET by TCAD Electro-Thermal Modeling
authors: Pei-Chi Liao, Xue-Fen Hu, Yi-Pin Lee, Kung-Yen Lee, Chun-Wei Yeh, Pei-Chun Liao, Tsuyoshi Funaki
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: The short-circuit (SC) reliability is critical for SiC MOSFETs in high-power systems, as excessive current and voltage may trigger the parasitic BJT and cause device failure. A 1200 V planar SiC MOSFET was analyzed using calibrated TCAD electro-thermal simulations. The influence of different turn-off gate voltages, (V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">GS,OFF</inf>) on SC performance was investigated. The results show that applying V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">GS,OFF</inf> = −4 V reduces channel current, delays BJT activation, and increases the short-circuit withstand time (SCWT) from 5 μs to 6 μs compared with V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">GS,OFF</inf> = 0 V. Carrier analysis confirms that negative bias prevents the positive feedback loop between the channel and the parasitic BJT, which lowers the junction temperature (T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">j</inf>) rise. To validate the accuracy of TCAD, a Foster RC thermal network was built in LTspice, showing good agreement with simulation results. These findings provide insight into the SC failure process and show that proper gate bias can improve the robustness of SiC MOSFETs. Future work will include experimental tests to confirm the simulation results.

title: Quantum Computing for Sustainable Agriculture: A Review and Conceptual Framework
authors: Yue Wu, Attila Nagy, Ács Szilvia, Beatrix Fregan, Zoltan Rajnai
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Global challenges of food security, population growth, climate change and resource scarcity require increasingly urgent solutions. The emergence of quantum computing opens new opportunities for future agriculture, especially within the framework of the agriculture 5.0 vision. The study demonstrates how quantum algorithms and quantum simulations can be applied in key areas such as energy transfer in photosynthesis, increasing the efficiency of gene editing, designing protein structures, optimizing fertilizer production, and adapting to climate change. Through these applications, quantum technology can not only complement classical approaches in agri-informatics, but also open new dimensions towards sustainable, data-driven and intelligent food production. The aim of the thesis is to establish a functional framework that systematically maps the opportunities and benefits of integrating quantum technology into agriculture.

title: Selection of a Rational Composition of Functional Software and Its Allocation for Onboard Computing Systems of Robotic Complexes
authors: Konstantin Suminov, Mikhail Kirilyuk, Nikita Bocharov, Nikolay Paramonov, Denis Yanko, Andrey Timonov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: Onboard computing systems (OCS) play a pivotal role in robotic complexes (RC), enabling the transition to autonomous systems. This article presents a method for selecting a rational composition of functional software (FS) and allocating it across computing nodes of RC OCS under extreme conditions. The method is based on solving a multidimensional knapsack problem with multichoice and dependencies between elements. This approach optimizes FS configuration while accounting for constraints and task requirements. The developed method can be applied to ensure the survivability of RC OCS in dynamic operating environments.

title: Learning to Optimally Dispatch Power: Performance on a Nation-Wide Real-World Dataset
authors: Ignacio Boero, Santiago Diaz, Tomás Vázquez, Enzo Coppes, Pablo Belzarena, Federico Larroca
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: The Optimal Reactive Power Dispatch (ORPD) problem plays a crucial role in power system operations, ensuring voltage stability and minimizing power losses. Recent advances in machine learning (ML), particularly within the "learning to optimize" framework, have enabled fast and efficient approximations of ORPD solutions, typically by training models on precomputed optimization results. While these approaches have demonstrated promising performance on synthetic datasets, their effectiveness under real-world grid conditions remains largely unexplored. This paper makes two key contributions. First, we introduce a publicly available power system dataset that includes both the structural characteristics of a complete nation’s electrical grid (Uruguay), as well as nearly two years of real-world operational data, encompassing actual demand and generation profiles. Given Uruguay’s high penetration of renewable energy in this network, the ORPD problem has become the primary optimization challenge in its operation. Equipped with this data, and as a second contribution, we assess the impact of these real-world inputs on ML-based ORPD solutions, revealing a significant increase in prediction errors when transitioning from synthetic to actual demand and generation profiles. Our results highlight the limitations of existing models in learning under the complex statistical properties of real grid conditions and emphasize the need for more expressive architectures. By providing this dataset and the associated code, we aim to facilitate further research into robust ML-based optimization techniques for power system management.

title: When FinTech Meets Privacy: Securing Financial LLMs with Differential Private Fine-Tuning
authors: Sichen Zhu, Hoyeung Leung, Xiaoyi Wang, Jia Wei, Honghui Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: The integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) into financial technology (FinTech) has revolutionized the analysis and processing of complex financial data, driving advancements in real-time decision-making and analytics. With the growing trend of deploying AI models on edge devices for financial applications, ensuring the privacy of sensitive financial data has become a significant challenge. To address this, we propose DPFinLLM, a privacy-enhanced, lightweight LLM specifically designed for on-device financial applications. DPFinLLM combines a robust differential privacy mechanism with a streamlined architecture inspired by state-of-the-art models, enabling secure and efficient processing of financial data. This proposed DPFinLLM can not only safeguard user data from privacy breaches but also ensure high performance across diverse financial tasks. Extensive experiments on multiple financial sentiment datasets validate the effectiveness of DPFinLLM, demonstrating its ability to achieve performance comparable to fully fine-tuned models, even under strict privacy constraints.

title: Measuring and Benchmarking Incident Response Readiness
authors: Muntathar Abid, Priyadarsi Nanda
publish: 2025 European Symposium on Usable Security (EuroUSEC)
abstract: Small-to-medium enterprises (SMEs) remain disproportionately vulnerable to cyber incidents due to constrained resources and underdeveloped operational practices. While many maintain incident response plans (IRPs) to meet regulatory requirements, these plans are often untested and poorly integrated into operational workflows, resulting in delayed containment, unclear escalation, and inconsistent response actions. This disconnect between documentation and execution representing a critical readiness gap that can significantly increase the impact and duration of cyber events. To address this challenge, this paper introduces the Incident Response Readiness Score (IRRS); a scenario-based assessment framework designed to empirically evaluate an organisation's incident response capability under simulated conditions. The IRRS applies a structured scoring rubric calibrated through a Scenario Risk Index, enabling proportional evaluation of performance across diverse incident types. By transforming qualitative incident response actions into a reproducible and risk-weighted metric, the IRRS offers a practical and scalable means of assessing and improving cybersecurity readiness for different type organisations.

title: Development of an Intelligent System for Linguistic Analysis and Storage of Dialects through Logic Programming (PROLOG)
authors: Radomira Lazarova, Stanimir Stoyanov, Atanas Dukovski, Veneta Tabakova-Komsalova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a prototype of an intelligent system designed for automated analysis, modelling and storage of endangered linguistic assets, with a focus on the Rhodope dialects of the Bulgarian language. The core of the system is a knowledge base implemented in the logic programming language Prolog, which formalizes lexical and morphological rules. The system architecture includes several modules for morphological analysis of different parts of speech (nouns, verbs, adjectives, invariable words), with each module containing specialized rules for lemmatization, word form generation and grammatical category recognition. Specialized predicates have been developed to process dialect-specific phonetic and morphosyntactic phenomena (such as triple articulation in the Rhodope dialects). To ensure accessibility and interactivity, the system integrates a web server implemented entirely in Prolog. The main contribution of the work is in demonstrating the possibility of creating efficient intelligent natural language processing (NLP) systems with symbolic artificial intelligence methods requiring minimal computational resources. The project serves as a model for the application of logic programming in the humanities and digital cultural heritage.

title: Radial Buckley-Leverett Solver Based on Physics-Informed Neural Networks with Gated Attention Mechanism
authors: Xiangyi Ma, Lianpeng Zang, El-Sayed M. El-Alfy, Jacek Mandziuk, Jian Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: In oilfield production optimization, water flooding is a key technique to enhance recovery, and its seepage process is commonly modeled by the Buckley-Leverett (BL) equation. However, under planar radial flow conditions, the BL equation is challenging to solve due to its hyperbolic nature and shock formation. Traditional numerical methods are constrained by numerical dissipation and high computational costs, limiting predictive accuracy, while conventional physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) suffer from unstable convergence near shocks, leading to poor accuracy. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a PINN framework integrated with a gated attention mechanism (Gated Attention-PINN). By introducing gated attention modules, the method strengthens feature interactions, significantly improves shock-capturing capability and convergence stability, and further enhances model interpretability. This work not only extends the applicability of PINNs to radial flow simulations but also provides a high-accuracy, stable, and interpretable tool for complex multiphase flow modeling. Experimental results demonstrate that Gated AttentionPINN outperforms standard PINN in both accuracy and convergence speed, achieving a 65% reduction in mean squared error and an increase in $R^{2}$ to over $95 \%$.

title: Belt Defect Detection Based on Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Lei Yun, Wugedele Bao, Jinming Wang, Fei Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: To address the issues of false positives and suboptimal detection performance due to a limited number of belt defect samples in existing belt defect detection methods, this paper proposes a belt defect detection method based on an improved unsupervised generative adversarial network (GAN). This method primarily trains the model using images of defect-free belts, calculates outliers in the test set images, and distinguishes whether the samples have defects. The method combines an encoder and replaces its standard convolutions with depthwise separable convolutions to reduce detection time. In the discriminator, spectral norm normalization is used to stabilize model training. During the detection phase, the outlier calculation formula is improved, and the weighting of each loss component is redistributed to enhance detection accuracy. The experimental results show that the accuracy (A) of the model on the belt data set is 98.67%, the probability of correct judgment of the value of the defective sample is higher than that of the normal sample (AUC) is 99.88%, and the average accuracy (AP) is 99.71%., outperforming the detection performance of DCGAN and f-AnoGAN under equivalent conditions. Additionally, the average detection time is reduced by 2.70% compared to f-AnoGAN. The experiments demonstrate that the improved algorithm achieves good results in belt defect detection.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization for Task Offloading and Migration Decisions in Cloud-Edge-Terminal Collaborative Computing
authors: Huihai Sun, Yanyan Tan, Chuanfen Feng, Jiande Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of task offloading and migration decision-making in cloud-edge-terminal collaborative computing. We formulate a Multi-objective optimization model that simultaneously minimizes task delay and energy consumption, thereby providing a set of Pareto-optimal solutions for practical deployment. To efficiently explore the highdimensional decision space, a group-based encoding strategy is proposed to reduce variable dimensionality. On this basis, we develop a hybrid optimization algorithm that integrates MultiObjective Particle Swarm Optimization (MOPSO), a Backpropagation Neural Network (BPNN)-assisted prediction mechanism, and an Adaptive Expansion Sampling (AES) strategy. The MOPSO framework serves as the global optimizer, while the BPNN module leverages learned task-performance mappings to predict convergence directions, and AES adaptively balances exploration and exploitation. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to single-objective optimization and weighted-sum methods, the proposed approach achieves superior trade-offs between latency and energy consumption, faster convergence speed, and better solution diversity. These findings highlight the potential of the proposed framework for efficient resource optimization in next-generation cloud-edge-terminal collaborative systems.

title: Improvement of MBGD-RDA Algorithm Based on Fuzzy Clustering and Research on Regression Performance
authors: Weimin Hu, Xinyi Wang, Eun-Hu Kim, Zunwei Fu, Zheng Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Aiming at the problems that the membership function initialization of traditional training algorithms for Takagi-Sugeno-Kang (TSK) fuzzy systems relies on prior knowledge and the generalization ability is limited by parameter settings, an improved MBGD-RDA algorithm based on fuzzy clustering (FC-MBGD-RDA) is proposed. This algorithm adopts Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) clustering to replace the manual initialization process of Gaussian membership function, and adaptively generates the membership degree distribution of the rule antecedent through a data-driven approach. It retains the mini-batch gradient descent (MBGD), L2 regularization, DropRule and AdaBound optimization strategies of the original algorithm, forming a TSK fuzzy system training framework with both adaptive rule generation and efficient parameter optimization. Experiments on 4 standard regression datasets show that FC-MBGD-RDA achieves a lower average test RMSE compared to the original MBGD-RDA. It converges faster on high-dimensional datasets and exhibits stronger robustness against hyperparameter variations.

title: Predictive Wellness Analytics Through Hybrid Sensor-LLM Integration
authors: Roopam Dhanraj Choudhari, Gaurav Khodwe
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: This paper presents a novel predictive wellness analytics framework that integrates human activity recognition (HAR) sensor data with large language model (LLM) extracted behavioral context for personalized health interventions. Our hybrid pipeline combines the WISDM accelerometer dataset with contextual features derived from natural language wellness logs, enabling both accurate activity classification and personalized recommendation generation. The proposed late-fusion architecture achieves 98.2% accuracy for core activity recognition (Walking, Jogging, Sitting, Standing) while simultaneously providing contextually aware wellness recommendations. Through controlled experimental validation using synthetic wellness narratives, we demonstrate that incorporating LLM-extracted behavioral features (sleep patterns, fatigue levels, activity goals) significantly enhances the personalization capabilities of traditional sensor-based wellness systems. This work establishes a technical foundation for intelligent digital health assistants that bridges the gap between objective sensor measurements and subjective wellness experiences, while identifying critical research directions for real-world deployment.
