authors: Abu Shahir Md Khalid Hasan, Mohammad Dehan Rahman, Md Majharul Islam, Md Maksudul Hossain, H. Alan Mantooth
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: Over the past decade, Gallium Oxide (Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) has seen noticeable technological strides, positioning itself as a frontrunner among ultra-wide bandgap semiconductor technologies. Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> has impressive inherent material properties such as critical field strength, generously adjustable conductivity, elevated mobility, and the capacity for scalable melt-based bulk growth, rendering it particularly suitable for power electronics applications. A primary focus lies in power electronics, where Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> is poised to offer top-tier performance at an economically viable level. Enhancement-mode Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (E-MOSFETs) have already demonstrated stable DC output characteristics under normal conditions. This stability is achieved through the incorporation of a low-doped body layer beneath the MOS gate, facilitating normally-off operation, while the epitaxial drift layer dictates on-resistance and breakdown voltage. Research has delved into the impact of doping concentration and drift channel layer thickness on device properties, aiming to design a device capable of withstanding a breakdown voltage of 680V. This study zeroes in on single-event upset (SEU) occurrences in Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> E-MOSFETs near the breakdown region. The analysis encompasses two types of events: SEU with normal incidence and oblique incidence. The insights gleaned from this analysis hold substantial potential for enhancing power electronics circuit simulations.

title: SafEV: ML-based DDoS Attack Detection Framework for Autonomous EVs in Smart Cities
authors: Poorvanshi Kochar, Rimmi Sharma, Saanvi Ganna, Lakshit Pathak, Rajesh Gupta, Sudeep Tanwar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The incorporation of Autonomous electric vehicles (EV) into smart cities offers substantial advantages for transportation and energy management. However, it also instigates new security challenges distinctly from Distributed Denial of Services (DDoS) attacks which leads to disruption of network operations. In order to mitigate, prevent and detect DDoS attacks in autonomous EV networks, we proposed SafEV a Machine Learning (ML)-based framework using various ML models such as K-nearest Neighbour (KNN), Logistics Regression (LR), Support Vector Machines (SVM), and Naive Bayes (NB) and the SVM was found to be the most accurate classifier among them, distinguishing DDoS attacks with an accuracy of $95.50 \%$. The model’s efficiency and accuracy demonstrates realtime attack detection and mitigation. To evaluate the SafEV framework’s efficiency, we use several performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F 1 -score, PR and ROC curves, which further emphasises the robustness and resilience of the system. The proposed SafEV framework provides an efficient method for sheltering Autonomous EV Networks, ensuring trustworthy and cautious operations within smart cities. Furthermore, to enhance the security and productivity of transportation and energy systems, it precisely detects malicious activities.

title: Polyp Segmentation with PolypPVT, TransUNet, and Fine-Tuned UNet: A Deep Learning-Based Comparative Study on Kvasir-SEG
authors: Khadersab Adamsab, Vaidehi P Deshpande, Rahila Begum Gadi, Nabeel Ahmed Gadi, Vinayak V Kulkarni, Aziza Ahmedi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Early detection of colorectal polyps is essential in reducing the risk of colorectal cancer. And one of the leading causes of cancer-related mortality worldwide. While colonoscopy remains the clinical gold standard for detection, at the same time, manual polyp segmentation introduces subjectivity and inefficiency. To address these challenges, this study presents the use of deep learning models PolypPVT, TransUNet, and Fine-Tuned UNet for automated polyp segmentation. Each model is evaluated under uniform training, augmentation, and evaluation conditions using the publicly available Kvasir-Seg dataset, which comprises 1000 annotated colonoscopy images. PolypPVT with Pyramid Vision Transformer (PVT) encoder achieved higher outcomes with Dice 0.94 and IoU 0.89. And a hybrid convolution-transformer model, TransUNet, obtains a Dice score of 0.91 and an IoU of 0.86. A refined UNet model with ResNet34 backbone with the scSE attention mechanism trails with a Dice score of 0.88 and IoU of 0.83. Results show that transformer-based models are more effective at capturing feature representation and enforcing boundary precision. The performance comparisons are also subject to visual overlays and learning curves. This work provides important considerations when deploying clinical AI models by revealing the strengths and trade-offs of the state-of-the-art segmentation architectures and facilitating more reliable and accurate polyp detection in clinical practice.

title: Through an AI's Looking Glass: Discovering Dental Sexual Dimorphism with Explainable AI
authors: Natthanich Hirunchavarod, Natnicha Sributsayakarn, Suchaya Pornprasertsuk-Damrongsri, Varangkanar Jirarattanasopha, Thanapong Intharah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: We propose a framework that extends explainable AI (XAI) from per-instance interpretation to dataset-wide knowledge discovery in dental morphology. A deep convolutional neural network was trained on 5,132 panoramic radiographs from 2,778 individuals to predict sex. Using OPG-SHAP, a domain-specific XAI method, we identified influential oral parts and validated them with statistical analysis. The upper canine was the most influential region, with females showing a significantly higher width-to-height ratio (0.391) than males (0.347), aligning with existing literature. Additionally, the upper third molar emerged as a novel sexually dimorphic feature, with males showing a higher ratio (1.064) than females (1.036). Both differences were statistically significant (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p<0.001$</tex>). Our results demonstrate how interpretable AI can rediscover known anatomical patterns and reveal new insights, enabling clinically meaningful knowledge extraction from neural networks.

title: Development of a Portable Plantar Image Acquisition Setup and its Analysis for Pressure Distribution and Arch Index of Varied Foot-types using an Artificial Intelligence
authors: Akshay Daydar, Amit Kumar, Lipika Boruah, Subramani Kanagaraj
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The increase in pathological foot conditions such as flat foot, and high arch foot leads to associated complications, amputations and morbidity that could result in a substantial increase in treatment costs. The prognosis of these deformities is clinically identified using plantar pressure maps from commercial setups is highly accurate, but was found to persist limited applicability due to lack of mobility and affordability. To address these challenges, a portable plantar pressure measurement setup has been developed and named as Portable Plantar Image Acquisition (PPIA) setup. This setup is able to capture a sequence of images during the stance phase of participants involved in the study. Furthermore, the analysis of the collected data is conducted from state-of-the art AI models involving Unet segmentation model [1] and the K-means clustering algorithm, differing from the previously explored portable setups. The study was conducted on 51 participants, including healthy and pathological feet involving flat and high arch conditions. The developed PPIA setup has achieved excellent results in mimicking the results of commercial systems for (1) foot type classification, with an accuracy of $92.15 \%$, a precision of $83.38 \%$, and a recall of $81.44 \%$, and (2) plantar pressure distribution with mean squared error (MSE) values of $\mathbf{1. 4 0 ~ f o r ~ t h e ~ f o r e f o o t ~ (F), ~} \mathbf{1. 4 8}$ for the midfoot (M), and 3.02 for the heel (H) regions, respectively. The decision-making process of healthcare professionals is expected to be aided by the PPIA setup and AI-based module with the same effectiveness as commercial systems.

title: WT-ViT: A Wavelet-Enhanced Vision Transformer for High-Accuracy Automatic Modulation Classification
authors: Xinfeng Gao, Li Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Automatic modulation classification (AMC) plays a crucial role in intelligent communication systems, as it enables reliable identification of signal types under diverse channel conditions. In this work, we propose a novel method, Wavelet-Enhanced Vision Transformer (WTViT), which integrates the multi-resolution analysis capability of wavelet transform with the powerful sequence modeling ability of Vision Transformer. By employing a wavelet transform convolution module, rich multi-scale time-frequency features of signals are effectively extracted, which are then processed by a Transformer encoder to capture long-range dependencies and complex global structures. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, extensive experiments are conducted on the widely used RadioML 2018.01A dataset and a self-constructed supplementary dataset with broader modulation categories. The results demonstrate that WTViT consistently outperforms existing methods, achieving classification accuracies of $95.54 \%$ and $97.96 \%$, respectively, thereby confirming its robustness and strong generalization ability for AMC tasks.

title: SNR-based Adaptive Semantic Communication in Vehicular Networks
authors: Zhentong Feng, Axida Shan, Zhanfei Ma, Jing Chen, Jiujie Zhang, Xuebao Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: Semantic communication aims to improve the efficiency of data transmission by focusing on meaning rather than exact signal reconstruction. This paper proposes an adaptive semantic communication system that dynamically adjusts the encoding strategy based on signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Specifically, we employ a deep neural encoder-decoder pipeline for the MNIST dataset, selectively applying compression and denoising based on SNR levels. Our experiments show that, for MNIST the reconstructed image has 94% classification accuracy even under compression rate of 0.1, for CIFAR-10 the reconstructed images are acceptable at 0.7 compression which saves 30% of data usage in image transferring. The proposed method is designed with vehicular networks in mind, where wireless channels are highly dynamic due to rapid mobility and frequent topology changes. Our system is salient when bandwidth is limited and unstable which is constantly occurring between vehicles and infrastructure.

title: Exploring the Impact of Generative AI on Education: A Twitter Sentiment Study with Transformer Models
authors: Sreekantha Desai Karanam, R.S. Kamath, Sampath Kini K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Generative AI (GenAI) tools such as ChatGPT are transforming educational practices worldwide. While these technologies present opportunities for personalization, efficiency, and innovation, they also raise challenges related to academic integrity, data security, and the evolving role of educators. This study investigates public perceptions of GenAI in education through sentiment analysis of Twitter discourse. A dataset of 1,487 education-related tweets was extracted, pre-processed, and analysed using a RoBERTa-based sentiment classification model. Results indicate that 89.8% of tweets expressed positive sentiment, 7.7% neutral, and 2.5% negative. Temporal analysis revealed spikes in tweet activity corresponding to key GenAI developments, with positive sentiment consistently dominating. These findings provide actionable insights for educators, policymakers, and AI developers in shaping responsible integration strategies for GenAI in education.

title: Mathematical Models and Algorithms for Flexible Management of Project Timelines and Resources
authors: Ekaterina Ivanova, Tatiana Azarnova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This article addresses the problem of project management under uncertainty and resource constraints, where traditional planning methods prove ineffective. It proposes an approach that combines the classical method of determining the critical path (prescriptive scheduling) and a specialized genetic algorithm for dynamic resource optimization. The genetic algorithm shifts noncritical tasks within their slack time to minimize the need for expensive subcontractors while meeting the project deadline. The model encodes potential schedule shifts as chromosomes and uses a fitness function to minimize subcontracting costs. The results demonstrate that this combined method provides a flexible and effective decision support tool for optimizing both project schedules and resource allocation.

title: IEEE CASS R9 Tours 2025 [CAS Outreach Highlights]
authors: Carlos Silva-Cardenas, Victor Grimblatt, Manuel Delgado-Restituto, Ricardo Reis
publish: IEEE Circuits and Systems Magazine
abstract: The IEEE CASS R9 Tours 2025 were organized in Paraguay, Brazil, Costa Rica and Honduras. The tours included technical talks, a special talk about the IEEE CASS and opportunities provided by the society. The main goal of the CASS Tour is to motivate professionals and students in R9 to become active members of the society and to motivate professionals and students to organize new CASS Student Branch Chapters. It also helped improve activities in existing CASS Chapters.

title: Dynamic IoU Thresholding for Test-Time Adaptive Object Detection
authors: Keyi Wan, Jikai Zheng, Mingjia Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Object detection in real-world deployment often suffers from severe performance degradation due to domain shifts between training and test environments, such as drastic variations in style and illumination. This issue is particularly critical for safety-critical real-time applications like autonomous driving and video surveillance. Test-Time Adaptation (TTA) offers a promising solution by dynamically updating model parameters during inference without requiring source data or pre-collected target samples. However, existing TTA methods mainly target image classification, while their extension to object detection remains limited and is hindered by noisy pseudo-labels. To tackle this, we introduce a dynamic adaptive IoU thresholding mechanism that combines IoU across consecutive iterations (IoU-CI) and IoU among overlapping detections (IoU-OD). We further design a dynamic threshold adjustment strategy guided by iteration progress, detection confidence, and prediction uncertainty, enabling adaptive filtering and improved pseudo-label quality. Extensive experiments on multiple artistic-style datasets show that our method consistently outperforms state-of-theart TTA baselines, boosting detection performance by over 4 mAP points (e.g., $23.17 \%$ on Comic2k), and significantly enhancing pseudo-label reliability.

title: Efficient Neural Network Pruning through Causal Weight Identification and Performance Retention
authors: Shalini Joseph, Mayank Gadia, Pratyush Meher, Pramath Srivastava
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Neural network size reduction through pruning constitutes an important problem for resource-limited devices since it enables weight removal without performance degradation. Traditionally pruning methods used weight ranking techniques and magnitude penalties to rate weights for later removal during the retraining phase of surviving weights. The process of network size reduction through neuron removal from the network forms part of pruning strategies. The weight selection process forms an optimization problem which aims to find specific weights that minimize misclassifications. The system has two new mechanisms for weight updating through chaos stimulation and it identifies causal weights that generate misclassifications. The network that undergoes pruning achieves its performance level with no reduction in explainability.

title: Harnessing Machine Learning For Real-Time Yoga Pose Detection
authors: Hareesh B, Akhila S Nayak, Gururaja S, Murari B K, Jayashree M, Nishmitha J
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Yoga is an ancient Indian system, is progressively becoming an integral part of daily life across the world to keep up our mental and body health. However, practicing different Asanas of yoga requires proper and definite knowledge of its postures, as incorrect poses may lead to adverse effects. The proposed work introduces a system that detects yoga pose in real time. It supports independent, affordable yoga practices without expert supervision using computer vision and machine learning techniques. The proposed system uses webcam input to extract 33 body key points through the structure of mediapipe posture assessment. These traits can be categorized into five yoga poses, like downward dog, tree, warrior, plank and goddess pose etc using several controlled teaching methods. Among the assessed classifiers, the Support Vector Machines model reached the highest performance with 98% accuracy prior to Random Forest (97%), Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) (63%), and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) (28%). The SVM model is integrated into a flask based web application and provides real time feedback, user authentication, session monitoring, and personalized progress monitoring. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed system to ensure accurate recognition of posture while maintaining simple deployment, highlighting its potential as a digital wellness tool that provides accessible and personalized experts for yoga support.

title: Design of a High-Isolation MIMO Antenna for 5G N78, WiFi 6E, and Conventional WiFi Bands
authors: Xinru Chen, Peng Zhang, Fengpeng Liu
publish: 2025 8th World Symposium on Communication Engineering (WSCE)
abstract: In response to the demand for high throughput and compact size in 5G and WiFi 6E multi-band terminals, this paper presents the design of a multi-band MIMO antenna operating in the WIFI 2.4G, WIFI 5G, WIFI 6E, and 5G N78 bands. The antenna structure comprises inverted-L elements, parasitic branches, and a ground plane. Through innovative design approaches including optimized inverted-L antenna stub width and parasitic element slotting techniques, the system successfully achieves coverage across four frequency bands while effectively minimizing the overall antenna dimensions. The final 4×4 MIMO antenna system is integrated along the periphery of a standard mobile phone substrate. Simulation results demonstrate that across the WIFI 2.4G, WIFI 5G, WIFI 6E, and 5G N78 bands, the return loss is better than –10 dB, the port isolation is greater than –20 dB, and the envelope correlation coefficient (ECC) is below 0.006. These performance metrics meet the stringent requirements of terminal devices for high isolation, low correlation, and multiband coexistence, thereby providing an effective solution for future terminal antenna design.

title: AI-Driven Drone Swarms Restore Connectivity by Beaming Emergency Power
authors: Haider Mohammed Abbas, Mansurov Isroiljon Gofur Ugli, Karthikayen A, Lalit Sachdeva, D. Aarthi, S.M. Madirimova, P. B. Edwin Prabhakar, Arjun Syam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Power failures and losses of the telecommunication network in disaster-prone areas negatively impact the response time for emergency operations, the provision of medical attention, and the coordination of the improvement unit. The conventional approaches to restoring connectivity, such as ground repair teams and the implementation of backup generators, are slow, resource-intensive, and hindered by access issues in numerous distant locations or places characterised by danger. The above constraints create a strong demand for a rapid adaptation and a swift, technology-oriented solution to bridge the significant gap between infrastructural downtime and complete revival. In resolving this challenge, this paper proposes a novel framework that utilises an AI swarm of uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs) equipped with wireless power beaming technology, enabling the restoration of evanescent energy and real-time connectivity. It incorporates a swarm coordination algorithm, which utilises common forms of reinforcement, allowing drones to autonomously manage flight paths, allocate available power during dynamic changes in priority locations such as communication towers and hospitals, and adapt to changing demands and environmental factors. Wireless power beaming modules ensure that necessary facilities become operable again without the need for direct physical repair. At the same time, swarm intelligence ensures system redundancy and resilience, even in the event of drone failure. Simulation investigations in disaster conditions demonstrate that the proposed solution can decrease recovery time by over 60 per cent compared to traditional solutions, significantly increase power provision efficiency over the medium term, and offer a scalable solution with coverage across multiple facilities simultaneously. The framework ensures that lifelines essential to critical operations are not shut down at the time when they are needed most, just after a disaster, by concentrating on selective recovery to bring essential life support systems back online, in addition to the recovery of the entire grid. The findings indicate that AI-controlled swarms of drones are not only a cost-efficient and scalable solution but also an innovative approach to emergencies, as autonomous aerial systems become the bridge between the destruction of facilities and human survival.

title: Empowering Blind Internet Users: Addressing Communication Self-Efficacy and Digital Barriers
authors: Sanjram Premjit Khanganba, Ritu Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This study examines digital divide faced by blind internet users, emphasizing the gender disparities in shaping the Communication Self-Efficacy (CSE)-the confidence and ability to navigate and engage in online communication and digital platforms. Employing a mixed-methods approach, specifically an explanatory sequential design, the study first gathered quantitative data to identify trends in CSE among blind users, followed by qualitative insights from semi-structured interviews that explore experiences, highlighting the intersection of gender and CSE. This disparity is further explored in the qualitative phase, which uncovers factors contributing to the lower CSE among female blind users, including reduced familiarity with assistive technologies, limited previous internet use, and fewer opportunities for digital literacy training. The findings suggest that female blind users face more significant barriers to developing CSE, causing a gender digital divide. Access, lack of digital literacy programs, and tailored assistive technology training emerge as critical factors influencing CSE, particularly for women. By combining statistical trends with in-depth personal narratives, the study highlights the need for gender-sensitive interventions that support equitable digital inclusion for them.

title: User Friendly Chatbot for DTC Decoding and Troubleshooting
authors: M Prathyusha, Jb Simha, Shinu Abhi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Modern vehicles, with their intricate electronic systems, often present challenges in understanding and troubleshooting Diagnostic Trouble Codes (DTCs). Traditional diagnostic methods, such as consulting extensive manuals or employing specialized tools, can be cumbersome and time-consuming. This paper presents a solution in the form of a locally deployed chatbot that utilizes the Phi-2 Small Language Model (SLM) to interpret DTCs, streamlining the automotive diagnostic process. The chatbot, designed with a focus on user-friendliness and accessibility, simplifies the retrieval and interpretation of diagnostic information, making it a valuable tool for both vehicle owners and technicians. The evaluation results demonstrate the chatbot’s efficacy in handling a diverse range of DTCs and its potential in reducing downtime and costs associated with vehicle diagnostics.

title: The Use of Blockchain to Secure IoT Big Data
authors: Tsvetomir Gospodinov, Ivan Lambov
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has resulted in massive volumes of heterogeneous data that are valuable for analytics, prediction, and decision-making. However, the decentralized and resource-constrained nature of IoT ecosystems introduces vulnerabilities in data integrity, confidentiality, and trustworthiness. Blockchain technology offers a promising solution by providing decentralized trust, immutability, and tamper-resistant storage. This paper investigates the use of blockchain for securing IoT big data pipelines. An experimental architecture integrating IoT sensors, a message broker, a permissioned blockchain, and a big data analytics platform is presented. Results demonstrate that blockchain integration improves data integrity and auditability with minimal performance overhead, while also enabling accountability and trust in large-scale IoT data ecosystems. The paper concludes with a discussion of limitations, opportunities, and directions for future research

title: AI Powered Autonomous Robot for Self-Driving and Delivery
authors: S Vijaya Shetty, Vinayak R Krishnan, Sudesh Gadi, K A Abhijith, Siddharth S Edavi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This paper outlines the development of an AIpowered autonomous vehicle using a cost-effective combination of Raspberry Pi and Arduino for intelligent navigation and decision-making. The system integrates computer vision, machine learning, and sensor data to navigate diverse environments autonomously. A Raspberry Pi functions as the central processing unit, overseeing motor control and processing video feeds transmitted to a laptop via socket streaming. The laptop uses a custom-trained You Only Look Once Version 11 (YOLOv11) machine-learning model for real- time traffic signal detection and classification, enabling the vehicle to recognize and respond to traffic lights with high precision and recall (0.976 and 0.961, respectively). Additionally, ultrasonic and infrared sensors are used for obstacle detection, ensuring safe navigation. The vehicle demonstrated robust performance during testing, achieving a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 0.95 for Intersection Over Union (IoU) at 50% and strong detection accuracy across multiple traffic signal classes. The modular design supports seamless operation in both indoor and outdoor settings, making it suitable for various applications, including autonomous delivery, surveillance, and research. This system highlights the potential for integrating computer vision, embedded systems, and machine learning to create scalable and efficient autonomous solutions, addressing critical societal needs like safety, reduced labor dependency, and improved operational efficiency.

title: Research Software Engineering: Introducing a New Computing in Science & Engineering Department
authors: Anna-Lena Lamprecht, Miranda R. Mundt
publish: Computing in Science & Engineering
abstract: This article introduces the new Research Software Engineering (RSEng) department at Computing in Science & Engineering. Through a conversation with the department coeditors, we highlight why RSEng matters, how it differs from industrial software engineering, what it means to be an RSE, and the scholarly and practical questions that lie ahead. Along the way, we draw on emerging literature, case studies, and community perspectives to frame the profession and practice of RSEng within computational science and engineering.

title: Modeling the Spread of Pollutants in the Lower Layers of the Atmosphere
authors: Dmitrii Ivanov, Eugenii Baskakov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This work is devoted to mathematical and analytical modeling of pollutant transport in continuous media, with a primary focus on the atmosphere. The research is motivated by the critical need to understand the spread of contaminants originating from both natural phenomena and human activities, which adversely affect ecosystems.The study aims to develop a comprehensive approach to these processes through mathematical modeling, a key tool for assessing ecosystem health and predicting future trends. The core objectives include deriving theoretical foundations for transport problems, obtaining analytical solutions, and examining specific contaminant dispersion models, notably the Gaussian plume model. Furthermore, the work involves the development of numerical methods for solving transport equations.The central outcome of this research is the development of a dedicated software application, complete with a graphical user interface, for simulating pollutant transfer. This practical tool is designed to enhance the understanding of real-world contaminant movement, providing a valuable asset for environmental analysis and prediction.

title: Automated Guava Fruits Disease Classification using Deep Learning
authors: Prasannahariveeresh Jeyaveerapandian Raji, Rajesh Kannan Meghalingam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: One of the most widely grown fruits, guavas are severely impacted by several diseases that reduce their quality and yield during cultivation. Disease detection is essential for producing higher-quality and more abundant fruit. Early and accurate disease detection is essential for improving fruit production and minimizing economic losses. This research proposes an automated guava disease detection using EfficientNet-B3, a CNN algorithm known for its accuracy and computational efficiency. Two publicly available datasets from Mendeley and Kaggle were used to fit the model. The dataset contains images of six guava diseases named Red Rust, Phytophthora, Stylar End Rot, Anthracnose, Scab, and Fruit Fly as well as healthy guavas. Several image preprocessing was to improve the model generalization. In this paper, EfficientNet-B3 model achieved a classification accuracy of $99 \%$. Additionally, Precision, Recall, and F1 Score were used to validate the model’s performance across different disease categories. Comparing manual disease inspection, this automated system reduces human effort, enhances diagnostic accuracy, and can be deployed in real-world agricultural applications, including smartphone-based disease detection tools and precision farming solutions. Future work will explore model optimization for edge devices and real-time disease monitoring to further improve scalability and accessibility.

title: Development and Research of a Nanocomposite Based on Anaerobic Sealant for Restoring Rolling Bearing Fits
authors: Anton Vladimirovich Butin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This article presents the results of research aimed at improving the durability of rolling bearing fits in vehicle components. The work is important because of the need to reduce repair and maintenance costs by restoring worn parts. A promising solution is the use of a polymer nanocomposite based on anaerobic sealant AN-111, modified with aluminum and copper nanoparticles (NPs). A set of experimental studies was conducted, including the investigation of deformation-strength properties, polymerization kinetics, thermal conductivity, heat resistance, and the durability of restored joints. The optimal nanocomposite composition was determined, providing a significant improvement in performance characteristics compared to the original sealant. A restoration technology was developed and implemented, showing high technical and economic efficiency.

title: Digital Twin Driven Paradigm Shift in Visual Communication Design
authors: QingQiao Zhang, XiaoJing Li, CongNa Lv
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Modern Education and Information Management (ICMEIM)
abstract: This paper proposes a digital twin paradigm for visual communication education. We build a four layer system spanning artifact, process, context, and learner, with computable indicators for alignment, balance, hierarchy, color difference conformity, and readability, and a unified fidelity measure that enforces digital and physical consistency. On this basis we introduce VisTwin-CLS, a curriculum aware gap driven scheduler with short horizon lookahead under resource and fidelity constraints. In reproducible simulations, learning gains and artifact quality increase, fidelity improves, and time cost decreases. We also provide a deployment blueprint and reproducibility materials for studio adoption.

title: Development Of A Web-Based Employee Attendance Application With Gamification And GPS Technology To Improve Attendance Discipline
authors: Khalisha Fitriyani, Heri Purwanto, Edi Andiansyah, Khaerul Manaf, Hanhan Hanafiah Solihin, Djoko Pitoyo
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: This research was carried out to design and develop a web-based attendance system that combines GPS location verification with elements of gamification as a way to strengthen employee discipline and motivation. The application allows attendance to be recorded only when the user is within a valid GPS range, while features such as points, badges, and leaderboards are used to reward punctuality and consistency. The system was tested using the black box method, and all functions worked correctly during the trials. In addition, user feedback was gathered through a questionnaire using a 1–5 Likert scale to evaluate several aspects, including interface usability, the ease of login and attendance submission, clarity of displayed information, and overall system response. The results showed an average score of 4.69, which falls into the "very good" category. Among respondents, 88% agreed that the interface was easy to use, another 88% found the attendance process smooth, 94% felt the information displayed was clear, and 88% stated that the system responded quickly. From these results, it can be concluded that the application performs effectively and is positively received by its users. In practice, it provides a reliable and modern approach to attendance management while also supporting higher employee engagement and consistency in daily work routines.

title: Impact of Defected Ground Structures on Microstrip Bandpass Filters for 5G/6G Applications
authors: Sergiu Andreica, Calin Munteanu, Marian Gliga, Claudia Constantinescu, Claudia Pacurar, Adina Giurgiuman
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This study presents the design and comparative analysis of microstrip bandpass filters employing intact and defected ground structures (DGS) for operation at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 G H z}, \mathbf{1 0}$</tex> GHz, and 12 GHz. A scale-and-tune methodology was applied to a square resonator topology, combining electromagnetic optimization in ANSYS HFSS with experimental calibration using a vector network analyzer. Prototypes were fabricated on FR-4, RT/Duroid 5880, and Rogers RO3210 substrates, each realized in parallel with intact and defected ground planes. Measured results confirmed the simulations, showing that DGS introduces additional transmission zeros, enhances stopband attenuation by up to 30 dB, and improves selectivity with limited insertion loss penalty. Substrate properties were found to significantly influence matching, bandwidth, and quality factor, while maintaining mechanical stability above 12 GHz. The outcomes demonstrate that integrating DGS into microstrip filters provides a cost-effective strategy for miniaturization and performance enhancement, ensuring suitability for compact RF front ends in emerging 5G/6G wireless communication systems.

title: Governance of AI and Agentic Systems: Challenges and Methodologies
authors: Milena Kumurdjieva, Lyubka Doukovska, Nehla Ghouaiel, Ahmad Dhanani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: The accelerating advancement of artificial intelligence (AI), coupled with the rise of agentic systems, is reshaping the landscape of opportunity and risk for both organizations and society at large. While AI governance frameworks have evolved to address ethical, legal, and operational challenges, existing models often fall short in managing the autonomy, adaptability, and emergent behaviors of agentic AI. This paper examines the limitations of current governance approaches and introduces comprehensive frameworks tailored to both traditional and agentic AI systems. Our proposed models integrate principles of transparency, accountability, security, and resilience across the AI lifecycle, emphasizing proactive risk management, stakeholder engagement, and normative governance. By aligning technical safeguards with ethical imperatives, the frameworks aim to foster trust, mitigate systemic risks, and ensure responsible innovation.

title: Microcontroller-Based Adaptive Smart Home System for Energy Efficiency and User Comfort
authors: Sudipto Pramanik, Moytri Ghosal, Sandipa Chowdhury, Protoye Kumar Mohanta, Sadia Tasnim, Sagira Zaman Eva
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Most smart home automation systems offer advanced features but remain expensive, complex, or narrow in focus. This paper introduces a cost-effective microcontrollerbased smart home system that integrates lighting, fan, and airconditioning control into a unified platform. By leveraging realtime sensor data and user input, the system dynamically adjusts appliances to balance comfort with energy savings. Unlike solutions requiring cloud connectivity or complex AI frameworks, the proposed approach uses a standalone Arduino-based controller and simple control logic to achieve intelligent automation. This simplicity allows significant energy savings-reducing lighting and HVAC power consumption comparable to more complex AI-driven systems yet attainable with low-cost, readily available components. The novelty of the system lies in its holistic integration of multi-appliance control under a single microcontroller with adaptive, user-centric operation. The proposed system has significant implications for resource-constrained regions by enabling affordable, sustainable automation that reduces electricity costs and improves user comfort without the need for expensive infrastructure. The result is a scalable and practical smart home solution that advances accessibility, sustainability, and comfort.

title: Neural Architecture Search via Tournament Learning Competitive Swarm Optimization and GNN-Predictor
authors: Zhexuan Su, Liangliang Zhang, Yamin Han, Lin Wang, Bo Yang, Yonghui Jin
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Neural Architecture Search (NAS) has emerged as a promising approach for the automated design of deep neural networks. However, the high computational cost of training candidate architectures greatly limits the efficiency of conventional approaches. This paper proposes GLC-NAS, a novel NAS method that employs Tournament Learning Competitive Swarm Optimization (TLCSO) with a Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based surrogate model. Within GLCNAS, a TLCSO method is proposed to improve optimization performance by incorporating tournament selection, local search, elitism strategies, and competition-driven learning. In addition, to mitigate the need for extensive training and alleviate computational bottlenecks, a GNN predictor is employed as an evaluation module during the TLCSO search process, thereby enabling efficient and reliable performance estimation for candidate architectures. The experimental results in the CIFAR-10 dataset demonstrate that GLCNAS reduces search time from several days to only minutes. GLC-NAS achieves faster convergence and identifies superior architectures, providing an efficient and practical solution for the design of automated neural architectures.

title: Real-Time Error Classification in 3D Printing Using MobileNetV3 and Edge Device Integration
authors: Appu Chalawadi, Chinmay C Kamadolli, Shrilakshmi A Shetty, Vaishnavi Mahantesh Karale, Shivaprasad Mukhandmath, Dr Uday Kulkarni
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: This project introduces a lightweight, real-time system for detecting errors in 3D printing using the MobileNetV3 architecture. The model is trained to assess crucial printing parameters such as flow rate, lateral speed, Z offset, and hotend temperature, categorizing each as low, optimal, or high. To support on-device processing, the system is deployed on a Raspberry Pi 5, allowing efficient local inference without relying on cloud services or expensive hardware. This makes the solution ideal for compact and cost-sensitive 3D printing environments. By leveraging a compact neural network on accessible hardware, the system promotes energy-efficient and reliable additive manufacturing. It helps prevent common printing issues, reduces material wastage, and enhances overall output quality. Experimental results show that the optimized model improves classification accuracy by 7% compared to conventional methods. Furthermore, real-time performance on Raspberry Pi 5 confirms its effectiveness for practical, low-power edge deployment in 3D printing applications.

title: AI-Based Accident and Crime Detection System: A Smart Surveillance Approach
authors: Saakshi J Shetty, Keerthi Shetty
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The inability of contemporary metropolitan areas to respond promptly to crimes and traffic accidents may lead to fatalities and threats to public safety. This study proposes an AIpowered real-time surveillance setup that utilizes computer vision and deep learning techniques, specifically YOLOv5, to detect accidents and criminal activity from live video feeds. Trained on classified datasets, the system has a 91 percent accuracy rate in detecting accidents, an 85 percent accuracy rate in detecting theft, and an 80 percent accuracy rate in detecting violent incidents. By giving law enforcement and medical personnel automated notifications, it enhances emergency response. The proposed technology is scalable and could be used in smart cities.

title: Machine Learning-Based Analysis of Celestial Objects Using the SDSS17 Dataset
authors: Florin Octavian Robu, Dan Munteanu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: This study explores the application of machine learning (ML) techniques on the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) Data Release 17 dataset, for the classification, regression and clustering of celestial objects, including stars, galaxies and quasars, using spectral features, redshift and position coordinates. Using Python and libraries such as scikit-learn, LightGBM and XGBoost, the research applies the classification algorithm (Logistic Regression, k-Nearest Neighbors, Random Forest), regression (Multiple Linear Regression, Polynomial Regression, LightGBM) and clustering (K-means, DBSCAN) on this data. The results indicate a maximum accuracy of 0.9796 in the classification with Random Forest, obtained by integrating all features, and a coefficient of determination of 0.4328 in the regression with k-NN, highlighting the combined contribution of the data. In clustering, K-means achieved a silhouette score of 0.6692 per redshift, reflecting the ability of distance-based separation. The study highlights the potential of SDSS17 as an "open science" resource for the practical application of artificial intelligence in astronomy. The conclusions confirm the effectiveness of nonlinear methods in cosmic data analysis and the essential role of open access to data in advancing research.

title: An Improved U-Net Model for Precipitation Nowcast Based on Weather Radar Data
authors: Zhan Zhang, Qingping Song, Juan Huo, Congzheng Han, Wenying He
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The U-Net model adopts a symmetric encoderdecoder U-shaped architecture, consisting of three main components: the encoder, the decoder, and skip connections. Due to its simplicity and effectiveness, U-Net performs well with small sample datasets and has been widely used in medical image segmentation, gradually expanding to other domains such as remote sensing and autonomous driving. Inspired by Residual Networks (ResNet) and the Convolutional Block Attention Mechanism (CBAM), this study proposes an improved version of U-Net, called RA-UNet, which incorporates temporal residual convolutions and attention modules to enhance radar data extrapolation accuracy for precipitation nowcast. Using radar data with a 6-minute temporal resolution from China, the RA-UNet model was developed, tested, and validated. Experimental results show that RA-UNet achieves higher prediction accuracy and stability across multiple key metrics than the U-Net, demonstrating its advantages in the precipitation nowcast based on radar data.

title: TFMana: A Traffic Feature Calibration Method to Empower Reliable Network Traffic Analysis
authors: Zhengpeng Li, Shuang Zhao, Shuhui Chen, Fei Wang, Biying Wang, Minxin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: In recent years, network traffic analysis solutions that are driven by artificial intelligence models have achieved impressive performance. The “magic spells” of these solutions come from the knowledge that they learn from large amounts of network traffic data. However, these solutions neglect the impact of the real-world network's complexity on data quality, which makes the knowledge they learn from regular network traffic data difficult to be effective on low-quality data. Considering the packet loss in real-world network environments, this paper presents TFMana to calibrate the inaccurate packet length features extracted from incomplete network traffic data. TFMana utilizes an encoder-based masked language model to predict features of lost packets, incorporating network traffic feature embeddings to enhance prediction accuracy. This approach enables the calibrated features to approximate those extracted from loss-free network traffic asymptotically. Comprehensive experiments are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method. The evaluation demonstrates that TFMana's calibration achieves recovery accuracy between 83.94 % and 85.66 %, with minimal sensitivity to packet loss rates. Integrated with four benchmark application identification models, TFMana significantly improves classification accuracy under packet loss conditions. Notably, the analysis models maintains reliable performance even at high packet loss rates of 30 %.

title: Real-Time Emergency Vehicle Detection and Response in AVS
authors: Anamika Pandey, Jansirani.D, Garifullina Alsu Robert Kizi, Muhamed Fallahhusein, D. Bhanu, B Sujatha, M. G. Saydumarov, Rashmi Naveen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Autonomous vehicles changing urban traffic raises challenges for guaranteeing their and EVs’ safety and smooth operations in urgent situations. The SmartAV-RescueSense system is presented here as a multi-sensor and artificial intelligence framework made to help AVs notice and answer to emergency vehicles right away. With the help of its new fusion engine, the system combines microphone signals from different directions and all-around cameras to properly sense sirens and emergency signs, regardless of whether it’s noisy or hard to see. Because of the module, emergency signals are quickly recognized and the system functions well without the need for online storage or processing. Besides, the platform uses the Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) protocol to obtain live warnings from equipped emergency vehicles, allowing AVs to act safely and efficiently. Thanks to its reinforcement learning structure, the dynamic path model directs AVs to give way or change their route in the best way given the situation and the urban environment. The approach also makes use of mapped priority regions over time to anticipate the route of an emergency vehicle in a busy city grid. Simulations of many different emergencies at the same time confirm that the system works well and responds promptly. It shows that this method represents considerable advantages in accuracy, time for response, and safety over older technologies. thanks to this research, urban traffic safety is increasing and these cars can live side by side smoothly. Those trying to improve these systems will increasingly focus on significant, real-life experiments and fitting them into city infrastructure.

title: Using Deep Learning to Estimate Vegetation Growth from Remote Sensing Data
authors: Hiyam Debary, Levente Klein
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Satellite observations offers a consistent and global spatial coverage in multiple spectral bands. These imagery can detect the reflected light from land cover classes and was successfully used to detect forest or grassland land cover. In combination with LiDAR measurement, the vertical dimension of vegetation can be assessed. With the emergence of deep learning based AI models, fusing LiDAR and satellite observation can be used to assess canopy height or above ground biomass. One challenge is a consistent calculation of the year-to-year growth of biomass using state of the art AI models. Current verification techniques are either Flux Tower measurements or using multiyear LiDAR measurements covering the same area. We demonstrate that deep learning methods can successfully estimate vegetation growth.

title: ACDKAN: An Advanced Cognitive Diagnosis Model for Foreign Language Education
authors: Qiongqing Liu, Hongbin Zhu, Chunlin Li, Meijia Huang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: A primary objective in intelligent foreign language education systems is to predict students' performance on exercises, with a focus on exploring their proficiency in specific knowledge concepts. Traditional cognitive diagnostic models usually analyze the linear relationship between students and exercises by manually designing functions, but this approach is difficult to adequately capture the rich content closely related to foreign language exercises. To address this problem, this paper proposes a generalized cognitive diagnosis model called the Attention Cognitive Diagnosis Kolmogorov-Arnold Net (ACDKAN). This model incorporates advanced modules from the field of machine vision. It extends the Multidimensional Item Response Theory (MIRT) to ensure the interpretability of factor vectors and to effectively explore the semantic information within foreign language exercises. By studying the precedence relations between knowledge concepts, ACDKAN reveals the complexity of targeted knowledge concepts and enhances the learning ability of exercise feature vectors. Experimental results based on real foreign language exercises datasets show that ACDKAN model proposed in the paper outperforms other advanced cognitive diagnostic methods.

title: MagTapeDB: A Dataset of Historical Magnetic Tape Recordings
authors: Ignacio Irigaray, Emilio Martinez, Diego Silvera Coeff, Luiz W. P. Biscainho
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: We present a novel dataset designed to support the development and evaluation of audio restoration techniques focused on historical music recordings. The dataset comprises over 800 audio excerpts, including musicological tape recordings, isolated tape hiss segments, and pitchpipe tones used as tuning references. Each fragment is annotated with metadata such as instrument presence, year of recording, and tape reel number. The dataset enables a variety of restoration-related tasks, including denoising, noise profiling, instrument detection, and segmentation. We also provide baseline results for denoising using state-of-the-art deep learning models and demonstrate an application for playback speed correction using Electrical Network Frequency (ENF) analysis. Our goal is to contribute to the preservation of audio heritage by facilitating reproducible research and benchmarking in music restoration.

title: Blockchain Transaction Graph Analysis Using Image Processing Techniques
authors: Miklós Sipos, Sándor Szénási
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Blockchain technologies generate large-scale transaction data that can be modeled as complex directed graphs. Traditional analysis methods focus on topological and statistical properties of these graphs, but recent advances in computer vision provide new avenues for structural recognition. This paper presents a system for visualizing Bitcoin transaction graphs and analyzing them through image comparison techniques. Using modular JavaScript tools, the system parses transaction data, generates address-level graphs, renders them as images, and applies pixel-based similarity metrics to identify structural patterns. The evaluation shows that visually similar transaction types yield high similarity scores, while outliers are effectively distinguished. The results support the viability of image-based graph analysis as a supplementary method for blockchain transaction monitoring and anomaly detection.

title: A Comparative Analysis of IP-Based and Non-IP-Based Network Architectures: Technical Characteristics, Advantages, Limitations, and Prospects
authors: Pavel Dzhunev
publish: 2025 33rd National Conference with International Participation (TELECOM)
abstract: The purpose of this scientific report is to systematically compare traditional IP-based network architectures with emerging non-IP approaches, such as Information-Centric Networking (ICN), by evaluating their technical characteristics, advantages, limitations, and prospects regarding scalability, security, and efficiency. The results indicate that while IP-based architectures remain dominant due to their ubiquity and stability, they face growing challenges in areas such as Internet of Things (IoT) scalability, mobility, and security. Non-IP architectures, particularly ICN/NDN, offer built-in security mechanisms, efficient content distribution, and enhanced mobility support, yet they face significant challenges related to compatibility and ecosystem maturity. The comparative analysis emphasizes that the future of networking will likely involve hybrid models and the gradual adoption of non-IP paradigms in niche domains before broader acceptance.

title: The Use Of Augmented Reality In The Digital Transformation Of Early Childhood Education
authors: Abdul Alpariji, Heri Purwanto, Beki Subaeki, Suharjanta Wisnu Pitara, Raden Muhammad Adrian Septiandry, Peti Savitri
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Digital transformation in education encourages the use of innovative technologies such as Augmented Reality (AR) to improve the quality of learning, especially in Early Childhood Education. This study aims to develop an interactive and child-friendly AR-based learning application that covers basic introductory material and engaging and adaptive educational games tailored to the characteristics of early childhood learners. The development method used is Extreme Programming (XP), which consists of planning, design, coding, and testing stages. Data collection was conducted through interviews with PAUD teachers and literature reviews. The application was evaluated through functional testing and the distribution of questionnaires to teachers and parents. The research results indicate that the application functions well technically and has received positive feedback. The questionnaire results showed a usability score of 82.5%, learning feature effectiveness of 80.8%, and visual-audio appeal of 79.2%. Teachers also stated that the application enriched their teaching methods and increased children's engagement in the learning process. In conclusion, this AR application successfully supports the digital transformation of learning in early childhood education by providing interactive, educational media that is tailored to children's needs. Further research is recommended to improve the quality of educational games and develop a desktop version of the application.

title: Physics-Informed Operator Learning for Hemodynamic Modeling
authors: Ryan Chappell, Chayan Banerjee, Kien Nguyen, Clinton Fookes
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Accurate modeling of personalized cardiovascular dynamics is crucial for non-invasive monitoring and therapy planning. State-of-the-art physics-informed neural network (PINN) approaches employ deep, multi-branch architectures with adversarial or contrastive objectives to enforce partial differential equation constraints. While effective, these enhancements introduce significant training and implementation complexity, limiting scalability and practical deployment. We investigate physicsinformed neural operator learning models as efficient supervisory signals for training simplified architectures through knowledge distillation. Our approach pre-trains a physics-informed DeepONet (PI-DeepONet) on high-fidelity cuffless blood pressure recordings to learn operator mappings from raw wearable waveforms to beat-to-beat pressure signals under embedded physics constraints. This pre-trained operator serves as a frozen supervisor in a lightweight knowledge-distillation pipeline, guiding streamlined base models that eliminate complex adversarial and contrastive learning components while maintaining performance. We characterize the role of physics-informed regularization in operator learning and demonstrate its effectiveness for supervisory guidance. Through extensive experiments, our operatorsupervised approach achieves performance parity with complex baselines (correlation: 0.766 vs. 0.770, RMSE: 4.452 vs. 4.501), while dramatically reducing architectural complexity from eight critical hyperparameters to a single regularization coefficient and decreasing training overhead by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 \%}$</tex>. Our results demonstrate that operator-based supervision effectively replaces intricate multi-component training strategies, offering a more scalable and interpretable approach to physiological modeling with reduced implementation burden.

title: Nonlinear Prestack Inversion Using Black-Winged Kite Particle Filter Algorithm Based on Bayesian Theory
authors: Bangbang Gao, Lingqian Wang, Bo Yu, Tong Xia, Hui Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Prestack seismic inversion, as a quantitative interpretation method, can integrate multiple information under Bayesian theory framework to obtain the posterior probability density functions of elastic parameters for reservoir prediction. Particle filtering (PF) algorithm is a popular method for solving nonlinear and non-Gaussian problems, and can achieve promising results in prestack inversion. However, in traditional PF algorithms, even with the introduction of various resampling methods, the problem of particle impoverishment still exists, leading to inaccurate inversion results. To solve this problem, in this paper, the black-winged kite algorithm is used to replace the resampling process, and a black-winged kite particle filtering algorithm nonlinear prestack inversion method is proposed. This method overcomes the particle impoverishment problem and improves the inversion accuracy. We test the performance of our proposed method from both synthetic noisy data and a real dataset. Moreover, comparison with the whale optimization particle filter method shows that our proposed method can achieve higher inversion accuracy of elastic parameters.

title: From Metric Learning to Future Representation Learning: Challenges, Advances, and Opportunities : Plenary Talk
authors: Gábor Kertész
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: In recent years, deep metric learning and contrastive learning have become essential approaches to represent similarity and difference using neural networks. By comparing pairs or triplets of examples, these methods construct embedding spaces that are the foundation of modern computer vision, natural language processing, and multimodal systems. Yet, while they have enabled breakthroughs in object re-identification and face verification, fundamental challenges remain: efficient negative sampling, robust training stability, and generalization across domains.In this talk, I will provide a brief overview of the evolution of metric and contrastive learning, from early Siamese and triplet architectures to recent developments in loss functions and sampling strategies. Building on these foundations, I will highlight the current research frontier, beyond pairwise comparisons toward self-supervised representation learning.

title: Decentralized Event-Sampled Control of Multi-Unit Power Systems via Adaptive Dynamic Programming
authors: Xiong Yang, Jianling Meng, Shumei Zhang, Leijiao Ge
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This article presents a decentralized dynamic event-sampled control (ESC) strategy for multi-unit power systems (MUPSs) subject to mismatched interconnections. Initially, with the introduction of a dynamic event-sampling mechanism, the decentralized ESC problem of MUPSs is converted into a set of event-sampled optimal control problems of auxiliary subsystems. It is demonstrated that all the solutions of the event-sampled Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations (ES-HJBEs) arising in these optimal control problems together constitute the decentralized dynamic ESC law. Then, in order to solve the ES-HJBEs, the critic neural networks (CNNs) within the adaptive dynamic programming framework are constructed. The CNNs’ weights are updated via simultaneously using the gradient descent method and concurrent learning. The benefits of such a tuning rule are that it not only makes full use of state data (including historical and instantaneous state data) but also no longer requires the persistence of excitation condition. Moreover, uniform ultimate boundedness of the closed-loop auxiliary subsystem states and the CNNs’ weight estimation errors are proved via Lyapunov approach. Finally, simulations of a three-unit power system are given to validate the present decentralized dynamic ESC scheme.

title: Multi-granularity Feature Fusion Network integrating ASC for SAR Target Recognition
authors: Haohao Ren, Shuyi Liang, Lei Miao, Qiuyan Huang, Youxin Lv
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Deep learning has achieved remarkable progress in synthetic aperture radar automatic target recognition (SAR ATR). However, data-driven methods suffer from spurious correlations that conflate target attributes with confounding factors limiting generalization and robustness in complex conditions. The attribute scattering center (ASC) model, which can map SAR data to physically interpretable features, offers insights for addressing the aforementioned problem. Therefore, this article proposes a multi-granularity feature fusion network (MgFFNet) leveraging ASC to realize robust and interpretable target recognition in complex scenarios. First, we extract multi-granularity scattering features based on ASC model including scattering points feature and component feature. On this basis, we develop a multi-granularity deep feature embedding module that leverages scattering features to hierarchically guide vision features toward causally interpretable representations. Finally, we propose a multi-granularity feature fusion module to achieve different features aggregation, so as to facilitate target identity decision making. Evaluation experiments on two publicly released datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach surpasses numerous advanced SAR ATR methods.

title: Minimizing Age-of-Information in Heterogeneous Multi-Channel Systems: A New Partial-Index Approach
authors: Yihan Zou, Sixiang Zhou, Kwang Taik Kim, Xiaojun Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: We study how to schedule data sources in a wireless time-sensitive information system with multiple heterogeneous and unreliable channels to minimize the total expected Age-of-Information (AoI). Although one could formulate this problem as a discrete-time Markov Decision Process (MDP), such an approach suffers from the curse of dimensionality and lack of insights. For single-channel systems, prior studies have developed lower-complexity solutions based on the Whittle index. However, Whittle index has not been studied for systems with multiple heterogeneous channels, mainly because indexability is not well defined when there are multiple dual cost values, one for each channel. To overcome this difficulty, we introduce new notions of partial indexability and partial index, which are defined with respect to one channel’s cost, given all other channels’ costs. We then combine the ideas of partial indices and max-weight matching to develop a Sum Weighted Index Matching (SWIM) policy, which iteratively updates the dual costs and partial indices. The proposed policy is shown to be asymptotically optimal in minimizing the total expected AoI, under a technical condition on a global attractor property. We also propose an interpolation-based algorithm to quickly compute (approximate) partial indices in real time. Extensive performance simulations demonstrate that the proposed policy offers significant gains over conventional approaches by achieving a near-optimal AoI. Further, the notion of partial index is of independent interest and could be useful for other problems with multiple heterogeneous resources.

title: Parasitic Capacitance Extraction Strategy for Complementary FET in Standard Cells Based on Analytical Model
authors: Rongzheng Ding, Sikai Wang, Huawei Tang, Yusi Zhao, Zhongshan Xu, Xiaona Zhu, Shaofeng Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: Complementary FET (CFET) technology is attracting widespread interest as one of the most promising scaling boosters. The additional interconnect layer required for the bottom device in CFET results in a more complex distribution of parasitic capacitance. In this article, we propose a strategy to extract the parasitic capacitance of CFET in standard cell (SDC). Considering the unique multilayer structure of CFET and the practical requirements for circuit design, the interconnections between gates can be categorized into five distinct configurations. Each configuration is further divided into three styles. The capacitance associated with the fixed-style part remains unchanged regardless of design variations and should be included in the compact model of the transistor. Each style is modeled using analytical approaches. For the first time, we evaluate the parasitic capacitance between the interconnections of PFET and NFET in CFET. The comparison between the model and numerical field solver simulation results, along with the transient simulation results obtained by applying the proposed strategy to circuits, comprehensively validates both the feasibility of the strategy and the accuracy of the model.

title: Hybrid Quantum-Inspired Optimization for AIGC-Driven IoT Task Offloading in MEC Networks
authors: Wenrui Zhang, Changshi Zhou, Weiqi Liu, Tao Han, Nirwan Ansari
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: The rapid evolution of 6G networks and AI-generated content (AIGC) is reshaping service provisioning at the wireless edge, where low-latency and computation-intensive tasks must be efficiently supported. Integrating AIGC with 6G Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystems offers significant benefits, enabling real-time analytics, IoT data augmentation and synthesis, personalized services, and intelligent resource coordination across heterogeneous devices. However, provisioning AIGC services at the mobile edge poses formidable challenges: massive data heterogeneity, stringent delay requirements, and the inherent limitations of learning-based offloading methods, such as high training cost, unstable convergence, and weak transparency. Inspired by the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA), we propose a hybrid optimization framework that combines classical wireless bandwidth pre-allocation for IoT devices connected to mobile edge computing (MEC) servers with Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO)-based AIGC server selection. This hybrid classical-quantum design ensures stable results and enables efficient exploration of combinatorial allocation spaces. We further implement the quantum circuits and evaluate the performance of our proposed approach. Simulation results show that our method achieves lower processing latency and greater stability than conventional reinforcement learning and heuristic baselines in small- to medium-scale IoT deployments. While current quantum hardware scalability remains a constraint, the framework points toward a promising pathway for large-scale AIGC offloading as quantum technology matures.

title: A Knowledge Graph and Large Language Model Framework for Customized Manufacturing: A Case Study in Furniture Panel Production
authors: Cunji Zhang, Bingsheng Liu, Xifan Yao, Xuan Jing
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Compared to traditional mass production, customized discrete manufacturing—such as furniture panel production—generates massive, heterogeneous, and highly dynamic data throughout its lifecycle (order processing, process design, manufacturing execution). Storing this complex, interconnected lifecycle data in traditional relational databases suffers from high redundancy, weak relevance, dispersed distribution, and storage limitations. To address this, this paper proposes a generalizable knowledge graph-based method for knowledge modeling and fusion with semi-dynamic update capability in customized manufacturing, demonstrated through a case study in custom furniture panel production. Firstly, three ontology models (process, resource, feature) are constructed to structurally represent multi-source production knowledge, resolving issues of high redundancy and weak semantic associations found in traditional databases. Secondly, a bidirectional KG construction method is proposed, integrating top-down ontology modeling with bottom-up entity mining for effective dynamic knowledge integration. Thirdly, a graph embedding-based multi-dimensional knowledge fusion algorithm is designed, combined with order-based Knowledge Graph Fragment (KGF) models, to enable semantic association and reasoning of knowledge nodes across processes. A case study in a furniture factory validated the method, building a KG from the ontology models, confirming the fusion method's effectiveness in significantly improving production knowledge manageability and application efficiency. Furthermore, to overcome limitations (e.g., insufficient intent recognition, generalization) of pure knowledge graph-based QA systems, the constructed knowledge graph was integrated with the DeepSeek Large Language Model (LLM). This integration employs ontology-driven prompting and leverages the LoRA lightweight fine-tuning of the DeepSeek-LLM-7B-Chat. This KG–LLM fusion approach for customized manufacturing QA generates more domain-specific and professional responses than methods using solely LLM or KG. The proposed framework provides effective support for intelligent decision-making and optimization in mass-customization production environments, with validated efficacy in the furniture domain.

title: Cross-City Correlation Learning for Traffic Forecasting
authors: Zhiyuan Deng, Zhe Wu, Li Su, Xinfeng Zhang, Yaowei Wang, Qingming Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Traffic forecasting is essential in city-level applications, where data-driven deep learning has become the most popular method. However, sufficient data in developing cities is not always accessible, posing a challenge for training effective models in scenarios with limited data. Recently, several works have promoted this issue through cross-city knowledge transfer and shown promising performances. However, existing methods can neither distinguish node divergence nor extract functional similarities between cities, which results in suboptimal performance. To overcome the limitations, we propose a Cross-city Correlation Learning (CCL) framework. Firstly, we construct a self-supervised learning model to infer accurate node-to-node and node-to-region cross-city correlations from multiple noisy labels without using any auxiliary information. Then, we achieve spatial knowledge transfer from a transfer-adaptive graph convolution network based on the learned correlations in two aspects: the learnable adjacency matrix and region-specific kernel parameters, which ensure the target models can transfer more and better utilize the knowledge from the source domain. The experiments are conducted on six real-world datasets and fully prove the effectiveness of the proposed framework.
