title: Real-Time, In Situ Measurements for the Dynamic Testing of a Road Bridge
authors: Radu Iuliu Cruciat, Cristian Lucian Ghindea, Andrei Gheorghe Pricopie, Ionut Radu Racanel
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Bridge structures play a critical socio-economic role, as a part of the national or regional transport infrastructure, necessitating rigorous performance evaluations prior to final acceptance and commissioning. Such evaluations commonly involve both static and dynamic regime testing using controlled trial loads. This study presents the methodology and instrumentation implemented for the dynamic testing of a road bridge with reinforced concrete deck. The measurement system, comprising calibrated sensors and data acquisition units, enabled real-time monitoring of structural response under test loads. Procedures for signal processing, data analysis and extraction of key dynamic parameters are described, alongside the criteria applied for interpreting the experimental results. To complement the experimental analysis, a finite element model of the bridge was developed, providing a numerical framework for validation and correlation of the measured dynamic behavior. The integrated approach allows for a comprehensive assessment of the bridge's structural performance and ensures reliability in operational conditions.

title: Further Evidence for the Organizing Role of the Plasmapause in the Nightside Distribution of Pc1/EMIC Waves
authors: Tamás Bozóki, Balázs Heilig
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: In a recently published paper, we investigated the spatial distribution of Pc1/EMIC waves in the topside ionosphere based on the high-frequency (HF) magnetometer measurements of the ESA Swarm A satellite, and showed that the appearance of these waves closely follows the variations in the plasmapause (PP) location. In the present contribution, we complement our results by incorporating Swarm B and C data into the analysis, as well as data from the year 2024, which included several geomagnetically active periods, such as the much studied Mother’s Day superstorm in May 2024. Hereby, we could increase the robustness and reliability of our earlier results, especially with regard to higher levels of geomagnetic activity.

title: Remote Sensing Image Generation from Text Disription Using Difussion Transformer
authors: Haoming Qin, Junpeng Zhang, Jie Feng, Weitong Zhang, Jue Zhang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Text-generated images have a wide range of applications in the field of remote sensing. Previous work on remote sensing image generation was mainly based on GAN, whereas the excellent performance of the Diffusion model has remained unexplored. In this work, we present RS-DiT, a novel Diffusion Transformer for generating remote sensing images conditioned on text discriptions. The main idea of RS-DIT is to predict the noise to be removed through conditional information in the input noise image, and generate remote sensing images that meet specific needs through diffusion. We use the semantic differences between remote sensing images of different categories and the text description information of a single image as conditional input, so that the generated images can achieve good results in semantic generalization and accurate description. In order to evaluate the difference between our model and previous GAN and transformer-based methods, we used zero-shot classification, FID, Inception, and clip score to evaluate the authenticity, diversity, and semantic relevance of the generated images. Experimental results demontrate that our method achieves SOTA performance.

title: The Technology for Designing a Logical Database Schema to Support a Business Process Using the EPC Diagram
authors: V.P. Khranilov, P.V. Misevich, P.S. Kulyasov, E.N. Pankratova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The technology for developing the DB schema for supporting a business process is described in this paper. The business process is described by the EPC diagram. A modification of the standard EPC diagram is developed in the article. The elements of the EPC diagram are assigned associative relationships to the values of various measures functions and the elements of the situational description (frames). The technology is based on a database logic diagram template. The template is the structure of the snowflake database. The technology is based on adapting the template to the EPC diagram. The technology maps the business process model into the system of the tables of the template. There is an example for illustrating the process of developing a logical database schema to support a business process in the paper.

title: PSRR Improvement Technique for Super Source Follower Based Voltage Regulators
authors: Vahan Sahakyan, Mariam Bagratunyan, Armen Khalilyan
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: The article presents a new technique for improving the PSRR in a voltage regulator with a PMOS output transistor. The voltage regulator with a PMOS output transistor was designed to support a 2-mA active load. The technique is relevant for modern 14nm and below technology nodes. SPICE analysis performed over the designed circuit showed a worst-case PSRR value as of -35 dB at lower frequencies at wide temperature ranges of -40°C…125°C and supply voltages up to 0.994 V considering the process deviation within ± 4.5 Sigma. Voltage overshoot protection circuit was also developed to ensure safe operation of core devices in various operation modes.

title: Procedural Floor Plan Generation for Simulations: Rooms and Corridors on Demand
authors: Sofia Monteiro, Rui Nóbrega
publish: 2025 International Conference on Graphics and Interaction (ICGI)
abstract: This paper presents an approach to generate interiors of known real buildings using target parameters. This can be useful in simulations in hazard situations, earthquake simulations or architecture, archaeology, engineering and defense contexts. However, modeling this type of complex structure requires a significant amount of time and manual work, especially when it comes to designing and planning the interior according to important parameters, such as room size and ratio. This paper presents a method for procedurally generating interior floor plans, based on buildings extracted from Geographic Information Systems (GIS). This approach subdivides a building into rooms and corridors, parametrized by room area and room ratio, based only on its geometry. This method is designed to adapt to imperfect data with an unspecified orientation. To evaluate this approach, we conducted a user study with 29 participants. The results show that this approach is particularly strong in how it handles imperfect information and manages space and is stronger at generating smaller rooms. This method provides a fast and effective way to generate building interiors, independently of their orientation or the existence of imperfect data, with a focus on the study of shock wave propagation through them.

title: ZKPass – A Zero-Knowledge Proof Based Authentication System for Secure Identity Verification
authors: Srinivas P M, Ruthvik M T, Sanjay UG, Shiva Kumar S, Nishmith, Chandra Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Secure digital identity management is every emerging concern. Traditional authentication which includes use of passwords, central databases, and third party recovery present great security and also usability issues. Zero- Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) and blockchain have put forth as very good for Decentralized identity systems. But also many present solutions have large compute requirements, don’t scale well, and have poor user recovery. This review puts forth that in present ZKP based identity systems we see the lack of password less login, human readable identities, and self sovereign recovery. We look at recent systems which we note have a heavy use of complex crypto credentials, central verification which is a point of failure, and extensive infrastructure which in turn do not see wide scale adoption. To present solutions to these issues we have put forth a UID based identity which uses ZKPs for authentication which does not require storage of passwords or private keys. We introduce a novel recovery which uses a human readable phrase from private key, salt, and UID which in turn is a user controlled method. What we did is we put the UID on the blockchain which in turn improves privacy and scale. Our analysis which we present improves on issues of usability, scale and security which in turn we present a very simple and practical solution for today’s identity management issues. Also this study we present which we put forth to be the base for what we think will be future works in the development of useable ZKP based identity systems.

title: Generative Diffusion Models for Test Pattern Synthesis in VLSI : Enhancing Fault Coverage and Silicon Lifecycle Management
authors: Tanuj Mathur, Mohan Vamsi Musunuru, Naveen Kumar Siripuram, Prabhu Muthusamy, Bhargav Kumar Konidena
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: The challenges of making semiconductor technologies work reliably, in terms of yield, fault-tolerance, have escalated dramatically, due to the rapid scale-down into the nanoscale regime, and these challenges are even more acute in very-large-scale integration (VLSI) systems. Traditional Automatic Test Pattern Generation (ATPG) tools, well known as the backbone of digital verification, are increasingly not keeping up with the stochastic and dynamic fault model of the advanced nodes. The techniques tend to overedit to a priori fault models, like stuck-at or transition fault models, and thus are not very flexible to newer defect patterns. Furthermore, their over-reliance on exhaustive backtracking and deterministic search, inject too much computational overhead and redundant test vectors that weaken efficiency while managing silicon lifecycle (SLM). Enter recent cutting-edge developments in generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) the prospect of probabilistic models learning complicated patterns of defect incidence, and the apparent need to revisit traditional to the world understanding of diffusional phenomena. Of these, diffusion models are notable in the variety and high quality of the samples of data they are able to produce by iteratively removing noise using generative annealing, rendering them useful at preserving distributional diversity yet alleviating mode collapse, one of the more faults of generative adversarial networks (GANs). In this paper, we develop a Generative Diffusion Model (GDM) framework that is automatic test pattern synthesis oriented in nanoscale VLSI systems. Wide-scale data consisting of defect and failure trace data (combined with benchmark circuit data) is used to train fault-aware representations that generalize beyond classical fault models. Incorporating such an approach into an SLM pipeline can enable a model to be adaptively retrained using incremental defect data such that the ultimate relevance is maintained throughout the device life cycle. Experimental results on the ITC-99 benchmark circuits show a 22 percent enhancement in fault coverage over the traditional ATPG and GAN-based synthesis and a 40 percent decrease in run time, and, further, it produces statistically diverse test vectors with no addition of test vectors. The scalability of the approach to medium-to-large circuits is further demonstrated by a detailed case study and demonstrates a greater diversity of fault activation in a circuit with increased robustness. These findings indicate that there would be a paradigm shift of the application of electronic tests strategy and diffusion-driven synthesis stands tall as a viable and dynamic solution to and management of reliable microelectronic devices.

title: Automatic detection of atrial fibrillation based on enhanced CNN-BiLSTM and global grouped coordinate attention
authors: Kai Zhang, Haiying Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: The automatic detection of atrial fibrillation (aFib) through electrocardiogram (ECG) signals is currently an important aspect of timely diagnosis of heart diseases. To this end, we designed a deep learning framework that integrates convolutional neural networks (CNN), bidirectional long - short term memory network (BiLSTM), and global group coordinate attention (GGCA) mechanisms. The main purpose of this model design is to capture both spatial and temporal features in the ECG signals simultaneously. Experimental results show that our model achieved outstanding performance on the MIT - BIH arrhythmia dataset (2017 competition version): it exhibited a significantly higher macro F1 score of 0.914 and a specificity of 0.987, which surpasses the 0.82 macro F1 score of traditional CNN LSTM concatenated hybrid models. Notably, the introduction of the GGCA mechanism significantly enhanced the feature discrimination ability, giving our model the potential for application in real - time cardiac monitoring scenarios.

title: Enzymatic Carbon-Sequestering Bio-Cement: A Bacteria-Driven Approach for Sustainable and Low-Carbon Construction
authors: Ravinder Sharma, Anita Sofia Liz.D.R., Kurbonova Marguba Yuldashevna, Ramee RiadHwsein, R. Sarankumar, Karthikayen A, Zokhira Khidralieva, Keerthi Shetty
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Cement accounts for approximately 8% of total anthropogenic carbon dioxide emissions, and traditional cement production is a major culprit of this. Sustainable alternatives are imperative to lessen the environmental impact of the construction industry so urgently. The invention described herein proposes an innovative enzymatic carbon sequestering bio-cement that utilizes microbial-induced calcite precipitation (MICP) to develop a low-carbon and self-healing cement substitution. Rather than allowing the aggregates to disperse or settle out of suspension, a bioanalytical approach is used, which takes advantage of urease-producing bacteria like Sporosarcina pasteurii for capturing atmospheric CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> through biochemical reactions that precipitate CaCO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> while binding aggregates as well. This process is different from conventional cement, requiring ambient temperature, which reduces energy consumption and lowers emissions. The experimental results show that bio-cements possess similar compressive strength, long service life, and the ability to self-heal micro-cracks, thereby increasing the life span of the infrastructure and reducing maintenance costs. Furthermore, the life cycle assessment shows a huge decrease in the carbon footprint of Portland cement. This means that enzymatic bio cement has the potential to change green construction by providing a scalable, inexpensive, and environmentally friendly replacement for conventional cement. We would identify ways in the future to improve bacterial performance, large-scale implementation, and integration with current multi-part construction practices to rapidly accelerate the adoption of bio cement in public and private implementations.

title: Logic for Bus Interconnect Testing
authors: Vladimir Hahanov, David Devadze, Zaza Davitadze, Svetlana Chumachenko, Eugenia Litvinova, Volodymyr Obrizan
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: Chiplet is the technological and structural architecture of an emerging computer system. It is an architecture that integrates heterogeneous components such as SoC, SiP, multichip, package, silicon die, and CPU. These structural components form the logical architectures: Chiplet GPU, Chiplet Memory, Chiplet I/O, Chiplet Interconnects. For the market, chip-let has a clear advantage over Monolithic Chips, which is determined by the following properties: Improved Yield, Flexibility, Scalability, and Heterogeneous Integration. As part of emerging computing, a Chiplet is just logic, represented by structures and functions, and nothing else. Chiplet Interconnects are no exception – this is also logic. A systematic approach to modeling, simulation, and testing the logic of Chiplet Interconnects, the model of which is represented by a logical vector, is proposed. The basic paradigm is that any logic should be tested systematically against logical faults that are in the good-value model of the structure or functionality, either explicitly or implicitly. Any physical defects in components or bus Interconnects in the Chiplet architecture manifest as logic faults. Defects violate the logic of any computing device, including bus structures. This means that any physical defects manifest themselves as logical faults. This means generating system tests that cover combinations of logic faults. A Modelling test card is offered, which is a logical relationship between a comprehensive test and all combinations of logic faults. A logic vector is all you need to model a Chiplet Interconnects test map in three matrix operations. As well as any structure and functionality, it can be represented by a logical vector for modeling a test map. In addition, a logical vector is also a data structure for graph rendering of the validity of a process or phenomenon model. A logical vector is the simplest model that is convenient for simulating on a computer and rendering the results for a human. Modeling and rendering on the logical vector harmoniously complement each other in solving market problems. Examples and processing time of bus, graph structures, and functionalities for modeling a test map and graph rendering models are given. All mechanisms for modeling and rendering test maps for functions and structures are embedded in the Python language codes, which are exposed in cyberspace as an open-source application.

title: Analysis of L-Band Insar Histograms for Mapping Forest Vertical Structure
authors: Chiara Telli, Marco Lavalle, Gustavo H. X. Shiroma, Nazzareno Pierdicca
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the use of the Histomography technique to map forest vertical structure from interferometric synthetic aperture radar (InSAR) images. This technique uses InSAR histograms that are obtained by mapping each pixel in a SAR interferogram to a particular height bin according to its corresponding interferometric phase. This approach potentially enables the estimation of forest vertical structure, from which surface topography and tree height can be retrieved. In this work, the vertical profiles obtained using the Histomography technique are compared with the LiDAR waveforms to assess strengths and limitations of the method. The SAR dataset is a stack of fully-polarimetric L-band UAVSAR images acquired over the Howland Forest, USA, in summer 2021, while LVIS LiDAR waveforms are considered the reference data. The comparison between the SAR profiles and the LiDAR measurements indicates that Histomography effectively captures the vertical structure of the forest.

title: Prospects for the Implementation of Electric Drive Systems in Tractor Construction: A Case Study of the MTZ-82 Modernization
authors: A.A. Goodskov, R.R. Ibadov, A. E. Cochin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This work analyzes the prospects for modernizing the MTZ-82 tractor by replacing its traditional diesel transmission with an electric drive system. A critical review of the shortcomings of the classic mechanical transmission is presented, highlighting significant energy losses (up to 18-23%), high operational costs, and poor ergonomics. The transition to an electric drive is proposed as a solution. The paper provides a comparative analysis of various electric drive concepts, including direct engine replacement and wheel-hub motors, and justifies the choice of the most balanced scheme — the use of individual axle-specific electric motors with compact gearboxes. Based on detailed calculations of the parameters of the existing MTZ-82 transmission (wheel torque, rotational speed), technical specifications for designing the electric drive system have been developed. Key requirements are defined: a peak motor torque of 300 N•m, a rated power of 120 kW per axle, a gearbox ratio of 140:1, and a high protection class of IP67. The technical and economic analysis demonstrates that the proposed modernization can increase the overall efficiency of the power plant by 25-30% and reduce operational costs by 40-45% due to lower maintenance and fuel expenses. The service life of the system's key components should be at least 20,000 hours for the electric motors. The developed approach preserves the tractor's operational characteristics while significantly improving its energy efficiency and environmental friendliness.

title: Planar Superlattice U-GaN High Electron Mobility Transistor (HEMT)
authors: Vikram Magendar, Hiu Yung Wong
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: Superlattice (SL) GaN high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs) are promising for normally-off operation and potential CMOS integration with both n- and p-type devices. However, usually planar SL HEMTs suffer from limited access region channel utilization, as only one two-dimensional electron/hole gas (2DEG/2DHG) channel in the access region contributes when fabricated. In this work, we propose a planar "SL U-GaN HEMT," where sidewall GaN layers connect the superlattice two-dimensional electron/hole gases, enabling all access-region channels to conduct. Two-dimensional technology computer-aided design (TCAD) simulations confirm normally-off behavior with a threshold voltage of approximately 4 V for the n-type SL U-GaN HEMT. The n-type SL U-GaN HEMT delivers over 3 times higher drain current than the regular SL GaN HEMT, while the p-type variant shows significantly reduced gate leakage. These results demonstrate that the planar SL U-GaN architecture addresses the channel utilization limitation of planar SL GaN HEMTs and provides a path for planar GaN CMOS integration.

title: AWF: Adaptive Weight Fusion for Enhanced Class Incremental Semantic Segmentation
authors: Zechao Sun, Shuying Piao, Haolin Jin, Chang Dong, Lin Yue, Weitong Chen, Luping Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: Class Incremental Semantic Segmentation (CISS) aims to mitigate catastrophic forgetting by maintaining a balance between previously learned and newly introduced knowledge. Existing methods, primarily based on regularization techniques like knowledge distillation, help preserve old knowledge but often face challenges in effectively integrating new knowledge, resulting in limited overall improvement. Endpoints Weight Fusion (EWF) method, while simple, effectively addresses some of these limitations by dynamically fusing the model weights from previous steps with those from the current step, using a fusion parameter alpha determined by the relative number of previously known classes and newly introduced classes. However, the simplicity of the alpha calculation may limit its ability to fully capture the complexities of different task scenarios, potentially leading to suboptimal fusion outcomes. In this paper, we propose an enhanced approach called Adaptive Weight Fusion (AWF), which introduces an alternating training strategy for the fusion parameter, allowing for more flexible and adaptive weight integration. AWF achieves superior performance by better balancing the retention of old knowledge with the learning of new classes, significantly improving results on benchmark CISS tasks compared to the original EWF.

title: Software Architecture Patterns for Real-Time Digital Twin–IoT in Smart Campus Management: A Comparative Study
authors: Erilda Muka, Genta Rexha, Galia Marinova
publish: 2025 33rd National Conference with International Participation (TELECOM)
abstract: Digital Twin technology links physical assets with virtual models to support real-time monitoring, control, and optimization. While prior work often emphasizes conceptual designs or simulations, fewer studies investigate the impact of software architecture on latency, reliability, and scalability in real-world deployments. This paper examines three software patterns: Edge-first, Hybrid, and Cloud-coordinated applied to a prebuilt DT-enabled IoT prototype for smart campus management. The prototype integrates an ESP8266 microcontroller, environmental sensors, and a Unity-based twin to manage HVAC and lighting in a lecture hall. Each pattern was implemented and assessed in terms of end-to-end control latency, synchronization accuracy between physical and digital states, resource efficiency, and operation during network disruptions. In addition, different security mechanisms, from lightweight shared-secret verification to certificate-based authentication, were explored. The study highlights how architectural design choices shape performance, scalability, and secure operation in DT-enabled IoT systems.

title: EEG Channel Selection via h-index-Based Centrality Measures of Complex Networks for Music Genre Classification
authors: Andrés Eduardo Coca Salazar
publish: 2025 15th IEEE International Conference on Pattern Recognition Systems (ICPRS)
abstract: The intrinsic characteristics of music affect the brain by activating specific areas that alter its electrical activity. Understanding this behavior can support relevant applications, but high dimensionality hinders model interpretability, performance, and generalization. Therefore, selecting the most informative channels would reduce complexity, lower computational cost, and potentially improve classification performance. In this paper, we propose an approach to identify the musical genre associated with an acoustic stimulus based on the analysis of electroencephalogram (EEG) signals, aiming to overcome the high dimensionality of the data. To this end, we computed the functional connectivity (graph G) between EEG channels using techniques from various analysis domains, and mined the most representative channels (nodes i). To achieve dimensionality optimization, we propose two centrality measures based on the h-index and degree-strength centrality (DSC) metrics: (1) global ks-index (h<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ks</inf>), and (2) local l<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ks</inf> -index (l<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ks</inf>). High values of h<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ks</inf>(G) helped to select the most representative networks, while the computation of l<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ks</inf>(i) enabled the identification of the most relevant channels. The selected networks and channels were then mined: the former using global topological measures, and the latter using conventional time-series metrics. In the experiments, we varied the number of the most relevant networks and channels, as well as the DSC type, and used five classifiers with repeated k-fold cross-validation. Our best classification accuracy was 60.1%, achieved with one graph, two channels, and an artificial neural network. The results showed that the new indices helped distinguish subtle structural variations between nodes, select the most relevant channels, and surpass the state of the art in the accuracy-channel ratio.

title: Design and Implementation of a CDN Testbed for Performance Evaluation of NGINX-Based Content Distribution
authors: Akbar Febry Wahyu Andrian, Hanif Al Falih, Mohammad Ridwan Effendi, Ian Josef Matheus Edward
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: The rapid growth of internet traffic, dominated by heavy media content, poses significant challenges in terms of latency and operational costs for content providers. While Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) are the standard solution, their performance heavily relies on internal strategies like cache eviction, where conventional algorithms such as Least Recently Used (LRU) are often suboptimal for dynamic user access patterns. Furthermore, much of the advanced research in CDN optimization is validated solely through simulations, creating a gap between theory and reproducible practical implementations. This paper presents the design and implementation of a comprehensive, multi-regional CDN testbed to bridge this gap. The testbed integrates three main subsystems: a server subsystem using Nginx, a monitoring subsystem with Prometheus and Grafana, and a machine learning subsystem for intelligent cache eviction. As a primary validation of its utility, we used the testbed to conduct a comparative analysis of cache eviction policies. Results show that under a realistic Zipf distribution traffic simulation, the machine learning-based Learning from the Experts (LRB) algorithm achieved an average Cache Hit Ratio (CHR) of 90.15%, significantly outperforming the baseline LRU (85.84%). The main contribution of this work is a functional, measurable, and reproducible testbed that not only validates the superiority of an intelligent caching approach but also provides a platform for future CDN optimization research.

title: Improving LoRa Interference Immunity through Modulation Parameter Adaptation
authors: Yurii Karaush, Mykola Patlaienko
publish: 2025 33rd National Conference with International Participation (TELECOM)
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of improving the noise immunity of LoRa wireless technology in conditions of intense interference. To this end, an analysis was conducted of the influence of modulation parameters—bandwidth (BW) and spread factor (SF)—on communication quality indicators, in particular bit error rate (BER) and data transfer rate. It is shown that, with a fixed SF, an increase in bandwidth has virtually no effect on BER, but leads to an increase in transmission speed. By adapting SF together with BW, the required speed can be achieved while maintaining low BER values. The results obtained allow us to formulate recommendations for selecting modulation parameters to ensure reliable data transmission in conditions of deteriorated electromagnetic environment.

title: Intelligent Platform For Comprehensive Analysis And Training Of Computer Vision Models
authors: Olesia Barkovska, Vitalii Serdechnyi, Andriy Kovalenko, Vitalii Martovytskyi, Ihor Novoseltsev
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: The paper presents an intelligent platform for scientific research in the field of computer vision, aimed at comprehensive comparative analysis of the accuracy, performance, and robustness of modern models under variable lighting and weather conditions. The primary objective of the development is to create a scalable system that supports experiments with a wide range of models (YOLOv8– YOLOv11, DETR, Mask R-CNN, SSD, RetinaNet, etc.) using interactive analytics, complete logging, and automated report generation. Unlike conventional testing environments, the proposed platform accounts for the characteristics of images from various application domains. For each scenario, log files are automatically stored with key metrics (mAP@0.5, mAP@0.5:.95, Precision, Recall, F1-score, IoU) and FPS, ensuring a comprehensive evaluation of both accuracy and processing speed. A distinctive practical novelty of the system is the implemented module for studying the impact of video stream preprocessing methods (CLAHE, gamma correction, median filtering, etc.) on object detection accuracy. Experimental results demonstrated, for example, that in low-visibility conditions the combination of Zero-Dce + gamma correction + CLAHE yielded an increase in mAP@0.5 in the range of 4–6%, depending on the model architecture. The platform also provides tools for assessing the effect of CUDA acceleration on the performance of each model. The developed system has undergone validation in a series of experiments, including tasks of adapting computer vision models within hardware-software complexes for assisting visually impaired individuals under limited computational resources, confirming its efficiency and practical applicability in various applied domains

title: Shear Wave Velocity Prediction of Complex Reservoir Based on MambaTab with Conventional Logging Data
authors: Junhao Cheng, Chunxu Zhou, Zitong Zhang, Yichen Liu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: Accurate prediction of shear wave velocity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{s}})$</tex> is crucial for characterizing rock physical properties and identifying hydrocarbon reservoirs. Well logs, as structured tabular data, provide rich features for Vs prediction. However, traditional machine learning models struggle to capture the complex coupling among multi-source logs, while deep learning models often require heavy preprocessing and large parameter scales. This study proposes a Vs prediction method based on MambaTab, which embeds well log features and employs a structured state-space model (SSM) to capture long-range dependencies along depth and nonlinear relationships among features. Experiments on carbonate and volcanic rock datasets show that MambaTab outperforms benchmark models, effectively balancing accuracy and efficiency. This method offers a promising framework for geophysical characterization and reservoir prediction in complex geological settings.

title: Practical Limitations of Digitization Methods in Buck Converter Control
authors: Cornel-Iulian Postolache, Dorin O. Neacșu
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: This paper reviews digitization methods applied to digital control of a voltage-mode DC-DC buck converter, emphasizing practical limitations due to sampling frequency and quantization effects. The performance of digitization techniques (Tustin, Zero-Order Hold, Matched Pole-Zero, and Least Squares) is analyzed through MATLAB/Simulink simulations using realistic parameters derived from the Microchip Buck Converter PICtail™ Plus hardware platform (9 [V] input, 3.3 [V] output, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 5 0}[\text{k H z}]$</tex> switching frequency). Additionally, frequency response-based control, specifically a lead compensation, is employed to enhance the system's transient response and stability margins. The results provide practical insights for selecting suitable digitization methods and compensation strategies, identifying critical trade-offs at reduced sampling rates, and guiding future digital control implementations in power electronics.

title: Development of a Remote Control Interface for a Mobile Robot using ROS and LabVIEW
authors: Vladimir Hristov, Antonia De Amorim
publish: 2025 33rd National Conference with International Participation (TELECOM)
abstract: This paper presents a bidirectional communication interface between LabVIEW and the Robot Operating System (ROS) for real-time teleoperation of a mobile robot. The proposed system enables LabVIEW to function as a ROS node capable of publishing velocity commands and subscribing to sensor data, providing a graphical user interface (GUI) for intuitive robot control. The integration is implemented through TCP/IP communication between a Windows-based LabVIEW client and a Linux-based ROS host. The system was validated in the Gazebo simulator using a Clear path Husky robot model, achieving real-time operation with network latency below 5 ms and smooth trajectory tracking at 10 Hz. The results demonstrate that the developed ROS–LabVIEW interface effectively bridges industrial-grade software with modern robotic frameworks, enabling flexible and user-friendly teleoperation for both simulation and real-world applications.

title: Educational Applications of AI: Supporting ProblemSolving in Informatics
authors: Veronika Gabal’ová, Hana Ingrid Vrtoch Oppenberger, Veronika Stoffová
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: This paper presents the authors’ experiences with integrating artificial intelligence (AI) tools into the educational process, with a particular emphasis on informatics subjects across various educational levels. The study examines informatics education across multiple levels of the educational system, ranging from primary and secondary education to higher education. Particular emphasis is placed on higher education, especially within teacher preparation programs in computer science, focusing on how prospective educators can effectively integrate modern technologies and tools into their instructional activities, develop students’ digital competencies, and support their ability to solve complex problems. AI is taught as a standalone subject at the master’s level of teacher education in computer science; however, it also serves as a supportive tool that enhances students’ problem-solving skills. Rather than providing ready-made solutions, AI guides students, explains reasoning, and facilitates the development of their own knowledge structures. The paper explores practical applications of AI tools in teaching practice, such as lesson planning and accessing up-to-date information relevant to course content. Within the context of computer science didactics, the authors provide examples of classroom activities involving chatbots and discuss how AI can be effectively utilized by both students and educators in self-directed learning. The paper concludes with a summary of general opportunities and challenges associated with the use of AI in education, supported by the authors’ experiences and recommendations for its effective implementation.

title: Unstable Sample based Style Enhancement for Invisible Text Backdoor Attack
authors: Jiahao Qin, Xinghao Yang, Baodi Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Text backdoor attacks bring great risks to the secure deployment of Natural Language Processing (NLP) models, where attackers usually inject a specific trigger to mislead the model. Various of backdoor triggers have been designed, including visible triggers, e.g., directly adding a specific symbols to the end of the sentence, and invisible triggers, e.g., rewriting sentence structure or style. Generally, the invisible triggers are hard to be peceived by both human readers and backdoor defenders, but they also meet two limitations, i.e., the low training efficiency and low attack success rate. To address these challenges, we propose Unstable Sample based Style Enhancement (USSE) for invisible text backdoor attacks. Specifically, we improve training efficiency by prioritizing unstable samples that are more prone to distributional shifts during training iterations, thereby reducing redundant updates and accelerating model convergence. Furthermore, we enhance attack success rates by introducing a style enhancement score that reinforces the consistency and distinctiveness of trigger-specific stylistic features, making them more easily activated during inference. Extensive experiments conducted on four benchmark datasets-SST2, OLID, Ling-Spam, and HSOL-demonstrate that USSE improves training efficiency by more than $30 \%$ compared with random selection methods, while also achieving a $2 \%$ increase in attack success rate.

title: Automation of Qualification Test Data Processing for Hydropower Generating Units
authors: Mihaela Andrei, Narcis-George Alupoaie
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: The qualification of hydropower generating units involves a series of performance and reliability tests whose results must be accurately processed and analyzed to ensure compliance with operational standards. Traditionally, this process is time-consuming and exposed to human error due to the large amount of data recorded during tests. This paper proposes a fully automated solution for data processing and evaluation of qualification tests in hydropower units. The user interaction with the software system is mediated by a minimalist and intuitive interface, designed also in Phyton, to logically guide the operator through the analysis configuration steps. The user can define the precise context of the evaluation by selecting essential parameters. The choice of the test type, whether it is a certification procedure designed to validate compliance with standards or a qualification procedure for assessing operational performance, establishes the regulatory framework and purpose of the analysis. Subsequently, the precise specification of the hydropower unit under test ensures full traceability of the results, and the selection of the particular test to be processed, such as the dynamic response to frequency variations or the behavior during operation. The proposed solution reduces manual intervention, accelerates reporting, and improves result accuracy.

title: Method for Quality Control and the Estimation of Electron Beam Curvature for Particle Accelerator Electromagnets
authors: Victor-Eduard Albei, Marius Popa, Dragos Ovezea, Cristinel Ilie, Nicolae Tanase, Daniel Lipcinski, Romulus-Marian Mihai
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: Our work demonstrates the practical usage of a highly-compatible testing setup in the estimation of the effect that a given dipole electromagnet model has on the properties of an electron beam that is passed through the device's active length. Considering the direction control application of dipole electromagnets within particle accelerators, we will primarily be concerned with determining the rotation transformation that is applied by the dipole's field onto the electron beam's direction vector. In order to achieve this, our work involves fundamental concepts of particle physics and electromagnetism, together with a set of magnetic field measurements performed on the device under test. Our beam deflection computations will involve the assumption that the magnetic field generated by the device is directed along a single dimension of our coordinate system. This assumption is only valid if the dipole electromagnet is correctly positioned in the electron beam's path. In an attempt at solving this issue, our testing setup is used to correctly determine the adjustments that may be performed on the dipole's positioning, relative to its intended mechanical configuration, such that the previously mentioned condition holds. This method has the potential of allowing for the usage of electromagnets that are moderately outside specifications, as long as the field generated by them may be considered uniform in a given aperture. In other words, our work may be used to correct orientation errors in dipole electromagnet manufacturing, without increased costs.

title: Near-field Characterization of Large-Scale mm-wave Massive MIMO Arrays using IDM Computed EM Lagrangian Density
authors: Debdeep Sarkar, Yahia M. M. Antar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: In this paper, use of IDM (infinitesimal dipole model) computed EM Lagrangian density is proposed to characterize the NF (near-field) of large-scale mm-wave MMIMO (massive MIMO) arrays for 6 G applications. As full-wave EM simulation is infeasible for such large-scale MMIMO arrays, the proposed IDM-approach offers an useful time and memoryefficient route for NF analysis, with better accuracy compared to conventional isotropic element based technique. The normalized Poynting vector magnitude and EM Lagrangian density in the NF region are visualized for large-scale ID-based URAs. It is shown that the spatial distribution of normalized EM Lagrangian density plots provide an alternative paradigm as compared to the traditional phase-error criteria to quantify the “Fresnel distance” (boundary between the reactive and radiating NF region) for large-scale MMIMO arrays. The impact of the array-aperture dimension in configuring the distribution of NF reactive energy density is further highlighted through the large-scale ID-URA examples.

title: Assessing the Role of Residential Battery Storage in Enhancing Energy Autonomy and Grid Flexibility
authors: Gurguiatu Gelu, Dușa Alexandru, Coman Gelu, Cristian Iosifescu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: This paper investigates the role of residential battery energy storage systems (BESS) in improving energy autonomy and grid flexibility through theoretical modeling and real-world analysis. Two case studies of hybrid PV–battery systems with distinct management strategies demonstrate that optimized configurations can achieve full self-sufficiency, while undersized ones remain partly dependent on the grid.Building on these results, the study reviews existing sizing approaches—economic (NPV, IRR, BCR), technical (SCR, SSR, efficiency), lifetime-based (SoH), and multi-objective models— and identifies their limitations for residential use. To address these, a simplified sizing framework is proposed, defined by two clear criteria: backup capability for critical loads and self-consumption enhancement through energy shifting.This practical, user-oriented method supports the design of PV-coupled storage systems that enhance resilience, cost efficiency, and renewable integration, while contributing to the development of distributed flexibility solutions.Keywords — residential battery storage, energy autonomy, grid flexibility, ancillary services, renewable integration

title: Research on an Intelligent Evaluation System for Large Language Models via Simulation-Based Training in Vertical Domains
authors: Zejian Fu, Jieying Wei, Tao Chen, Guoqiang Wei, Hongyu Liang, Bingzhao Wei
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: Large model technology represents a critical research direction in deep neural networks. Leveraging the groundbreaking innovations of the Transformer architecture and large-scale parameter optimization, it has demonstrated remarkable capabilities in fields such as natural language processing and data analysis. This paper systematically reviews theories and techniques related to large models in vertical domains. To address challenges in constructing an intelligent evaluation system for large models in simulation training, a dynamic rank adjustment-based LoRA fusion approach is proposed. By integrating simulated training datasets and a knowledge base of evaluation criteria, a Retrieval-Augmented Generation based intelligent evaluation system for simulation training is developed. Experimental results show that the proposed system enhances task transfer capability while ensuring professional rigor.

title: Subspace Decomposition-Based Blind Estimation of OFDM Subcarrier Number
authors: Ruixuan Li, Baoguo Li, Jiulin Zeng, Jiajun Chen
publish: 2025 8th World Symposium on Communication Engineering (WSCE)
abstract: Accurate estimation of the number of subcarriers is a crucial step in blind parameter estimation of Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) signals. This paper proposes a subspace decomposition-based method for estimating the number of subcarriers. The method constructs a virtual array data matrix and performs eigenvalue decomposition on its covariance matrix to achieve subcarrier number estimation. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves higher estimation accuracy under low signal-to-noise ratio conditions compared to traditional techniques. Furthermore, it enables estimation of the actual number of active subcarriers.

title: Phase Estimation Algorithm for Interference-Protected GNSS-Based Direction Finder
authors: Vladimir I. Tsarik, Victor I. Djigan
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: A signal phase estimation algorithm is considered. It is intended to be used in the direction finders, based on the processing of the Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) signals. The algorithm processes output signals of two Adaptive Antenna Arrays (AAAs) which ensure the direction finder operation even in the interference presence scenarios. Details of the phase estimation algorithm are presented. Besides, architecture and adaptive algorithm of the AAAs weights calculation are presented as well. The algorithm is based on the Linearly Constrained Recursive Least Squares approach. It uses the Matrix Inversion Lemma to invert the AAA input signal correlation matrix, which is used for the calculation of the Kalman gain vector which in turn is used for the calculation of the AAA weights. Simulation results demonstrate 0.5°…4° phase estimation accuracy, if the 3-by-3 AAAs are used, the Signal-to-Noise Ratio is –20 dB at the outputs of the AAA channel receivers and the AAAs operate in the presence of 0…8 spatially distributed interfering signals with the Interference-to-Signal Ratio of 90 dB each. The proposed AAA and the phase estimation algorithm are suggested for usage in modern GNSS direction finders.

title: Kubernetes Monitoring Stack on Raspberry Pi Cluster
authors: Milen Hrabarov Todorov
publish: 2025 33rd National Conference with International Participation (TELECOM)
abstract: As the number of machines in clusters and the services they provide grows, the implementation of systems for monitoring and logging is of extreme importance. Not only because it is impossible to manually monitor a complex infrastructure, but also because maintaining and logging aids the optimization, reconfiguration, and debugging processes. As monitoring is a continuous activity, and data can be of different forms used for different purposes, the use of an analytics platform for monitoring and further analysis is necessary. The novelties in this paper include the methods for deploying a lightweight Kubernetes and its monitoring on top of the cluster that consists of twenty single-board computers Raspberry Pi 5.

title: KCNN: A 1D Kernel Enhanced CNN Aided Feature Fusion Technique for Multi-level Anxiety Detection from Wearable ECG Sensor Signal
authors: Jyeshtar, Arkapravo Dey, Saptarshi Chatterjee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This work proposes heart rate variability (HRV) and kernel enhanced 1D-CNN based feature fusion technique for automatic anxiety detection from single channel wearable electrocardiogram (ECG) sensor signals. From the ECG sensor signals R-peaks are detected employing non-linear energy operator to extract efficient HRV features. To extract the inherent temporal features from the ECG signals a set of preinitialized filters have been incorporated in a kernel-enhanced convolutional neural network model (1D-KCNN). Fused features are used with some standard classifiers to identify normal, light, moderate and severe anxiety levels. The performance of the algorithm for detection of anxiety is evaluated on a publicly available wearable ECG sensor dataset. This work has achieved 97.85% accuracy with 97.49% F1-score for detection of four anxiety classes using cross gradient boosting (XGBoost) model from short duration ECG signals. This work has outperformed recently published works on anxiety detection from ECG and multi-modal physiological signals.

title: Comparative Analysis of the Efficiency of Window Functions for the Frequency Measurement Method Based on the Amplitude Spectrum Analysis
authors: Anton V. Pavlovich, Artem S. Orlov, Gennady V. Antipov, Elizaveta V. Koniushenko, Nikolay A. Serov, Andrey N. Serov
publish: 2025 XXXV International Scientific Symposium Metrology and Metrology Assurance (MMA)
abstract: The frequency of an electric network is its most important parameter. High accuracy of frequency measurement in real electric networks allows for high accuracy of measurement of other electric parameters, which include the root-mean-square value, active power, reactive power, apparent power and a number of electric power quality parameters. One of the most promising measurement methods is the method based on obtaining the signal spectrum and then finding the frequency corresponding to its maximum. The main source of methodical error in this approach is associated with the socalled “spectrum leakage” effect. To eliminate this effect, weighting functions are often used, the effectiveness of which is limited. In this article, a comparative analysis of the applied weighting functions is performed and their effectiveness is estimated. The cases of a rectangular window, a Hanning window and a window with maximum suppression in side lobes are considered for cases of spectrum approximation using three samples. The effectiveness of the approaches is estimated for the case of a sinusoidal signal, a sinusoidal signal distorted by noise and a polyharmonic input signal. Using the Matlab software package, a simulation model was obtained, which allowed us to check the correctness of the obtained analytical expressions and evaluate the effectiveness of the approaches under consideration.

title: Development of a Neural Network for Road Surface Defect Detection
authors: Michail Zhesterev, Stepan Sinepupov, Victor Mesherekov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper addresses the critical task of automating road infrastructure monitoring through the application of computer vision technologies. We present the development and training process of a convolutional neural network for detecting road surface defects such as potholes and cracks. The study details the stages of dataset preparation, comprising publicly available and augmented imagery, model architecture selection, and validation. The implemented software, based on the TensorFlow framework and utilizing transfer learning with a pre-trained EfficientDet model, achieves a detection accuracy of 0.69. The solution is integrated into a software pipeline for processing video streams and is designed for use within an unmanned aerial vehicle -based road inspection system. The results confirm the feasibility of using single-shot detectors for automated road condition analysis and outline directions for future model optimization and deployment on edge devices.

title: AI-Powered Augmented Reality (AR) Approach for Real-Time Wound Healing Visualization and Infection Risk Prediction
authors: Kiran Poojary, Anushree Raj, K. Annapoorneshwari Shetty, Khadersab Adamsab
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems and Pioneering Innovations in Robotics and Electric Mobility (INSPIRE)
abstract: Managing wounds is a critical aspect of healthcare, particularly for patients whose injuries heal slowly or become chronic. Conventional assessments typically depend on visual inspection by clinicians, a process that is often inconsistent, subjective, and time-intensive. In this work, we introduce a browser-based platform that merges a U-Net deep learning network with Augmented Reality (AR) to deliver live wound segmentation and infection risk indication through a standard camera feed. The system was trained on a diverse set of wound images covering different categories such as diabetic ulcers, surgical incisions, and burns, and included variations in skin tones and lighting to ensure wider applicability. Experimental evaluation shows that the U-Net achieved high accuracy (Dice = 0.91, IoU = 0.87, sensitivity = 0.89, specificity = 0.93), exceeding the performance of conventional CNN models by about 12%. The AR module overlays wound contours and potential risk regions directly on the real-time stream, offering clear and immediate visual cues to both patients and medical staff. This solution provides a step toward earlier infection detection, improved remote monitoring, and reduced clinical workload, while also being accessible without specialized equipment.

title: Prospects for Quantum Computing in Onboard Computer Systems for Robotics
authors: Nikita Bocharov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: This paper evaluates the prospects for applying quantum computing to the onboard computing systems of robots amid rapidly growing computational demands that strain conventional scaling and parallelism. We outline robot-specific requirements—performance, real-time guarantees, size-weight-power (SWaP), and reliability—and survey quantum algorithms relevant to core workloads, including combinatorial optimization (e.g., Grover, variational methods), selected linear-algebra subroutines (e.g., HHL), spectral transforms, and elements of quantum machine learning. A modeling frame-work is described for benchmarking these methods against classical baselines and for integrating quantum simulation into existing toolchains.Results indicate promising acceleration for search/optimization and certain perception and estimation subroutines, while end-to-end gains depend critically on state preparation, oracle construction, error rates, and measurement overhead. Given current hardware and SWaP constraints, immediate onboard deployment is unrealistic; instead, we propose a staged path: near-term offboard/cloud assistance for pre- and post-processing, medium-term hybrid classical–quantum pipelines, and longer-term integration of compact quantum coprocessors as devices mature. The paper concludes with practical guidance on workload selection and evaluation criteria for robots.

title: Block Ballot: Universal Verifiability in e-Voting System
authors: Teguh Nurhadi Suharsono, Renandh Alifian Putra Teguh, Gunawan Gunawan, Slamet Risnanto, Sofiani Nalwin Nurbani, Rosadi Rosadi
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Electronic voting (e-voting) is a digital system designed to facilitate both the casting and tabulation of votes in an election. Furthermore, it has been a major focus of research in cryptography over the past few decades. The proposed technique for implementing Universal Verifiability in the e-voting system for this research is the Block Ballot method. The Block Ballot method is effective for handling voting requests in electronic voting environments. The system treats every voter’s choice as an exchange that gets aggregated into a poll box, allowing the tally of votes to be monitored through the Block Ballot structure. Anyone can agree on the final count thanks to the Block Ballot’s audit trail, which allows the total number of votes to be confirmed by verifying that no data was altered, removed, or improperly introduced into the block. Based on several simulations, the block ballot method has been successfully used for the purposes of universal verifiability at the e-voting stage. The block ballot method in this study produced a universal verifiability degree of 1, which shows that the block ballot has reached the best universal verifiability degree value compared to other methods.

title: Simulation on High-altitude Nuclear Explosion Pulsed X-ray Detection Based on Lobster-eye Optical Imaging
authors: Yunfei Zhu, Peng Li, Xiaoqiang Li, Kai Zhang, Linhe Du, Hongjia Liu, Yanbin Wang, Yuan Wang, Shuang Zhang, Xiong Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: Lobster-eye technology utilizing direct X-ray imaging features a wide field of view, high resolution, and exceptional sensitivity, thereby enabling the detection of faint pulsed X-ray signals. This study employs the Monte Carlo method to simulate the pulsed X-ray arrival spectra generated by a 1-kt-yield high-altitude nuclear explosion at burst heights of 40–60 km. Additionally, the ray-tracing method is utilized to model the transmission process and imaging outcomes of pulsed X-rays within the lobster-eye optical system. Through these simulations, the feasibility of the lobster-eye optical system in detecting low-yield and low-burst-height high-altitude nuclear explosions is confirmed. This study broadens the detection range for high-altitude nuclear explosions, offering an innovative technical approach for developing detection technologies targeting low-yield and low-burst-height high-altitude nuclear explosions.

title: Nested Quasi-Newton Optimization for Federated Learning Under Periodic Deterministic Communication Constraints
authors: Lei Zhao, Wu-Sheng Lu, Lin Cai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables decentralized model training while preserving data privacy, however, real-world deployments are often constrained by Periodic Deterministic Communication (PDC) schedules, where communication between clients and the central server occurs at fixed intervals due to bandwidth limitations, energy constraints, or regulatory restrictions. These rigid schedules introduce fundamental challenges, including delayed model updates, model drift, inefficient convergence, and heightened sensitivity to non-IID data distributions, which undermine FL performance in practical settings. To address these limitations, we propose Federated Nested Quasi-Newton Optimization (FedNQN), a novel framework that accelerates convergence and enhances FL robustness under PDC constraints. FedNQN integrates curvature-aware central acceleration with variance-controlled local adaptation, ensuring stable learning dynamics despite restricted communication. At the global level, second-order curvature information accelerates model updates, compensating for infrequent synchronization, while local updates leverage variance-controlled optimizations to mitigate drift and adapt to heterogeneous data distributions. This coordinated optimization strategy enhances convergence speed, improves model accuracy, and maintains computational efficiency, making FL more adaptable to real-world constraints. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets validate FedNQN’s effectiveness, demonstrating superior performance over state-of-the-art FL methods in terms of stability, scalability, and resilience to communication inefficiencies.

title: Demystifying Evidence-Theory-Based Novel Uncertainty Quantification: A “Cut-Merge” Approach for Mitigating Overconservative Reliability
authors: Rui-Shi Yang, Hai-Bin Li, Hong-Zhong Huang, Yong Yang, Li-Jun Sun, Xiao Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: In recent years, the quantification of structural uncertainty using evidence theory has been widely adopted. However, there is a long-term difficult problem of overconservative reliability in this field. This article reveals that the “one-vote veto” phenomenon in the mapping mechanism of the focal element's basic probability assignment (BPA) to the reliable domain is the fundamental reason. Thus, the rational mapping of focal element's BPA to the reliable domain is a new problem that has not yet been paid attention to and is in urgent need of a solution. To address this new scientific problem, a “cut-merge” approach for uncertainty quantification inspired by triangular distribution is proposed. Its core idea is “cutting” first and then “merging.” “Cutting” is to construct two extreme probability density functions (PDFs) that obey the triangular distribution on each focal element, and “merging” is to integrate the extreme joint PDF on the reliable domain, to realize the scientific mapping of focal element's BPA. This method eliminates the need for extreme value analysis of focal elements and requires only the computation of two definite integrals to obtain the reliability interval. The results of an artificial synthetic case with a known true distribution of focal elements show that the proposed method is obviously superior to the traditional method in most engineering scenarios. The results of four application examples show that compared with the traditional method, the proposed method reduces the uncertainty interval width by 64.81% on average and increases the smoothness index by 67.01% on average. This work provides a new theoretical tool for structural reliability analysis.

title: Parameterization of Volume Sampling for Active Learning of Radiance Field
authors: Ruiqi Li, Yiu-ming Cheung, Zhikai Hu, Yonggang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Radiance field techniques have demonstrated remarkable performance in reconstructing photorealistic real-world scenes. However, a widely recognized limitation of these methods is their reliance on densely captured images for training. Active learning offers a promising solution by selecting the most informative images to capture. An effective measure of data informativeness is the mutual information between the unknown image and the model parameters, known as the expected information gain. Naive estimation of this quantity requires inferring both the model and predictive distributions, which is computationally intractable for high-dimensional parameter spaces. In this work, we propose a computationally tractable method to estimate information gain. Instead of sampling in the high-dimensional model parameter space, we leverage the ray sampling process inherent in volume rendering to approximate the expected information gain. Specifically, we parameterize volume sampling with perturbed ray directions and learn the predictive distribution to infer optimal perturbation patterns. Furthermore, we derive an empirical risk decomposition that demonstrates how our method effectively explores the volume sampling space to enhance diversity, leading to efficient and informative view selection. Experiments show that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance in image quality for active learning of radiance fields, outperforming previous methods across various datasets, including both forward-facing and object-centric scenes.

title: Sea Fog Microphysics and Visibility Retrieval Using a 94 GHz Millimeter-Wave Radar on an Unmanned Surface Vehicle
authors: Rui Shi, Cuina Li, Yong Lei, Yunong Guan, Yuxiao Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Sea fog is a frequently occurring and potentially hazardous meteorological phenomenon. To better capture its dynamic characteristics within complex marine environments, this study conducted six cruise observation experiments off the eastern coast of Huangdao Station in Shandong Province by using a millimeter-wave cloud radar operating at a frequency of 94GHz mounted on an unmanned surface vehicle (USV). First, a comparative analysis was performed against the 35-GHz cloud radar installed at Huangdao Station to evaluate their capability in characterizing sea fog. The results showed that both radars were capable of detecting the vertical distribution of sea fog, while the 94GHz millimeter-wave radar exhibited higher sensitivity to capture weak fog particles during in the early stage of fog formation. Subsequently, Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM) was employed to investigate the relationships among key meteorological variables—forward visibility, relative humidity, air temperature, wind speed—and radar echo intensity. The analysis revealed a significant interrelationship among these variables, with a path coefficient of 0.72 for their collective influence on radar echo intensity. Radar echo intensity exhibited a significant positive response to relative humidity and a significant negative response to forward visibility (p<0.001). In addition, forward visibility was retrived using both the Generalized Additive Model (GAM) and Extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost). The results demonstrated that XGBoost achieved substantially higher predictive accuracy, with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>>0.819. This indicates that XGBoost more effectively captures the dynamic variability of visibility within fog-affected marine environments.
