title: Failure-Aware Multi-Robot Coordination for Resilient and Adaptive Target Tracking_supp1-3647786.mp4
authors: Lifeng Zhou
publish: N/A
abstract: Multi-robot coordination is crucial for autonomous systems, yet real-world deployments often encounter various failures. These include both temporary and permanent disruptions in sensing and communication, which can significantly degrade system robustness and performance if not explicitly modeled. Despite its practical importance, failure-aware coordination remains underexplored in the literature. To bridge the gap between idealized conditions and the complexities of real-world environments, we propose a unified failure-aware coordination framework designed to enable resilient and adaptive multi-robot target tracking under both temporary and permanent failure conditions. Our approach systematically distinguishes between two classes of failures: (1) probabilistic and temporary disruptions, where robots recover from intermittent sensing or communication losses by dynamically adapting paths and avoiding inferred danger zones, and (2) permanent failures, where robots lose sensing or communication capabilities irreversibly, requiring sustained, decentralized behavioral adaptation. To handle these scenarios, the robot team is partitioned into subgroups. Robots that remain connected form a communication group and collaboratively plan using partially centralized nonlinear optimization. Robots experiencing permanent disconnection or failure continue to operate independently through decentralized or individual optimization, allowing them to contribute to the task within their local context. We extensively evaluate our method across a range of benchmark variations and conduct a comprehensive assessment under diverse real-world failure scenarios. Results show that our framework consistently achieves robust performance in realistic environments with unknown danger zones, offering a practical and generalizable solution for the multi-robot systems community.

title: Data-Driven Bias-Lyapunov Iteration for Optimal Control of Unknown Markovian Jump Linear Systems
authors: Ruiqing Zhang, Huaiyuan Jiang, Bin Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: In this paper, a bias-Lyapunov iteration method is proposed to solve the optimal control problem of unknown Markovian jump linear systems. By incorporating a bias parameter into the conventional Lyapunov iteration method, the proposed method eliminates initial admissible control requirements. A model-based theoretical framework is subsequently established, accompanied by a rigorous convergence proof for the modified iteration process. Subsequently, a data-driven version of bias-Lyapunov iteration is developed to learn an optimal control for Markovian jump linear systems with completely unknown dynamics. Simulation examples validate the efficacy and advantage of the proposed bias-Lyapunov iteration method.

title: Semantic Communication and Control Co-Design for Multi-Objective Distinct Systems
authors: Abanoub M. Girgis, Hyowoon Seo, Mehdi Bennis
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: This letter introduces a deep learning approach to predict the semantic control dynamics of different systems with different dynamics and control rules. By leveraging the Koopman operator in an autoencoder (AE) framework, the system's state evolution is linearized in the latent space using a dynamic semantic Koopman (DSK) model, capturing the baseline semantic dynamics. Moreover, the signal temporal logic (STL) is incorporated through a logical semantic Koopman (LSK) model to encode system-specific control rules. These models form the proposed semantic logical Koopman AE that reduces communication and computational costs without compromising control performance, showing a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$91.65\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> reduction in communication samples and significant performance gains in simulation.

title: Investigation of Tracking Performance for Par-4 Delta Parallel Robot with Nature-Inspired Optimizations of Fuzzy-PID Controller
authors: Shaymaa Mahmood Mahdi, Ahmed I. Abdulkareem, Amjad J. Humaidi, Ammar K. Al Mhdawi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The Par-4 Delta parallel robot is a powerful candidate in most pick and place applications which requires high speed, high acceleration and high precision. The control design is the key for improving the tracking accuracy of parallel robots. The PID controller, includes proportional, integral and derivative terms for tuning the controller. However, optimal tuning process of PID controller is cumbersome unless optimization techniques are proposed. In this study, Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA) and Fuzzy logic controller are proposed to tune the parameters of controller. The objective of these methods is to optimally tune the parameters of PID controller towards global minimum of tracking errors. Using the Root Mean Square of Error (RMSE) as the metric of evaluation, the numerical results showed that the Fuzzy PID controller with WOA optimized parameters by 77.3% on the xaxis and 66.7% on the z-axis as compared to the other implemented methods.

title: Robosurg: Resilience of Vision-Language Models Against Adversarial Attacks in Robotic Surgery
authors: Ufaq Khan, Umair Nawaz, Mustaqeem Khan, Abdulmotaleb El Saddik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Image Computing: Techniques and Applications (DICTA)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and visionlanguage models (VLMs) is revolutionizing robotic-assisted surgeries by enhancing decision-making and operational precision. Despite these advances, the robustness of VLMs against adversarial attacks, particularly in surgical scene understanding via Visual Question Answering (VQA), is not well understood. These models are integral to surgical accuracy but may be vulnerable to data perturbations that can compromise patient outcomes. This paper introduces RoboSurg, a framework designed to protect VLMs against such adversarial threats in surgical environments. We tailor adversarial attacks to the surgical domain, exposing significant vulnerabilities in widely used models such as SurgicalGPT, BLIP, BLIP-2, and CLIP-ViL. RoboSurg incorporates multimodal adversarial training, advanced input preprocessing, and targeted architectural modifications to enhance the strength of these models. Our experimental results demonstrate that RoboSurg effectively lowers the impact of adversarial threats while maintaining model performance under normal operating conditions. Furthermore, the first study of adversarial attacks on VLMs in a surgical context is presented in this paper, and bringing AI solutions to the forefront of safety and reliability marks a significant achievement.

title: Automated Orthopedic Sole Fabrication Using Gradient Boost-Based Anthropometric Prediction and CNC G-code Generation
authors: Duraiarasu E, Madhav Rao, Ananthanarayanan B, Brahadeesh V RA, Kaarunya Shree G, Ajay Kumar K
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: In the field of personalized footwear and orthopedic sole manufacturing, acquiring accurate lower limb measurements is essential. While numerous image-based techniques—such as OpenCV with a reference object—have been explored for capturing foot dimensions, these methods often suffer from limitations including occlusion, perspective distortion, and missing or inaccurate parameters. To address these challenges, this study introduces an optimized predictive pipeline using the Gradient Boost algorithm to estimate foot length and horizontal breadth with accuracy. Unlike traditional predictive models that rely on generalized features such as BMI, gender, height, or weight, our model leverages refined anthropometric parameters from the ANSUR II dataset to achieve higher accuracy. The predicted values are used to generate a 2D outline of the sole, which is then converted into G-code compatible with CNC machines for contactless, precision-cut insole manufacturing. This approach significantly streamlines the production of custom orthopedic soles, offering scalable, non-invasive, and clinically relevant solutions for individualized foot care. Accurate determination of foot dimensions is critical to diagnosing and treating flat feet, diabetic foot ulcers, plantar fasciitis, and limb-length disparities. Traditional casting and manual mensuration methods are slow, error-prone, and rely on clinical judgment and skill, and commercial image-based solutions are commonly marred by imprecision due to occlusions and perspective distortions. The new Gradient Boost predictive pipeline offers a non-invasive, rapid, and accurate alternative by predicting horizontal breadth and foot length from anthropometric inputs. With automatic generation of CNC-compatible G-code from predicted mensuration, the system enables rapid production of customized orthopedic soles and insoles with minimal manual intervention. This elevates patient comfort, reduces risk of pressure-related injuries and damage, and enhances mobility outcomes, especially among diabetic, geriatric populations, and post-surgical individuals. The solution is interoperable with modern telemedicine and digital orthotics workflows and enables scalable deployment within rehab units, home-based environments, and hospital settings.

title: Flood Disaster Sentiment on Social Media Using IndoBERT and Support Vector Machine
authors: Ade Sutedi, Novan Rodiansyah, Rinda Cahyana, Lenny Kristianti, Reza Sacful Rahman, Slamet Risnanto
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: Hydro-meteorological disasters such as floods are increasingly intense in Indonesia as a result of climate change, environmental degradation, and unstructured urban development. In the digital era, social media platforms like X provide abundant text data that can be leveraged to analyze public sentiment toward flood-related events. This study aims to evaluate and compare the performance of the IndoBERT model and the Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm for sentiment classification on flood-related tweets in Indonesia. The analysis involves three different feature representation techniques Bag of Words (BoW), Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF), and Word2Vec embeddings for contextual representation. Additionally, the impact of Chi- Square feature selection on classification accuracy is examined. The dataset consists of 1080 Indonesian-language tweets collected through a crawling process and labeled automatically using a pretrained sentiment classification model. Results indicate that sentiment in the dataset is dominated by the negative class (62.7%), reflecting public concern and criticism toward flood management efforts. SVM+TF-IDF achieved the highest score for accuracy about 92.35% without feature selection and 0.92 for the evaluation matric, while IndoBERT also demonstrated strong performance on the same dataset compared to Word2Vec and after Chi-Square feature selection. These findings suggest that frequency-based features remain effective for short-text sentiment tasks using SVM, while contextual embeddings from models like IndoBERT offer promising complementary approaches.

title: Penetration tests on web applications using SQL Injection attacks
authors: Ivan D. Ivanov, Todor Grigorov, Semona Kovacheva
publish: 2025 33rd National Conference with International Participation (TELECOM)
abstract: Web application penetration testing is essential to ensure the security and reliability of software systems. Penetrating web applications can reveal vulnerabilities that can otherwise be exploited by malicious individuals, which can lead to serious consequences such as data leakage, privacy breaches, and reputation loss. In this document, we look at SQL Injection attacks, paying particular attention to the analysis of the result of the executed attacks, and the mechanisms to protect against SQL Injection.

title: An Improved YOLOv10-Based Algorithm for Student Behavior Detection in Classroom Environments
authors: Jiran Zhao, Guangfeng Guo, Baowei Liu, Zhixue Liu, Xintian Zhang, Pengyu Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Trustworthy Big Data and Artificial Intelligence (ICTBAI)
abstract: With the growing integration of artificial intelligence in smart education, recognizing student behavior in classrooms has become a key task for enhancing teaching quality and learning efficiency. To address this, we propose a lightweight and high-precision detection model, PSM-YOLO, based on the YOLOv10 framework. The model introduces a PASP-Path for small-object awareness, integrating Parallel Patch Attention (PPA) and Spatially Preserving Convolution (SPD-Conv) to enhance perception of small targets and critical local regions. The original detection head is replaced with a Detect_MBConv module, which combines inverted residual blocks and SE attention to significantly reduce computation and model size. Finally, the PIoU_v2 loss function is employed, incorporating geometric penalties and a non-monotonic attention mechanism to improve localization accuracy and convergence stability for medium-quality samples. Experimental results on a custom student behavior dataset show that PSM-YOLO achieves 87.9% mAP@50 while maintaining a compact model size of only 4.1 MB, striking a balance between accuracy and lightweight design suitable for embedded edge deployment. This study offers a practical algorithmic framework for small-object modeling and trustworthy deployment in smart education systems, with broad applicability in embedded AI, edge computing, and intelligent educational environments.

title: Analysis of Methods for Evaluating Responses of LLMs in Retrieval-Augmented Generation
authors: Kiril Traykov, Yuliana Kolova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems are increasingly employed to provide domain-specific, context-aware answers by combining large language models (LLMs) with external knowledge sources. However, evaluating the quality of chatbot responses, particularly when underlying document sets evolve over time, remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we investigate methods for assessing changes in RAG-generated answers before and after an update of the underlying knowledge base. We construct a dataset of paired responses (baseline vs. updated) and explore a spectrum of evaluation strategies: from modern LLM-based judgments to lightweight small language models (SLMs) and classical pre-trained architectures such as BERT. Our study focuses on the central question: Is the updated response better, worse, or equivalent compared to the baseline? We report experimental results across different models, highlighting strengths, weaknesses, and biases in automated comparative evaluation. The findings provide insights into practical approaches for response quality assessment in evolving RAG systems, offering a foundation for more robust and scalable evaluation pipelines in real-world applications.

title: AI-Driven Real Estate: Opportunities, Cyber Risks, and Emerging Challenges
authors: Rumen Ketipov, Lyubka Doukovska, Mariya Ketipova
publish: 2025 International Conference on Big Data, Knowledge and Control Systems Engineering (BdKCSE)
abstract: This paper examines the integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in the real estate investment domain, with particular emphasis on its potential to improve portfolio optimization through enhanced data integration, predictive accuracy, and advanced risk assessment. AI enables the identification of hidden patterns, demand forecasting, and more precise decision-making in a sector characterized by complex interdependencies and extensive datasets. At the same time, the adoption of AI introduces new cybersecurity risks that are subtle, multifaceted, and often difficult to detect. Such risks threaten the fundamental objectives of information security - confidentiality, integrity, and availability - and may arise during both the development and deployment of AI models. To illustrate possible responses, the paper highlights mitigation strategies noted in recent literature and emphasizes the importance of adopting transparent, adaptive, and risk-aware practices within the real estate sector. Finally, it points to advanced technologies, including blockchain and quantum-based methods, as potential enablers of greater resilience and security in AI-driven real estate investment.

title: UAV Swarm Tactics: An Agent-Based Simulation Study on Resource Allocation and Retreat Strategies in Asymmetric Engagements
authors: Irina Zaitseva, Oleg Malafeyev, Kun Zhang, Dmitry Shlaev, Victoria Bondar, Tatiana Smirnova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) swarms are increasingly recognized for their potential in complex operational environments. Effective command and control, particularly concerning resource allocation and tactical decision-making like retreat maneuvers, remain critical research areas. This paper presents an agent-based simulation framework to investigate the interplay between team composition, resource limits, and behavioral thresholds in asymmetric UAV swarm engagements. The simulation features two opposing teams: a blue team employing Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) for reconnaissance and Brown-Robinson game theory for specialized hunter drone tasking, and a red team utilizing Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) for adaptive roster selection and spawn positioning, coupled with a rule-based tactical decision module. We specifically analyze the impact of three key parameters on the red team's performance: (1) the maximum allowable team weight, (2) a health-based retreat threshold, and (3) a firepower-imbalance-based retreat threshold. By systematically varying these parameters, this study aims to elucidate their influence on mission outcomes, drone survivability, and overall swarm effectiveness, offering insights into robust strategy development for autonomous UAV operations.

title: Modular Communication Service Managed by Microservices
authors: Peter Farkaš, Martin Bobák
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Modern information systems face growing challenges related to performance, scalability, and resource efficiency. Among the key solutions to these challenges are virtualization and containerization, which play a fundamental role in modern IT infrastructures, particularly in cloud computing, microservices, and software deployment. Microservices, when combined with containerization, offer enhanced scalability, modularity, and deployment flexibility, making them ideal for real-time applications such as chat systems. Unlike traditional monolithic architectures, which struggle with agility and scalability, microservices allow for independent scaling and management of system components, optimizing resource utilization. This paper presents a modular communication service based on microservices architecture, demonstrating how event-driven messaging (Kafka), WebSockets for real-time interactions, and MinIO for distributed storage enable scalable, low-latency communication. Additionally, it explores how container orchestration with Kubernetes ensures automated deployment, fault tolerance, and high availability.

title: Observation Anomaly Detection for Block Adjustment of Satellite Images Based on Accuracy Propagation
authors: Yan Zhao, Yingdong Pi, Mi Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Block adjustment is necessary for high-precision processing and the application of satellite images. The key to ensuring the quality of block adjustment is obtaining sufficient, reliable, and evenly distributed tie points through image matching. However, the automatic image matching technology is affected by multiple factors, such as imaging geometry, radiation quality, land cover, imaging time, etc., which lead to observation anomalies such as weak connections and disconnection of images in an image block. Particularly, when the scale of an image block is large, various observation anomalies may exist, which can neither be found in block adjustment through counting the number of tie points nor can be detected by the test of the relative positioning accuracy of tie points after block adjustment, resulting in inhomogeneous internal accuracy of an image block and severely affecting the quality of block adjustment. To solve this problem, this paper proposes an automatic detection method for observation anomalies based on accuracy propagation within an image block, which achieves the accurate detection of various observation anomalies in the block beforehand to ensure the quality of block adjustment.

title: Exposing Digital Illusions: A Comparative Analysis of CNN Architectures for Deepfake Detection
authors: Panchadip Bhattacharjee, Advithiya Duddu, Gururaj H. L, Shreyas J
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Deepfake detection is an important line of defense against online deception, and convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are the cornerstone of contemporary detection frameworks. This paper is a comparison of three CNN frameworks - VGGFace16, DenseNet-121, and a self-designed custom CNN - on real vs. fake face discrimination using a dataset of $140,000+$ images. We utilized Explainable AI (XAI) methods, i.e., SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) and LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations), to promote the interpretability of our bespoke CNN model. Our methodology attains classification accuracy values above 95% for all models, with the custom CNN showing equivalent performance to pre-trained models and even better. The research shows the advantages of using XAI in deepfake detection while studying architectural trade-offs between computational efficiency and feature extraction. Quantitatively, our tailored CNN obtains an ROC AUC of $\mathbf{0. 9 9 5 6}$-well above VGGFace16 (0.9601) and DenseNet-121 (0.9924)-and is computationally effective, whereas qualitatively, the application of SHAP and LIME provides transparent explanations of the decision process, improving model transparency and credibility for real-world applications.

title: Deep Recurrent Q-Network Based MAC Scheduling Optimization Using Bandwidth Parts in 5G and Beyond
authors: Animesh Kumar, Ram Aditya S, Shyamal Dhua, Ashok Kumar Reddy Chavva, Vimal Bastin Edwin Joseph
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Bandwidth part (BWP) was introduced by 3GPP as a 5 G New Radio (NR) feature in Release 15. The performance of a User Equipment (UE) in each BWP depends on various factors such as its positioning, channel conditions, and fading. Due to these factors, a UE may perform relatively better in one BWP as compared to another. Considering this variation in performance, dynamically choosing the best BWP for a UE helps in increasing the throughput and reducing the delay to achieve better spectral efficiency. In this work, we address this problem through an MDP (Markov Decision Process) formulation which is solved using a Deep Recurrent Q-Network (DRQN) model. We highlight how our solution can also flexibly consider the different Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) required for different service types and UE priority classes to achieve better system performance overall. Using a time window based approach, the inference overhead is also reduced, and we discuss methods to address some potential deployment issues. We test the solution in various scenarios, achieving improvements of up to 50 in delay and 17 in throughput.

title: Recurrent Tsetlin Machine for Sequence Learning
authors: Congyi Xu, Shengyu Duan, Rishad Shafik, Alex Yakovlev
publish: 2025 International Symposium on the Tsetlin Machine (ISTM)
abstract: Sequential data processing remains challenging for interpretable machine learning, particularly in edge computing, where transparency and efficiency are essential. While Tsetlin Machines (TMs) achieve competitive performance in static pattern recognition, they process samples independently, limiting the application to sequential learning requiring temporal dependencies. This paper introduces the Recurrent Tsetlin Machine (RTM), extending TMs to sequential learning by using clause outputs from previous time steps as the recurrent state. This approach preserves TM’s interpretable Boolean operations while enabling temporal pattern recognition. The RTM evaluation on the C-element learning demonstrates significantly improved performance compared to conventional TMs (>95% vs 57%), with the model naturally converging to Finite State Machine representations that autonomously discover Mealy-machine-like behaviour with deterministic state transitions. This work establishes the first successful recurrent extension of Tsetlin Machines, opening opportunities for interpretable sequential learning.

title: A Machine Learning-Based Web Dashboard for Public Sentiment Analysis of Regional Elections Using Random Forest
authors: Fikri Fauzian, Slamet Risnanto, Gunawansyah, Rini Nuraini Sukmana, Didin Saepudin, Nurhaeni Sikki
publish: 2025 19th International Conference on Telecommunication Systems, Services, and Applications (TSSA)
abstract: This study presents the development of a machine learning-based web dashboard for public sentiment analysis concerning the 2024 West Java Regional Election. Utilizing data collected from the social media platform X (formerly Twitter), the system aims to extract and classify user sentiments related to political candidates. A total of 3,905 tweets were collected using specific election-related keywords, followed by preprocessing stages such as cleaning, normalization, tokenization, and stemming. Sentiment labels positive, negative, and neutral were assigned using an automatic annotation approach with the TextBlob library. Feature representation was performed using GloVe (Global Vectors for Word Representation), and classification was conducted using the Random Forest algorithm. The best classification performance achieved an accuracy of 64% with the 80:20 training-test split, with the neutral class yielding the highest F1-score (0.71). The system was deployed as an interactive web dashboard using Streamlit, providing real-time visual insights into public sentiment trends. This work demonstrates the integration of sentiment analysis, machine learning, and web-based delivery for enhancing political decision-making support and public engagement in regional elections.

title: Step-Cut Modification of Air-Forced Heat Sink to Improve Temperature Gradient in Power Semiconductor Modules
authors: Andrew Sharp, Henning Holzenkamp, Mobayode O. Akinsolu, Shafiul Monir, Yuriy Vagapov
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: The thermal performance of power electronic systems is critically influenced by the ability to maintain uniform temperatures across semiconductor devices. In serially mounted semiconductor arrangements, forced-air cooling often produces a progressive heating effect, causing downstream devices to operate at higher temperatures. This non-uniform thermal loading leads to localised hotspots, accelerated material degradation, and reduced operational reliability. This paper investigates passive geometric optimisation of an air-cooled aluminium heatsink to enhance thermal uniformity across three serially mounted IGBTs. A computational numerical model was developed in ANSYS Fluent, using steady-state simulations and validated by experimental temperature measurements from a physical test rig. The baseline model demonstrated temperature differences across the length of the heatsink of up to 7.85°C at 100W, confirming the presence of a significant temperature gradient. Geometric modifications were evaluated in the form of a step-cut recess in the heatsink fins. The optimised geometry, with recess depths of 31 mm and 14 mm, reduced the temperature difference to 0.43°C under identical operating conditions, representing over 90% improvement compared to the unmodified design. The findings demonstrate that position-specific geometric tailoring of heatsinks offers a cost-effective and manufacturable solution to improve temperature synchronisation in multi-device power systems.

title: Construction of a Basis of Internal States for a Transversally-Isotropic Medium in the Problem of the Action of Mass Forces
authors: Dmitriy Alekseyevich Ivanychev, Ekaterina Yurievna Levina, Diana Vladimirovna Ezdakova, Danila Igorevich Balykin
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The paper presents a technique for forming a basis of internal states in the structure of the energy method of boundary states. The finite-dimensional basis of the internal states of the medium is intended to solve the problem of determining the stress-strain state of a transversely isotropic body of rotation, which is under the influence of mass forces that change according to a cyclic law. The basis is constructed on the basis of a general solution for the medium, in which the spatial state is represented as a superposition of flat auxiliary states, for the formation of which a fundamental system of polynomials is used. After constructing a basis for a spatial state, it is orthonormalized and the desired state is expanded into a Fourier series according to the elements of the orthonormal basis. The problem comes down to finding the Fourier coefficients, which are quadratures.A solution is presented for a circular cylinder made of transversely isotropic siltstone and subject to the action of a mass force that varies according to the law of sine and cosine. The accuracy of the solution was assessed. The result is presented in graphical form.

title: SNACK: Loss Recovery Through Explicit Notification Combined with Selective Nack
authors: Jiasheng Wang, Yuehao Xu, Song He, Haotian Wu, Jian Yu, Zhijun Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: RoCE (RDMA over Converged Ethernet) performs well in a lossless network. However, its performance drops dramatically when packet loss occurs. This limitation stems from the shortcomings of traditional solutions in packet loss recovery, which are explicitly reflected in the two stages of packet loss detection and packet loss retransmission. For packet loss detection, they either rely on implicit detection, which leads to misjudgment or use explicit notification methods that cannot effectively detect multiple lost packets. For packet loss retransmission, they either adopt the Go-back-N mechanism, which is inefficient or implement selective retransmission that still fails to retransmit all missing segments accurately. To address these issues, we propose SNACK, a novel packet recovery mechanism that combines explicit notification and selective NACK(negative acknowledgment) retransmission. SNACK brings two key improvements. First, it precisely detects lost packets through dynamic window monitoring. Second, it adapts to retransmission using SNACK frames, which can selectively request missing packets. Our NS-3 simulation results show that SNACK achieves strong performance under packet loss. When the loss rate is 1%, SNACK keeps the throughput within 10% of the lossless case. In multiflow scenarios, it reduces the average FCT (Flow Completion Time) by 24.8% compared to existing methods. These results demonstrate that SNACK provides efficient loss recovery in various network conditions.

title: A Novel In-Orbit Method for Spaceborne SAR Absolute Radiometric Calibration Using Small Calibration Satellite
authors: Tian Qiu, Pengbo Wang, Yu Wang
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper presents a novel space-based approach for the absolute radiometric calibration of spaceborne Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) systems using a small calibration satellite equipped with calibration instruments such as transponders or passive reflectors to provide precise reference measurements. With the known orbital parameters of the SAR satellite, the calibration satellite parameters are appropriately designed based on Relative Orbital Element Method(ROEM), allowing the small calibration satellite to operate in a coordinated formation with the SAR satellite. In this formation, the SAR satellite can frequently observe and image the calibration satellite under the side-looking acquisition geometry, and calculate the calibration factor(CF). The proposed method reduces reliance on groundbased calibration sites, enables calibration intervals to align with the orbital period, and extends the capability for inorbit radiometric performance evaluation. More importantly, the entire calibration process is performed in the space environment, free from distortions caused by atmosphere, ionosphere, ground clutter, multipath effects and ambiguities, ensuring a truly ‘end-to-end’ measurement process.

title: Structural and Magnetic Investigations of High-Entropy Alloys for Potential Sensor Applications
authors: Lucian-Gabriel Petrescu, María-Catalina Petrescu, Chelariu Romeu, Cimpoeşu Nicanor, Axinte Mihai, Alaa Alasadi, Catalin-Daniel Constantinescu
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: FeNiCrMnAl high-entropy alloys (HEAs) offer a versatile platform for correlating structural features with magnetic behavior in multi-component systems. Their near-equiatomic compositions stabilize body-centered cubic (BCC) or mixed BCC-FCC phases, with Al addition enhancing lattice distortion and mechanical robustness. At the same time, the competing ferromagnetic contributions of Fe and Ni with the antiferromagnetic tendencies of Mn and Cr enable a wide range of magnetic responses. In this work, three FeNiCrMnAl alloys with varying Al content are synthesized and analyzed by energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS), and vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM). The results show a consistent convergence between EDS and LIBS data, with some Mn discrepancies attributed to matrix effects. Magnetic characterization reveals predominantly soft ferromagnetic behavior with low coercivity and composition-dependent anisotropy, most notably in the Al-containing alloys. These findings confirm that FeNiCrMnAl alloys combine structural stability, magnetic tunability, and sustainability, making them promising candidates for cost-effective sensor applications.

title: GaitSens: AI-Powered Gait and Mobility Analysis
authors: Harshita, Vaishnavi Moorthy, J Suresh, Shilpa Onkar Singh, Sumit Kumar, M Pushpalatha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Advancements in sensor technology and data-driven research have catalyzed innovative approaches to gait analysis and fall detection. This study explores the use of wearable sensors and novel technologies to comprehensively examine mobility and fall risks. The dataset expansion considers various factors, including walking speed, gender-specific gait patterns, surface inclination, attire, age groups, location, and real-life activities. Such multifaceted data enrichments pave the way for developing intelligent healthcare systems capable of addressing individualized mobility needs and providing targeted fall prevention strategies. The incorporation of video analysis and smartwatch data further augments the dataset’s depth, offering a more comprehensive view of gait and mobility. These advances collectively represent a paradigm shift in gait analysis, with far-reaching implications for healthcare, sports, and urban planning. Additionally, AI has transformed how individuals learn daily and businesses operate. This study also involves the building of AI features to enhance the analysis concluded by data visuals and dataset evaluation. The model built, and the dataset used for training is incorporated with an AI model to enhance the overall result.

title: Real-Time Event Simulation: Present Status and Fields of Application - A Scoping Review
authors: Márton Matula, Bence István Nagy, Roland Gulyás, Miklós Vincze, Botond Horváth, Péter Galambos, Martin Komlódi, Dániel Horti, Miklós Kozlovszky
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Real-time event simulation is increasingly vital across domains such as disaster response, robotics, and training, as it allows systems to respond immediately to changing conditions. This scoping review state-of-the-art solutions for real-time simulation, organizing them by key concepts: multiagent architectures, AI-enhanced simulation, real-time platforms, engines and gamified simulation environments. We observe that multi-agent systems (MAS) are widely used to model interacting entities, providing a realistic representation of complex scenarios. AI-driven simulation frameworks enable adaptive scenario management and personalized feedback based on user performance. Many modern simulators leverage game engines (e.g. Unity, Unreal Engine) as platforms for interactive 3D and 2D visualization. Gamified “serious game” environments create immersive, interactive scenarios that enhance learning and decision-making. Overall, the review highlights a convergence of AI, game technology, and networking in current real-time simulation solutions, and identifies future research directions for these integrated systems.

title: Autonomous Human Tracking Using Vision-LiDAR Fusion with Model Predictive Control-Based Trajectory Following
authors: Ibrahim Toy, Abdullah Yusefi, Akif Durdu
publish: 2025 14th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering (ATEE)
abstract: In this paper, a golf cart with improved autonomous driving capabilities has been used to construct a real-time human tracking application. The proposed tracking method is based on a human detection module that combines camera and LiDAR data to improve environmental perception capabilities using the YOLOv7 algorithm with sensor fusion. Following maximum accuracy human detection, the instantaneous position of the detected person is determined as the target, and optimal path following toward this target is achieved using the Model Predictive Control (MPC) algorithm. The MPC algorithm predict the required steering angle in real-time to reach the detected person by considering the vehicle's current state and dynamic constraints, while the speed value is calculated according to the remaining distance to the target. This method allows the car to track the detected person without requiring any external intervention. MPC-based tracking mechanisms in autonomous vehicle technologies are proven to be effective by the system created in this study, which exhibits reliable and secure human tracking in dynamic situations.

title: Processing of Experimental Results Using Databases on the Example of Studying the Process of Styrene-butadiene Copolymerization in the Cascade of Reactors
authors: Tatiana Mikhailova, Vladimir Mikhailov, Svetlana Mustafina
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: The study addresses the use of a database for processing the results of computational experiments on the modeling of continuous copolymerization of butadiene with styrene in the cascade of reactors. The developed database comprises experimental conditions, measurement results, and calculated parameters, thereby enabling data filtering, analysis of the influence of operating regimes on copolymer properties, and comparison with experimental findings. The proposed approach enhances the efficiency of data processing and the reproducibility of research, providing a foundation for integration with modeling and advanced data analysis methods.

title: Context-Aware Machine Learning Model for Large-Scale Text Classification
authors: R B Hussana Johar, M Prajwal, Uk Dhakshath, S Vinay, N A Shashank
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The exponential growth of textual data from news, social media, and other platforms necessitates automated systems for effective organization and categorization. Traditional text classification methods, such as rule-based approaches, often fall short due to their inability to handle large datasets, complex patterns, and evolving content efficiently. To address these challenges, this project presents a machine-learning-based system for text classification that leverages traditional algorithms like Naive Bayes and SVM.The system follows a structured pipeline that includes data collection, preprocessing, feature extraction, model training, evaluation, and deployment. By combining both classical and modern techniques, the proposed solution ensures robust classification performance with high accuracy, precision, and scalability. Key contributions include the ability to handle large datasets, capture contextual relationships in text, and deploy the model effectively for real-world use cases such as news categorization. This automated approach not only improves efficiency but also enhances classification accuracy, demonstrating superiority over traditional methods.The ultimate goal of this project is to provide a scalable, reliable, and adaptable solution to meet the growing demands of text classification applications, contributing to more streamlined and informed data processing.

title: Computer Network Abnormal Traffic Intrusion Detection Technology Based on Data Mining
authors: Yahong Sun
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Data Mining (ICDM)
abstract: Aiming at the shortcomings of traditional network intrusion detection systems in identifying new types of attacks, processing large-scale traffic, and controlling false alarms, this paper proposes a computer network abnormal traffic intrusion detection scheme based on data mining technology. A three-tier architecture system including client, application server and database server is designed, and abnormal traffic identification is realized through four functional modules: data preprocessing, feature extraction, model training, and intrusion detection response. An experiment of the designed system is conducted with the KDD99 dataset as the test object, and its performance indicators are compared with those of traditional systems. The results show that the system has a detection accuracy of 95.6%, a false alarm rate of 3.2%, a missed alarm rate of 1.2%, and a detection speed of 2000 data packets per second. All indicators are better than those of traditional systems. This system can effectively improve network security protection capabilities and provide technical support for intrusion detection in complex network environments.

title: Affordable Crop Disease Detection with Drone Imagery and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Vedant Mohapatra, Sasmita Mohapatra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: Drones and artificial intelligence (AI) offer a transformative approach to crop disease detection, enabling rapid and precise analysis beyond traditional methods. In this study, we developed and programmed a custom-built drone equipped with four 1500 kV brushless motors, a flight controller, 60-amp ESC, GPS, and a DJI O3 video transmission system. The hardware was assembled onto a carbon fiber frame with 3D-printed Thermoplastic Polyurethane (TPU) components, and a Raspberry Pi 5 was integrated for real-time inferencing. The AI model for crop disease detection was trained using drone collected data and publicly available datasets from Kaggle, leveraging PyTorch with Python3 on an HPC Cluster with an Nvidia H100 GPU and AMD EPYC 7453 CPU. Autonomous drone flight paths were planned using Litchi waypoint navigation software to create an autonomous point-to-point navigation flight path. Using the training data a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) vanilla model was developed for training and inferencing the crop diseases from the images used in the dataset. Four major crops-corn, potato, rice, and wheat- covering 10 distinct diseases were analyzed. The model achieved an accuracy between 75% and 95% for most cases, except for rice crops, where performance was lower due to the thin leaves providing fewer distinguishing features. This issue can be mitigated with additional image augmentation and fine-tuning the CNN model. Although several challenges were encountered in securing access to local farms for large-scale testing, preliminary evaluations in controlled environments-including select accessible field and park settings-yielded promising results. Field testing confirmed the drone's ability to capture high-quality images even in light rain and cloudy conditions. The system, which costs under $ 500, achieved a maximum flight time of 27 minutes, offering a cost-effective alternative to traditional soil sensors and soil culture testing. The early identification of crop diseases enables targeted interventions, conserving resources, reducing excessive pesticide use, and increasing crop yields.

title: Experimental Investigation and Behavioral Modeling of the Ron vs. Gate Overshoots Relationship in Schottky p-GaN HEMTs
authors: Ludovic Roche, David Trémouilles, Emmanuel Marcault, Corinne Alonso
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Wide Bandgap Power Devices and Applications (WiPDA)
abstract: The semi-floating p-GaN layer of commercial schottky HEMTs is suspected to be related to instabilities of the device’s electrical characteristics. Particularly, we recently explained how gate voltage spikes at turn-on can cause a drastic, lasting and reproducible dynamic Ron increase. The proposed explanation only partly matched the dynamics of the observed Ron fluctuations and only one device reference was tested. In this work, higher voltage spikes are explored and a device from an other manufacturer is also studied. We demonstrate with a ngspice simulation how all observed dynamic Ron behaviors can be explained with a two-diode model of the gate stack.

title: A Novel Hardware Efficient FPGA Implementation of Multi-Linear Regression Algorithm
authors: Velayutham Sudharsan, Shirshendu Roy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Multi-linear regression (MLR) algorithm is simple but one of the powerful machine learning algorithms for prediction where output linearly depends on the independent variables. This work proposes a novel and detailed hardware architecture for the MLR algorithm. The architecture supports both the training and testing phases of prediction operation. A linear system is solved in MLR to find the co-efficient vector. In this work, this linear system in the training phase is solved by the conjugate gradient (CG) algorithm which is an iterative algorithm. CG algorithm supports maximum resource sharing and gives better accuracy than other iterative algorithms. The architecture also uses a Gold-Schmidt iterative divider to reduce hardware complexity. The architecture is implemented on a field programmable gate array (FPGA) for validation of performance with a freely available database of student performance analysis with 5 independent variables. A relative signal-to-ratio (RSNR) of 36 dB is achieved in this work in estimating the co-efficient vector using the CG algorithm and an RSNR of 28 dB is obtained in the prediction of 256 samples. The proposed architecture is hardware efficient, supports online sample-wise training, and has less overall training time compared to all existing works. The architecture is easily applicable to all real-time applications and scalable for any parameter values.

title: RIS Assisted OTFS System for High-Doppler 5G-NR TDL Channels in mm-Wave Communications
authors: Saiteja Kalithkar, Ashvini Chaturvedi, Naga Siva Prasad Bodempudi, H Rashmi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: The efficiency of wireless communication networks has significantly advanced over the last decade, however, multifaceted challenges persist, especially in urban areas and highspeed environments that combat multipath fading and Doppler spread. Urban terrains characterized by dense infrastructure, high population density, and high-rise buildings cause signal interference, multipath propagation, and shadowing, thus resulting in poor reliability of communication links and quality of service (QoS). This paper investigates a RIS-assisted ZPOTFS system operating at mm-Wave (millimeter-Wave) frequencies for high-speed wireless scenarios to mitigate severe fading and Doppler spread limitations. Three different scenarios are modeled using appropriate 5G NR TDL channels. Performance measures, BER and throughput, are estimated and analyzed for different geographical scenarios featuring distinct surrounding dynamics, user speed, and array size of RIS. The results obtained demonstrate enhanced BER and throughput for RIS-assisted ZPOTFS systems, and offer insights for future system architecture in high-mobility 5 G and beyond 5 G (B5G) networks paradigm.

title: Smartphone App for Visually Impaired People to Determine Spatial Orientation using Vanishing Point
authors: Manabu Shimakawa, Shu Horita, Chiharu Okuma, Kimiyasu Kiyota
publish: 2025 IEEE 25th International Symposium on Computational Intelligence and Informatics (CINTI)
abstract: Visually impaired people have a strong desire to go out, but outdoors, they face numerous situations where they feel unsafe, such as colliding with obstacles, stumbling on a step or falling down stairs. If they fall from station platform, they will be in an extremely dangerous situation where they could come into contact with train. To address these challenges, various assistive technologies have been developed, including smart electronic white canes equipped with ultrasonic or ToF sensors and smartphone-based applications that offer obstacle detection and route guidance. One factor that causes anxiety for visually impaired people is losing the spatial orientation they are. This study aims to assist visually impaired people in recognizing lost spatial orientation by determining vanishing points from semi-structured environments and indicating its direction. The paper presents the system design and evaluates its effectiveness through experimental validation.

title: Intelligent Decision Support System for Designing Electrochemical Protection of Gas Pipelines
authors: Kristina Denisovna Evseenkova, Galina Viktorovna Kuznetsova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Control Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Automation and Energy Efficiency (SUMMA)
abstract: An intelligent decision support system is proposed for the design or modernization of electrochemical protection of main gas pipelines. The functional structure of the software package, information support for the system, algorithms for module interaction have been developed, and decision support mechanisms are implemented. The system accounts for monitoring data on the condition of pipeline sections, the climatic features of its operation, the presence of stray currents and calculates the optimal parameters of electrochemical protection (ECP) stations. In addition, monitoring data is used to identify damages, rank the types and criticality of defects, and form repair plans with recommendations on how to eliminate them. The scientific novelty of the work lies in a comprehensive solution for assessing the condition of pipelines, preparing repair plans, and improving the anti-corrosion protection system. The practical significance of the obtained results (software package) is determined by reducing the cost of time and resources, increasing the overall reliability and safety of pipeline operations.

title: Analyzing the Effect of Imperfect SIC in RIS-Aided NOMA Systems: Optimization and Performance Insights
authors: Helen Sheeba John Kennedy, B S Anjana, R Dipinkrishnan, Vinoth Babu Kumaravelu, Satya Kumar Vankayala, Seungil Yoon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: This study analyzes the performance under the impact of imperfect successive interference cancellation (SIC) in a non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) system enhanced by a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS). Closed-form expressions for both the outage probability and sum rate of the system are derived, considering the effects of imperfect SIC. Additionally, the power allocation factors are optimized to maximize the sum rate in the intelligent RIS-aided NOMA configuration. Results unequivocally demonstrate that, even under imperfect SIC conditions, the proposed RIS-aided NOMA system outperforms the conventional NOMA system in terms of outage probability and sum rate. Specifically, with 32 reflecting elements, the proposed system achieves the target outage at an SNR of $\sim-\mathbf{1. 4 1 ~ d B}$, whereas the conventional NOMA system requires an SNR of $\sim 27 \mathrm{~dB}$ for a SIC error rate of 9%.

title: IDTM: Interpretable Intrusion Detection with Tsetlin Machine: A Binarization-Guided Approach
authors: Charitha Gadari, Sreenivasa Reddy Yeduri, Ole-Christoffer Granmo, Linga Reddy Cenkeramaddi
publish: 2025 International Symposium on the Tsetlin Machine (ISTM)
abstract: The increasing sophistication of cyberattacks demands an intelligent and interpretable intrusion detection system (IDS) capable of operating efficiently in real-time environments. In this work, we propose IDTM, an IDS based on the Tsetlin Machine (TM), using its logic-based learning mechanism to perform accurate and explainable classification of network traffic using the CIC-IDS dataset. To address significant challenges associated with class imbalance and high dimensionality, we employ the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE), random undersampling, followed by Min-Max normalization and tailored binarization strategies. Features are discretized according to their statistical distribution: logarithmic transformation for highly skewed time-based features, quantile binning for bursty rate-based features, and uniform binning for others. This ensures compatibility with TM’s binary input requirements. Subsequently, Variance Thresholding and Extra Trees-based feature ranking were used to reduce noise to allow the model to focus on only informative features. Experimental results show that the TM achieves a high test accuracy of 99.07% while significantly outperforming conventional models in terms of inference time, demonstrating its potential as a lightweight, interpretable, and real-time-capable IDS solution. Additionally, the interpretable results demonstrate the importance of the various features of the data.

title: Supply Voltage Scaling Effects on CMOS Gate Aging Characteristics
authors: Vazgen Melikyan, Astghik Andikyan, Lavrentii Karapetian, Lilit Sargsyan, Ruben Aghoyan, Mariam Mardoyan
publish: 2025 IEEE East-West Design &amp; Test Symposium (EWDTS)
abstract: Aging is among the most critical phenomena that affect the reliability of integrated circuits (ICs), because of which the parameters of the circuit worsen with time and can even lead to the circuit failure. In this paper, we present a comprehensive analysis of the impact of supply voltage scaling on aging and delay characteristics of CMOS INVERTER, AND, OR gates and propose using high power supply VDD levels to minimize aging effects.

title: CTM-UNet: Integrating Convolutional Tsetlin Machines with U-Net Architecture for Semantic Segmentation
authors: Yi Liu, K. Darshana Abeyrathna
publish: 2025 International Symposium on the Tsetlin Machine (ISTM)
abstract: This paper investigates the integration of Convolutional Tsetlin Machines (CTM) with the U-Net architecture to evaluate whether Tsetlin machines can effectively fit and converge within established deep learning frameworks for image semantic segmentation tasks. We propose CTM-U-Net, a novel architecture that replaces traditional convolutional blocks in UNet with memory-efficient CTM blocks, leveraging the logic-based learning capabilities of Tsetlin machines while maintaining the proven encoder-decoder structure of U-Net. Our proposed structure aims to address the challenges of integrating TM/CTM with deep learning frameworks for dense learning tasks. Experimental validation in the CamVid dataset demonstrates that CTM-UNet successfully converges during training, achieving competitive performance with mean IoU scores comparable to conventional UNet while employing Tsetlin machine components. The results indicate that Tsetlin machines can indeed be effectively integrated into complex deep learning architectures, opening new avenues for semantic segmentation models that combine the logical reasoning capabilities of automata-based learning with the spatial hierarchy representation of established computer vision architectures.

title: Shaping the Future: IEEE’s Role in Emerging Trends in Electrical Engineering Education
authors: Cristian-Győző Haba
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ISEEE)
abstract: Electrical Engineering education is entering a transformative era characterized by rapid technological evolution and the increasing convergence of disciplines such as artificial intelligence, renewable energy systems, embedded computing, and the Internet of Things. These developments necessitate a reconfiguration of educational paradigms to emphasize adaptive learning, interdisciplinary collaboration, and the cultivation of innovation-oriented competencies. The latest trends point toward the integration of digital pedagogies, simulation-based learning, and outcome-driven curricula designed to prepare engineers for an environment of constant technological renewal. Within this shifting landscape, the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) plays a key role in advancing educational quality and professional development. Through its digital libraries, peer-reviewed journals, online courses, standards development, student programs, and community-driven initiatives, IEEE provides a comprehensive framework that supports lifelong learning and promotes global standards of engineering practice. Platforms such as IEEE Xplore, the IEEE Learning Network, and various specialized societies offer access to authoritative knowledge, fostering both academic inquiry and industry relevance.

title: Contrastive Learning with Generative Augmentation and Attention for HOI Detection
authors: Xinyue Tang, Hongru Ge, Na Lv, Xiaoyan Wang, Jinglan Tian
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Human-object interaction (HOI) detection aims to achieve a fine-grained understanding of images by localizing humans and objects while interpreting the actions and spatial configurations between them. Existing approaches are heavily based on extensive annotated data, limiting their applicability in open scenarios. In order to address this, we propose a novel HOI detection framework that integrates generative feature augmentation supervised by contrastive learning to enhance the discriminability of generated features. Additionally, we introduce a hard negative mining strategy to distinguish semantically similar yet distinct interaction categories. The proposed approach employs a multibranch network that aggregates multiscale features during inference. Further, self-attention and cross-attention mechanisms are utilized to enrich semantic representations and strengthen comprehension of complex interactions. Extensive experiments on HICO-DET and V-COCO datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach substantially enhances detection performance for unseen interaction categories, achieving state-of-the-art generalization and robustness in zero-shot scenarios.

title: Optimizing Asynchronous Event Dispatch in Modern C++ Publish/Subscribe Systems
authors: Alex I. Tsvetanov
publish: 2025 33rd National Conference with International Participation (TELECOM)
abstract: The paper extends the C++20 header-only library pubsub-lib, by integrating two low-overhead asynchronous dispatch strategies: C++ standard execution policies (std::execution::par, par_unseq) and Intel oneAPI TBB. Both reuse thread pools to minimize overhead. Benchmarks on a 12-core AMD Ryzen under Ubuntu/WSL show up to 100× latency reduction and significant throughput gains over std::async, with sub-microsecond per-subscriber times even at 1000 subscribers. The research concludes with guidelines for choosing dispatch strategies based on performance and portability.

title: Gate-Breaker: An LLM-Powered Netlist-to-RTL Reverse Engineering Tool
authors: Md Omar Faruque, Peter Jamieson, Ahmad Patooghy, Abdel-Hameed A. Badawy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Performance, Computing, and Communications Conference (IPCCC)
abstract: The escalating sophistication of hardware intellectual property (IP) theft, a multi-billion dollar problem for the semiconductor industry, demands novel approaches to both understanding attack vectors and fortifying defenses. This paper evaluates the potential of Large Language Models (LLMs) to reverse engineer Register Transfer Level (RTL) designs from gate-level netlists. We introduce a framework for netlist-to-RTL conversion, leveraging pattern recognition and code generation capabilities of modern LLMs. Our evaluation of four available LLM models across 156 circuit benchmarks reveals that LLMs can indeed recover functional RTL with reasonable accuracy until the RTL benchmarks become our classified 4th quartile of code complexity. We also provide a similarity metrics-based methodology to evaluate and ascertain the quality of reverse engineering. Among the evaluated models, OpenAI's O3-Mini emerged as the best performer with 75.1 % overall success rate. While performance degrades significantly on the most complex 4th quartile (53.4 % success rate), when O3-Mini does succeed on these challenging designs, it maintains a high Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) similarity of 0.924 and achieves a moderate 0.871 Control Flow Graph (CFG) similarity.

title: Member-Guided Multimodal Alignment for Text-to-Image Group Matching
authors: Lvxiang Jia, Ling Mei, Yiwei Cheng, Mingyu Fu, Bingjie Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on New Trends in Computational Intelligence (NTCI)
abstract: Text-to-image group matching aims to match group images from a few number of viewpoints using natural language descriptions. Existing datasets for this task are primarily designed for image-to-image matching, lack textual annotations, and mainly contain pedestrian groups captured from ground-based surveillance, with limited aerial perspectives. Due to the inter-group diversity and intragroup complexity of pedestrian groups, existing methods struggle to achieve robust alignment between visual and textual features of groups. To address these limitations, we introduce two cross-modal group datasets. First, we construct UAV-T by adding fine-grained textual descriptions to the existing UAV dataset. Second, we construct a new dataset by synthesizing UAV-based group images from the AG-ReID.v2 dataset: pedestrians captured from the same viewpoint are concatenated to form groups, and corresponding textual descriptions are provided to enable text-to-image group matching. Moreover, we propose Member-Guided Multimodal Alignment (MGMA) framework, a cross-modal group matching framework that effectively learns group-level representations by extracting and aligning visual and textual features of group members. Specifically, it models individual group members via Bbox-guided Masked Image Modeling (BMIM) and Masked Group Attribute Modeling (MGAM) modules to enable cross-modal interactions of group features. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves noticeable improvements over existing state-of-the-art approaches on both the AG-Group and UAV-T datasets.

title: Blockchain-Enhanced Malware Detection System
authors: S Yashaswini, K R Jayanth, S Lavanya, V Priya, A C Pavan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Given the prevalence in recent years of computergenerated ideas including constructors, email flooders, spoofers. This has now made it relatively easy for users, especially those who have little IT expertise to come up with slight modifications of the existing malware. In order to counter these threats, scholars have come up with infinite countermeasures including, static and dynamic malware analysis. These techniques are often unable to identify new malware in the main memory of the computer and otherwise involve significant work and special knowledge in the field. This project presents a memory dump analysis for malware detection with image processing and machine learning and blockchain for security and consensus. Raw data received from memory dumps is in the form of an array, which is transformed into RGB images, and from which features are identified by employing HOG descriptors. The classifiers adopted for detecting malware include Support Vector Machine (SVM) RBF kernel, Linear Support Vector Machine (SVM), eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) and Random Forests. The results achieved are then checked through a blockchain voting system, the nodes perform the same task of discriminating between malicious files or benign files followed by consensus mechanisms to check for its accuracy and its immunity to any form of alteration. This approach interfaces visual analytics and distributed policy decisions for large scale, trustworthy, malware detection.

title: Graph Neural Operators for Accurate Ice Layer Thickness Prediction From Radargram
authors: Heling Wang, Masoud Yari, Maryam Rahnemoonfar
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Accurately modeling the internal structure of the Greenland ice sheet is essential for understanding its dynamics and predicting future changes. Traditional machine learning models, such as Convolutional Neural Networks and Graph Convolutional Networks, struggle to capture the complex geometric structures in radar data, limiting their accuracy. This study applies the Graph Neural Operator (GNO) to NASA's Snow Radar dataset, representing radar images as graphs with nodes for spatial points and edges for local dependencies. GNO outperforms GCNs and GraphSAGE, achieving the lowest root mean squared error (RMSE) and providing accurate predictions of internal ice layer thickness, even in regions with high variability. These results highlight the potential of neural operators for advancing radar-based ice sheet modeling and geophysical analysis.

title: Effect of Waterproofing Material on Waveform Features of Photoplethysmography Signal
authors: Subhojit Jash, Sajan Kapil, Subramani Kanagaraj
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Computing and Communication Technologies (CONECCT)
abstract: Photoplethysmogram (PPG) is widely used to measure physiological parameters such as heart rate, respiration rate, and blood oxygen saturation, and it is easily integrated into the wearables due to its small size and affordability. In recent years, the morphological and temporal features of PPG signals have been used to comprehend the physiological mechanisms associated with healthy and pathological conditions. Despite its wide range of applications above water, its use underwater remains limited. This study examines the effect of waterproofing materials such as epoxy and silicon on the waveform features of the PPG signal. The PPG sensor used is MAX30102, and the materials are coated on its surface. The PPG signal is recorded from healthy participants for 5 minutes as they remain seated. The collected signal is pre-processed using a Chebyshev Type II bandpass filter, and six features, namely systolic peak, diastolic peak, dicrotic notch, peak-to-peak interval, systolic time and diastolic time, are extracted from the signal and compared with uncoated and coated surfaces. The signal features are also compared with different thicknesses of silicon coating. The signal quality index (SQI) for epoxy, silicone, and uncoated sensor surfaces has no significant difference. The systolic amplitude is decreased by $17 \%$ for silicon and $46 \%$ for epoxy. The peak-to-peak interval has no significant difference for the three cases, which suggests that the PPG signal frequency remains unaffected. The findings indicated that silicone is more suitable compared to epoxy for waterproofing, paving the way for future progress in wearable underwater health monitoring systems.
